Author: Marlowe, Sam
Title: A satisfying treat of plain and simple storytelling
Full_text:
First ■'night-
A satisfying treat of plain and simple storytelling
Theatre Sam Marlowe The Gruffalo Duchess Theatre • •••#.
Seven years after first being performed at Chester Gateway Theatre, Tall Stories' gently appealing adaptation of the bestselling children's book is still going strong. So much so, in fact,
that this festive West End run has been extended, giving more audiences aged 3-plus and their parents the opportunity to chime in with the rhyming refrains that are so familiar from the story by Julia Donaldson. Here, too, are all the characters who inhabit the brightly coloured woodland world of Axel Scheffler's illustrations, economically yet vividly brought to life, in Olivia
Alice Parsloe, as Mouse, meets the Gruffalo, played by Mark Peachey Jacobs's production, by a bubbly cast of three. The Gruffalo is, as its legions of young fans know, a hungry mouse's tale of adventure. Nose aquiver, the diminutive rodent sets off into the forest to search for hazlenuts to nibble — but predators lurk among the trees, eager to make a meal of this tasty mousey morsel. So Mouse resourcefully concocts an imaginary friend — a fearsome, toothy, warty creature called a Gruffalo — to scare away slavering foes. What is our tiny hero to do,
though, when it turns out that the imaginary monster is very real indeed? It's a tight squeak, but Mouse's ingenuity saves the day. Isla Shaw's set and costumes are simple and earth-toned, and James Whiteside floods the scenes with the golden-green light of a storybook pastoral morning. There's a score of jolly songs, and the trio of actors animate Donaldson and Scheffler's cartoonish creations with verve. Alice Parsloe's Mouse has a childlike innocence and enthusiasm; and Mark Peachey is both a nimble narrator and a dopey, gallumphing Gruffalo. Best of all, though, is Tom Warwick, a scene-stealer as a flat-capped, ska-singing, diamond-geezer Fox, an upper-crust flying-ace Owl and a hip-swivelling, maraca-shaking Snake. Between them they develop a warm rapport with their entranced spectators — and they even slip in a few sly jokes for the grown-ups. "Three years at drama school for this!" Warwick remarks in an aside as his moustachioed Snake lambadas into view. There are no gimmicks, no flashy props or elaborate stage business —just sweet, simple storytelling and a satisfying, seasonally snow-sprinkled happy ending. Forget all that fancy gift-wrapping, for young children this unpretentious little West End show might just make the perfect holiday treat. Box office: 0844 4124659, to Jan 11

Author: Craig, Amanda
Title: A spooky power to charm all ages
Full_text:
A spooky power to charm ■t
Meeting Neil Gaiman on the eve of the publication of The Graveyard Book, his latest, Amanda Craig finds that his wild imagination knows no boundaries — from films, to books, to theatre, and more
UNTIL LAST YEAR, Neil Gaiman may have been the most famous writer you've never heard of, but with the filming of Stardust and Beowulf, and the dramatisation of The Wolves in the Walls by the National Theatre of Scotland, all that has changed. The equivalent to a rock god ever since his cult Sandman books were published 20 years ago, Gaiman is now one of the biggest things to hit child-
ren's publishing since J. K. Rowling — also, as it happens, published by Bloomsbury. I'm in Covent Garden to interview him about The Graveyard Book, an interlinked collection of tales about Nobody, a baby boy who escapes from the serial killer who murders his entire family, and is brought up in a graveyard by ghosts, vampires and werewolves. Like his bestselling child-
ren's novel Coraline (also being filmed for release next year), it takes you into some scary places but, as he points out, what adults read as the most uncomfortable thing they can imagine, children take as a huge and thrilling adventure. "Adults know I can take them by the hand into a dark place and run away, whereas children trust me, and I want to repay that trust," he says.

Not for nothing is one of his best fantasies, Anansi Boys, about a young man who discovers that he's the son of the African god of mischief; one of the joys of reading Gaiman is how he subverts our expectations of magic, horror, fantasy and the mundane. An immensely likeable man with messy dark hair and, at 48, an endearing love of leather jackets, he was born near Portsmouth in Hampshire, the son of the last independent vitamin manufacturer in Britain. A geeky child who embarrassed his younger sister by always having his nose in a book, he went straight into writing after school. For two years he lived in Edgware and "did the starving writer thing, producing a bunch of short stories and a children's novel that everyone rejected before I realised that I hadn't written enough, lived enough". He then had a wonderful three years in the early 1980s, working as a freelance journalist for publications such as Time Out, "living off chicken wings at film screenings", and interviewing everybody he wanted to meet, including Douglas Adams and Terry Pratchett (both of whom later collaborated with him on books.) But in his mid-twenties his love of comics became too powerful to resist. Graphic novels are now pretty mainstream and respectable — when I tell Gaiman that my teenage daughter wants to become a graphic novelist he exclaims at once, "Good — then she'll become very rich!"
However, it was unexplored territory to all but adolescent males when he began the Sandman series; he still gets the owners of shops such as Forbidden Planet saying: "I got to thank you, man, for bringing women into my stores." Part of the attraction was that "unlike the novel where you'd be on the same shelf as Apuleius and Austen, comics have been around for only 100 years and there are all these cool places nobody has taken it as an art form. It's harder than writing film scripts — it's like writing, directing and editing a film." Now published as ten books, Sandman's market still keeps growing, and 20 years on, what seemed like the most disposable medium has become enshrined in leather bindings and a huge international fan base. Almost all Gaiman's books are, in a way, about someone trying desperately to fit into a dull, safe place and finding himself, like the shop-boy in Stardust, happy only in a crazy, dangerous one. His oeuvre spans the "extreme sex and weirdness" of American Gods (about a former convict travelling across the" US with a former god) to the primal fear of the picture-book The Wolves in the Walls. He loathes the concept of the crossover book, but his richly imaginative, dark fantasies have the classic element of appealing to the adult in children and the child in adults. It is no coincidence that two of the classic children's authors he most admires are Rudyard Kipling and P. L. Travers,
<NEWPAGE>
Grave outlook: Neil Gaiman in Abney Park cemetery, London
the author of Mary Poppins, both of whom had a profound influence on The Graveyard Book. Gaiman had the idea for it 20 years ago, when newly married and living in a tall thin house without a garden. He'd take his toddler son across the road to ride his tricycle in the local graveyard, and the idea of a boy brought up by dead people was "one of those wonderful, clear, perfect moments". He wrote a page and a half before realising that he needed to learn his craft if he wasn't to waste it; grappling with it every five years until finally realising in 2002 that he "wasn't going to get any better". Though inspired by the atmosphere of an English graveyard, it also fits perfectly into the Gothic, post-Poe American sensibility, and is a memorable, captivating read. Pleasingly, Gaiman himself now lives in "a huge, Addams family-style house in America, with acres of spooky woods," after realising in 1991 that he could buy his dream house there for the price of a one-bedroom flat in London. He moved his wife and three children to Minneapolis and has never looked back, writing the much-garlanded American Gods and becoming one of Hollywood's favourite writers. His own family, baffled by his choice of career (though always supportive) realised that he had "finally got cool" only after attending the premieres of Stardust and Beowulf within weeks of each other last year. The "mad artistic one" has, just like his heroes, come good.
THE GRAVEYARD BOOK by Neil Gaiman Bloomsbury, £14.99; 320pp m £13.49 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Mount, Harry
Title: A lavatory read from the 16th century
Full_text:
A lavatory read from the 16th century
Etiquette Harry Mount
A HANDBOOK ON GOOD MANNERS FOR CHILDREN De Civilitate Morum Puerilium Libellus by Erasmus trans. Eleanor Merchant WHAT DO YOU think was the world's bestselling book in the 16th century? The early Shakespeare plays, perhaps? The Bible? A royal insider's expose of the Reformation? No, it was this — a jokey, prurient little book on manners by Erasmus (1466-1536), better known as a Roman Catholic theologian and Dutch Renaissance humanist. The book, written in Latin in Freiburg in 1530, went into 130 editions over 300 years and had been translated into 22 languages within a decade of publication. You can see why it did so well. It has all the ingredients of the bestselling loo book — short, divided up into easily readable gobbets ("Silence suits a woman, and even more so a child") and, most importantly, rude. At times, the book reads more like something out of a modern lads' mag than the words of one of the most eminent classical scholars of the
15th and 16th centuries. He is all for farting at dinner — as long as you. "close the fert under colour of a cough" and don't rock from buttock to buttock on your chair and reveal that you are repeatedly farting. For anyone who thinks that modern manners have gone to the dogs, this is a salutary read. Europe in the 16th century was a much dirtier and offensive place than it is today. The Spanish, Erasmus confirms, did brush their teeth with urine. Erasmus didn't do much more than wash his mouth out — "Whitening them with fine powder is only for girls." All this means that Erasmus's tips are pretty basic. He cautions against slovenliness at a time when young men were used to staining the hems of their shirts and tunics with urine, and plastering their chests and sleeves with crusts of phlegm. In this filthy world, real reverence was shown, not for hygiene, but for king and God, in that order. The book was written for an 11-year-old boy from the Netherlands, Henry of Burgundy, son of the Prince of Vere, and throughout Erasmus stays on the side of the blue-blooded. To get his readers to acknowledge God,
teeth with fine powder is for girls'
ADVRTISING ARCHIVES «m%m^ When she was good, she was very, very good'!...
he draws on their much deeper respect for their masters: you'd be mad not to remove your cap, and bow in the presence ofthe king, wouldn't you, he says, so you should do it in church, too. For all this openness about bodily functions, though, Erasmus comes across as a bit of a snob and a killjoy. At the dinner table, he says, you mustn't gossip, talk about what you've been up to, criticise anybody else or reveal secrets. You should genuflect at the name of Jesus or the Virgin Mother, and willingly give up your seat
to someone of higher rank. And, should your bread fall on the floor, you must kiss it, in honour of the days when men treated bread with great respect. So, a night round at Erasmus's doesn't sound like much fun. But it's all very gripping to read about; partly because standards have changed so much — thank God, it's no longer outrageously rude to hold a book or a hat under your arm as it then was. A lot of etiquette has stayed the same, too — you shouldn't lick your plate ("something
cats do"), he says, although I've always thought it one of the best bits of a meal. His generalisations about manners also ring true today: ignore other people's faults but avoid falling short yourself, and always listen to your neighbour at meals. I could put up with a few phlegmencrusted sleeves if people at dinner parties followed these rules a little more today. Preface, £10; 112pp ® £9 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Koning, Christina
Title: Fiction
Full_text:
Fiction Christina Koning
MUDBOUND by Hillary Jordan Windmill, £7.99 El £7.59 (free p&p)
El To buy books at discounted prices, call 0870 1608080 or visit timesonline. co.uk/ booksfirst ir.R *r-R
Hillary Jordan ound
War and offers a bleak — if all too plausible — account of place and period. It begins with the funeral of the malevolent "Pappy" McAllan, a character who would be at home in one of William Faulkner's more grisly tales. The circumstances that led up to Pappy's death are then related by several different voices — including those of his two sons, Henry and Jamie, and Henry's wife, Laura. It is Laura with whom the reader initially sympathises most, seeing the harsh landscape with its endless flat fields and utilitarian farm dwellings from her disillusioned perspective. The attraction this bored and neglected wife feels for her brother-in-law, Jamie, whose rejection of the crudely racist tenets of his upbringing sets him apart from most of the other characters, is subtly conveyed — as is Laura's growing friendship with Florence Jackson, whose husband, Hap, is a tenant farmer on the McAllan's land. When Florence's eldest son, Ronsel, returns from the war, having served in one of the army's few black battalions, it destabilises an already fragile situation, setting in motion a chain of events that can end only in disaster. Mudbound — an unfortunate title — confronts disturbing truths about America's past with a directness and a freshness of approach that recalls Alice Walker's The Color Purple.
Jordan's tautly structured debut, selected as a Richard and Judy New Writers' Book of the Month, is' set in the Mississippi Delta in the aftermath of the Second World

Author: Null
Title: People of the Book
Full_text:
PEOPLE OF THE BOOK
Geraldine Brooks
Women, one turns to Brooks' latest work with high expectations. For here are many of the elements that made the earlier book — as well as the author's bestselling debut, Year of Wonders — so readable: lovingly described set-piece scenes; a literary framework; a sympathetic narrator. This is Hanna Heath, a young Australian book restorer given the job of stabilising a fragile sacred text. Rescued from the ruins of Sarajevo after the civil war of 1996, this 15th-century Jewish prayer book — the Haggadah — is illustrated with exquisite miniatures that hold the key to the identity of their creator. Before we can get to that, there are other layers of history to be uncovered. Thus, a scrap of butterfly's wing trapped in the binding of the Haggadah unlocks a tale of partisan resistance against the Nazis; a wine stain leads to 17th-century Venice; a cat's whisker to medieval Spain and so on. While all this is enjoyable enough, it does have a somewhat laboured feel, even where the present-day love story, between Heath and Ozren, the Bosnian academic who found the manuscript, is concerned. Given the preachy tendencies evident in Brooks' previous fiction, the sentimental pieties of this work do not surprise and do nothing to dispel the overall dullness of People of the Book.

While all this is enjoyable enough, it does have a somewhat wrong feel, even where the present- day love story, between Heath and Ozren, the Bosnian academic who found the manuscript, is concerned. Given the preachy tendencies evident in Brooks previous fiction, the sentimental job of this work do not surprise and do nothing to dispel the overall dullness of People of the Book. by Geraldine Brooks HarperPerennial, 7. 99 m 7. 59 free pp After the success of March, which won the 2006 Pulitzer prize for its account of the American Civil War as seen through the eyes of the eponymous character from Louisa May Alcotts Little

Author: Koning, Christina
Title: Hell
Full_text:
HELL by Yasutaka Tsutsui translated by Evan Emswiler Alma books, £7.99 m £7.59 (free p&p)
Ystsutaka Tsutsmi
Here, a motley collection of adulterous "salarymen", yakuza gangsters, bestselling novelists, kabuki actors and chat show hosts are congregated to undergo penance for the crimes they have committed in their lifetimes. As with the characters in Flann O'Brien's The Third Policeman, they have to relive these catastrophic events many times. For Izumi, a businessman, it is the moment when he finds his wife Sachiko in bed with his colleague, Takeshi, that he must repeatedly confront. For Yuzo, a teenage thug, it is the moment of his murder he must undergo time and again. Gangsters eternally torture their victims; actors eternally suffer terrible stage fright; planes are hijacked again and again; people endlessly die in car crashes. In this cycle of eternal recurrence, the dead are virtually indistinguishable from the living and, indeed, are fully aware of being dead. Their cartoon-like indestructibility makes it hard to sympathise with Tsutsui's characters — but one's sympathy, in any case, is not required. (The slapstick humour adds to the sense of dislocation, as does the constant shifting between past and present. The result certainly gives an impression of what Hell might be like — if only through the mixture of unease, revulsion and boredom that it creates in the reader.
"Hell is a city much like London," remarks Mephistopheles in Marlowe's Faust; in Tsutsui's version it looks more like Tokyo, or perhaps Osaka.

His 21 books before this memoir were of mostly academic interest, but support Sutherland's standing as what the French call a bien savant of English letters. Here is the being behind the brain. More accurately, as Sutherland's title suggests, he gives us his mostly wretched and wrenching childhood. Born in 1938 in Colchester to a working-class family, his father was killed while training to become a pilot. His mother abandoned him to relatives. Sutherland's account of his early life — indigent emotionally and financially - is worth reading for its portrayal of rationed life in Britain during and after the war. In very parenthetical prose, he can be delightfully droll — "sexual instruction was as scarce as Sanskrit" — and self-deprecating — "If God is a Victorian patriarch, I shall pay." With such arcane vocabulary as "sanscullotist", "spavined" (twice) or "gynocracy", Sutherland cannot quite quit the realm of his head for that of his heart. When he does, as in describing the traumas of his upbringing or his alcoholism, he is immensely affecting. He can be gruff and rebarbative and is (over?) critical of the British class system. But this is a rich, brave and rewarding book. Cathartic, one hopes, for Sutherland in his gloaming, it holds laughter and love and loss and lessons for us all.

Author: May, Derwent
Title: Blossoming on the bookshelves
Full_text:
Blossoming on the bookshelves
As Springwatch returns to BBC Two on Monday, Derwent May grabs his butterfly net and deerstalker to go in search of the finest new nature books
M WATSON/ARDEA; DAVID TIPLING/PHOTOLIBRARY * Nature in all its glory, clockwise from far left: amatungula and morning glory; flamingos in flight; robins enjoy a good reputation in print Below: a Great Crested Grebe
IF KATE HUMBLE is once again trying to curb Bill Oddie's bubbling erotic imagination, it must be spring — or at any rate it must be Springwatch on BBC Two. Either way, it is a timely moment to see what new nature books are in the shops. Starting at the garden door, Dominic Couzens has written a sequel to his RSPB book Secret Lives of Garden Birds, this one called Secret Lives of Garden Wildlife (Helm, £14.99/offer £13.49). So this time we do not get birds from the RSPB, but plenty of entertaining tales of other creatures — male spiders strumming tunes on female spiders' webs, foxes going crazy over shoes left in the garden, and hedgehogs regularly tossing a coat of spittle over their spines with their tongue, for a reason no zoologist has ever been able to explain. David Lack, the great ornithologist who was the first expert on robin behaviour, also compiled a little literary anthology called Robin Redbreast. His son, Andrew Lack, has expanded this into a longer book with a shorter title, Redbreast (SMH, £19.95/no discount), and has found some wonderful robins, mainly in poetry. They are mostly seen as good birds. There are several accounts of them covering the babes in the wood with leaves — one with good colour sense using strawberry leaves. Other robins comfort prisoners — or unhappy monks — at their cell windows. Ted Hughes gives his robin a "flaming shirt". Emily Bronte puts her finger on a paradox of the robin's song when she calls it "wildly tender" (just like her novel?), while Edward
Thomas brings out another paradox when he writes of the robin's "sad songs of autumn mirth". A new identification book to birds, by Marc Duquet, is called Birds By Colour (Helm, £12.99/£11.69). Wild flower guides are often arranged by colour, so why not birds? This one sets about the task imaginatively, with categories such as "Birds with a black throat" and "Birds with a black cheek". The only problem is that one cannot hold birds in the hand like flowers, so one may not even notice these features. Also, birds can look very different colours in different lights. Black crows can even look white when sunlight bounces off them. Nevertheless a good try, with good pictures. Where do all the flowers in our gardens come from? An excellent new book, Flower Hunters by Mary and John Gribbin (Oxford, £16.99/£15.29), tells the story of 11 botanists who travelled far in search of new flowers and trees. Joseph Banks went with Captain Cook on his first voyage round the world, and Botany Bay was named by Cook in honour of all the plants that Banks found there, including mimosas, acacias and eucalyptus. Banks also discovered jasmines and gardenias in Tahiti. Others include Joseph Hooker, who found rhododendrons and

magnolias in the Himalayas, and David Douglas, who after nightmarish adventures in the North American snow sent back the first seeds of the Douglas fir to Europe. The Gribbins also include the great Swede, Linnaeus, who as a boy was already making lists of his toys. He travelled for new plants only as far as Lapland, but his mind travelled around the whole plant creation, setting up a classification that endures to this day. He also made a flower clock, with the opening and closing of the different flowers telling the time — and this book tells us how to do it.
!Robins comfort unhappy monks and prisoners at cell windows1
The Greater Flamingo by Alan Johnson and Frank Cezilly (Poyser, £40/£36), is a thoroughly scientific study of this beautiful and amazing bird, but from its learned words there rise the most striking images. mind's eye we see flamingos of the. Camargue sitting on their mud nests the shallow close together stretch their full their head is the next bird's We see the flaHocks marching
along, then all throwing back their great pink wings simultaneously — perhaps to help them to synchronise their activities, perhaps just to show off to potential mates. We see tha hundreds of chicks clustering on the salt for protection, as close as a swarm of bees, when their parents have all flown away to find food for them. We can also learn about the the hard work that has gone into trying to save these flamingos. Meanwhile, Lost Land ofthe Dodo by Anthony Cheke and Julian Hume (Poyser, £45/£40.50) focuses on the home of a famous bird that is lost for ever. This is the Mascarene Islands, which consist of Mauritius, Reunion and Rodrigues. It is where, at the end of the 16th century, Europeans found the dodo, that strange, flightless bird, and where before the end of the 17th century it was extinct. Probably the main culprits were the pigs, introduced by the Dutch, that ate its eggs. But many other creatures have vanished from the islands since then, including the giant tortoises that the settlers ate, and this scholarly book gives a full, devastating account of them. There are delightful paintings by Julian Hume of other extinct birds — such as the raven parrot, Commerson's lizard-owl and the pigeon hollandais. This book also gives a moving and instructive account of what is being done to save the wildlife still found on the islands.

Author: Chancellor, Henry
Title: Between the covers with Bond
Full_text:
Between the
Movies have made Ian Fleming's creation a global brand, but the books came first. Henry Chancellor provides a reader's guide to the entire James Bond canon
ON FEBRUARY 17,1952, Ian Fleming sat down at his desk at Goldeneye, his house in Jamaica, and gazed out at the unbroken Caribbean Sea. He was a 43-year-old journalist, and he was trying hard to take his mind off his imminent wedding. Putting a fresh sheet of paper in the battered Royal portable in front of him, using six fingers he typed out a sentence. He crossed it out and tried again. Discarding that too, he finally came up with "The scent and smoke and sweat of a casino are nauseating at three in the morning". Suddenly he was off, writing in a fast, uninhibited manner and by lunch he had already typed 2,000 words. These were pulled straight from his memory and imagination,
he had no notes, no plan of where he was going. Fleming claimed he had even found the name of his hero by chance: A Field Guide to the Birds of the West Indies, by a certain James Bond, was sitting on his bookshelf. Every morning for a month he stuck to this iron regime, until he hammered out the final bitter sentence: "The bitch is dead now." Casino Royale, his first novel, was finished, and the phenomenon of James Bond was born. For the next dozen years Fleming would repeat the pattern of writing a new Bond novel between January and March at Goldeneye, to be published in the spring of the following year. What he had begun
"chiefly for pleasure, and then money", quickly developed into a long-running saga, in which each book picked up where the last one left off, and Fleming occasionally felt obliged to tie up some of the loose ends of the previous adventure (particularly what happens to the girls) before sending Bond off on his next assignment. "Everything I write has a precedent in truth," Fleming once said, and this is true not only of his fantastic plots and locations but also of his alter ego, 007. The James Bond series is not only the continuing story of the world's most famous secret agent, it is also a direct reflection of the lives and loves of Ian Fleming himself.

Author: Chancellor, Henry
Title: Simon Kernick
Full_text:
Simon Kernick BESTSELLING THRILLER WRITEK
Fleming did what very few authors have managed down the years: in James Bond he created a
character who was absolutely timeless. He might have been quintessentially English, but go anywhere in the world, and they know exactly who Bond is and what he does. The books are well-plotted, fast-paced and with a genuine international flavour that makes them just as exciting to read now as they were when they were written all those years ago.

Title: Engleby

Englcbi/
whether depicting the horrors of a First World War battlefield, or those of a Victorian psychiatric hospital. Now this flair for re-creating the past is used in a novel with a more contemporary setting. The narrator is the eponymous Mike Engleby, whom we first encounter as an undergraduate at Cambridge during the 1970s — a place and period the author, a student there at the time, re-creates with unnerving accuracy. Offered a place at the university to study English, Engleby switches to natural sciences, on the ground that it will offer more of a challenge. But what really exercises this precocious but immature young man is his attraction to fellow student Jennifer Arkland, whose every move becomes the subject of his creepy scrutiny. Mesmerised as much by her apparent ease in social settings as he is by her beauty, the awkward and unattractive Engleby infiltrates Jennifer's circle of friends, charting his unreciprocated passion in his journal. When Jennifer disappears after a party, a pattern starts to emerge in Engleby's ramblings. Just how much does he know of Jennifer's whereabouts — and how far is his account to be trusted? Disquieting and blackly funny, this bleak tale of obsession is as good as anything Faulks has written.
In his bestselling Birdsong trilogy, as well as in his more recent historical novel Human Traces, Faulks displays the meticulous eye for detail that gives his books their authority,

Author: Chater, David
Title: TV Choice
Full_text:
0 TVChoice David Chater
Natural World BBC Two, 8pm
In the autumn of 1893, during the twilight years of the Wild West, a hunter and amateur naturalist called Ernest Thompson Seton rode into New Mexico to wipe out wolves, which he regarded as cattle killers. His mission turned into a battle of wits between himself and one particular wolf called Lobo, who outwitted him at every turn. But it became much more than a battle between hunter and hunted. Seton underwent a conversion; he later wrote a bestselling book about his encounter with Lobo, which changed the attitude of the American public towards the natural world, kickstarted the conservation movement and inspired the ten-year-old David Attenborough. It is a wonderful story.
The Apprentice BBC One, 9pm
The two teams are sent out to gather as much laundry as they can, clean it and return it to their clients the following day. Within minutes, the result is a foregone conclusion. Although the boys do a lot of grunting, hugging and bonding along the way, they produce the goods with military precision. But it is the girls who provide all the entertainment Their team leader announces, without the slightest hint of irony, that she has been "hugely successful in a tough sales background". They offer to clean one hotel's laundry for
£5,000, compared with the usual price of £200. They lose track of who has what and squabble unceasingly throughout. Alan Sugar eats them alive in the boardroom.
Dan Cruickshank's Adventures in Architecture BBC Two, 9pm
The architectural historian Dan Cruickshank (right) is an acquired taste. Plenty of people find his earnest delivery and singular mannerisms impossible to watch. But if you've had the jabs and you're not bothered that this new eight-part series follows an entirely random itinerary, there are plenty of wonders to behold. In the opening programme,
he helps to build an igloo ("an ancient, elemental and beautiful structure") in Greenland; he sees the 70m-high statue of the Buddha of Le Shan ("Golly! He's absolutely enormous!"); he relishes the 13th-century Sun Temple at Konarak on the east coast of India, decorated with erotic statues "feasting on the divine nectar", and he admires the gaunt and terrifying cathedral-fortress of Albi in France. But to enjoy the series, you have to be able to cope with Dan.
Dexter ITVl, 10.35pm
It can't be healthy sympathising with a psychotic serial killer, any more than it is healthy to cherish nuggets of wisdom from a series that delights in being fundamentally ghoulish. But then this little corner of The Times has never exactly been a bastion of mental health. At the beginning of tonight's episode, Dexter says: "Life is so fleeting, so fragile. Every breath has the potential to be our last." And by the end, he has recognised another truth. "I realise now that my days are numbered," he says, "so I had better make the most of them." So whether you get lessons in mindfulness from Buddhist teaching or primetime ITV, occasionally — very occasionally — they can amount to the same thing.

Every breath has the potential to be our last. And by the end, he has seen another truth. I know now that my days are numbered, he says, so I had better make the most of them. So whether you get lessons in mindfulness from Buddhist teaching or primetime ITV, occasionally very occasionally they can amount to the same thing.

Pick up a book with The Times at WHSmith
lain Banks returns with his family saga The Steep Approach to Garbadale, next week's specially priced novel
THE BOOK In 1992 lain Banks wrote what some consider to be the ultimate modern family saga, The Crow Road, later adapted into a successful four-part television series. But here, in his 12th "mainstream" novel (he also writes sci-fi under the name lain M. Banks), he returns to the fertile ground of familial drama and intrigue.
The Steep Approach to Garbadale centres around the Wopuld family, creators of the bestselling boardgame Empire! — which has since gone through several incarnations since the 19th century, including the apologetic Commonwealth after the Second World War and the disastrous Seventies spin-off Karma! Alban is the black sheep of the family, but
he is brought back into the fold for a momentous meeting at the Wopulds' Highlands castle, Garbadale House. Will they sell out to the smooth-talking American Spraint Corp, or keep Empire! in the clan? Alban and his cousin Fielding are trying to persuade their relatives not to sell, but the waters are muddied by mixed motives and unsettling discoveries, and Alban can't push on until he has shaken off his childhood obsession with cousin Sophie, or found out the truth about his mother's suicide. With an attractively sharp-tongued protagonist and a corkscrew plot, Steep Approach finds Banks in his element.
THE OFFER Get The Steep Approach to Garbadale by lain Banks for £2.99 all next week when you buy The Times or The Sunday Times at participating WHSmith stores. See page 9 for full details.
age ull

It is the story of one young man's getting of wisdom, an oblique but observant history of Britain from the 1980s to the present day, and a great game of consequences" The Sunday Telegraph "What Banks serves up is both unanticipated and terrible. The fates of his characters are genuinely affecting" Evening Standard "His most accomplished book since The Crow Road. From the moment it begins there is an immediate sense of being in safe hands ... A first-rate novel" Literary Review

Author: Chevalier, Tracy
Title: Pick up a book with The Times at WHSmith
Full_text:
Pick up a book with The Times at WHSmith
William Blake is brought to life in next week's specially priced novel, Burning Bright by Tracy Chevalier
THE BOOK In her bestselling historical novel The Girl With the Pearl Earring, Chevalier painted a vivid picture of 17th-century Holland and its inhabitants (specifically the artist Vermeer and his servant Griet) - now she has given the same meticulous treatment to 18th-century London, and another celebrated artist - the
visionary poet, engraver and printer William Blake. The novel focuses on the troubled Kellaway family, who, still mourning their dead son Tommy, move from rural Dorset to a cramped and clamorous city caught up in two revolutions — industrial and French. In Lambeth the youngest Kellaway boy, Jem, strikes up a friendship with streetwise Maggie. They soon
t
discover that they have a most unusual neighbour — a man who recites Paradise Lost naked in the garden and talks to the ghost of his dead brother. The lives of the children and the poet become entwined and gradually they learn from each other: as Jem and Maggie mature, Blake composes the second half of what was to become his most famous work, Songs of Innocence and Experience. The children talk of Heaven and Hell, and Jem wonders "Can't there be something that's more a bit of both?" "That's the world, Jem," Maggie replies. It's a world that Burning Bright illuminates with clarity and beauty.
THE OFFER Get Burning Bright by Tracy Chevalier for £2.99 all next week when you buy The Times or The Sunday Times at participating WHSmith stores. See page 12 for full details.
THE AUTHOR ■ Born in Washington in 1962, Chevalier moved to London in the 1980s "for fun" and is still there, with her English husband and son. ■ In the 1990s she did an MA in creative writing at the University of East Anglia. ■ According to Chevalier, the 1993 film of Girl With a Pearl Earring "belongs to Scarlett Johannson, who packs so much into her luminous face that I couldn't take my eyes off her". ■ L. M. Montgomery's Anne of Green Gables is her desert-island book. ■ She is working on a novel about 19th-century fossil collector Mary Anning
THE REVIEWS "Highly pleasing... with a subtle clarity of style [and] quirky but seldom overdrawn characters." The Sunday Times "You can almost smell the smoke and mildewed clothes, see the gaunt, pockmarked faces of people struggling to survive and sense Jem's wonder as he gazes across the murky Thames to a perplexing world." Daily Express Her vivid portrayal of the sociopolitical realities of the day serves ultimately to vindicate Blake's warning that "fear of originality will stifle those who speak with different voices". The Irish Times

Author: Marlowe, Sam
Title: Bigotry in black and white
Full_text:
Bigotry in black and white
Noughts & Crosses Civic Hall, Stratford-upon-Avon • **##
SAM MARLOWE Here's some stirring theatre to counter the fake snow and sugar of Christmas — or Crossmas, as the festival is renamed in this play's dystopia. In her bestselling book for young people, the author Malorie Blackman creates a society divided in two: the privileged Crosses, and the underclass, the noughts (not dignfied by a capital). Crosses despise and fear "the blankers"; noughts hate and envy "the daggers". The Crosses are black; the noughts are white. Can a childhood friendship between a Cross girl and a nought boy survive as they grow up among so much pain and anger? Blackman's book is double-edged,
both cutting and crude. Her conceit impels the reader to reimagine social history, and her story, a brutal, pacy reworking of Romeo and Juliet, is gripping. Yet her prose style is self-conscious and cluttered with cliche. That shortcoming is apparent in the dialogue of Dominic Cooke's stage adaptation, and the play's climactic scenes feel rushed. But Cooke's production is fluid and vigorous. The burgeoning illicit love affair between high-ranking politician's daughter Sephy (short for Persephone) and frustrated, ambitious Callum is the lens that brings into focus inequalities that recall apartheid South Africa, pre-civil-rights America, the Troubles in Northern Ireland, even today's multicultural Britain. The attempt by a handful of nought children to attend Sephy's school results in a riot; Sephy is beaten up by fellow female Cross pupils when
DONALD COOPER m 1
The ruling Crosses campaign to keep noughts out of a school in the RSC's adaptation of Noughts & Crosses
she sits at the noughts' table in the canteen; Callum's brother and father become radicalised and join a terrorist movement. Division becomes internalised in the individual, with Callum experiencing self-disgust and Sephy shamed by Cross bigotry and by her own unconscious absorption of racist language.
Kandis Cook's sparse design of wheeled furniture and Liz Ranken's movement, by turns staccato and slow-motion, enhance the sense of a society without firm foundations and in peril of toppling into violence. The acting is sometimes overearnest, but Richard Madden and Ony Uhiara as Callum and Sephy make you invest in their
doomed passion, while Michelle Butterly and Phil McKee impress as Callum's helpless and beleaguered parents. And Noughts £t Crosses is young people's theatre that engages with issues of political urgency; that is enough to make it recommended family viewing. Box office: 0844 8001110, to Feb 2, then touring (www.rsc.org.uk)

Here's a thought

THE STUFF OF THOUGHT Language as a Window Into Human Nature by Steven Pinker IN THE PIVOTAL chapter of this complex but often revelatory book about the links between language and human nature, Steven Pinker quotes from Madame Bovary, in which Flaubert wrote that "language is a cracked kettle on which we beat out tunes for bears to dance to, while all the time we long to move the stars to pity". Not only is this a beautiful metaphor on the limits of language, but it highlights a central theme of Pinker's work. Amazing though language is in its complexity and subtlety, it is a construct ofthe human mind, making it a subjective and incomplete device for describing the world. It can, however, provide incredible insight into how the mind works, who we are and how our intelligence has developed over millions of years, which is exactly what Pinker lucidly argues here. Pinker is well known as a bestselling science writer, and has big ambitions for this book. The Stuff of Thought is intended as the third part of not one, but two trilogies. In tackling the interface between how we speak and who we are, he hopes that this book will
conclude both his previous work on the theories of language (T7ie Language Instinct and Words and Rules) and on human nature (How the Mind Works and The Blank Slate). It's a big ask, but Pinker pulls it off with aplomb. This is, essentially, a book of two halves. In the opening chapters, Pinker outlines his theories of "conceptual semantics" — the collection of concepts held in our mind and the way that they are combined in thoughts. How thoughts are expressed through language, he argues, is entirely dependent on how we experience the world, and how human beings have evolved. Dealing rather technically with concepts of space, time, causality and sub'So often, we don't mean what we say at all' stance, he meticulously picks apart rival theories, putting forward a complex but coherent argument of his own. This might be heavy going for those of a non-scientific or non-linguistic bent, but Pinker tries to keep things fairly light, peppering his prose with examples and quirks, paradoxes and counter-intuitive examples. So, in between referencing everyone from Shakespeare to Monty Python, we find out whether George Bush really did lie about his reasons for invading Iraq, why we say "underwater" when we mean "in water", and whether the ter-
rorist attack on the World Trade Centre constitutes one or two "events" (if you think that's trivial or "mere semantics", think again — $3.5 billion (£1.75 billion) was at stake in an insurance lawsuit). But halfway through, when the author tackles metaphor, things really take off. The Flaubert quote" is a fine example, but that's not what primarily concerns Pinker. Instead he deals with "conceptual metaphors" which are all-pervasive in language and so embedded in everything we say that we don't even notice them. Think how many phrases refer to love as a journey — "we're at a crossroads", "our marriage is on the rocks", "it's been a long, bumpy road". This applies across the board, from concepts of political allegiance being compared to physical bonds, to intellectual argument being compared to an act of war. Through this process, Pinker argues, a multitude of abstract concepts are expressed through more concrete experiences. He proves it by pulling apart a section ofthe US Declaration of Independence. This ability to frame complex ideas in simpler terms has been crucial in the evolution of human intelligence, yet it leads to inevitable conflict. If everything we say or think depends on how we frame it metaphorically in our minds and language, then "ending a pregnancy" and "killing an unborn child" are both valid ways to refer to abortion. But this innate human ability to use metaphor in such a creative way also enabled us to develop scientific theories, legal struc-
SHOUT/ DUTCHUNCLE.CO.UK
tures and political systems. After this profound passage, Pinker lightens things up a little. The subsequent chapters deal with the nature and process of naming things, the concept of obscenity and swearing. There is much fun to be had among all this. If someone has been impersonating Paul McCartney for the past 40 years, what do we really mean when we invoke the name "Paul McCartney"? Why are there gaps in our lexicon, such as no single term for grown-up children, or a collective term for one's nieces and nephews? Why did "internet" stick as a word, when "infobahn" didn't? Similarly, the discourse on the reasons for swearing and the rather odd idea of taboo subjects and words makes highly entertaining reading. While not strictly central to Pinker's overarching themes, the examination of the unique linguistic
oddity that is "fuck you" is funny and thought-provoking. Finally, as Pinker rounds off this perceptive, amusing and intelligent book, he examines how so much of what we say is nothing like what we mean. From sarcasm to diplomacy, sexual advances to bribes, politeness to insults, it is revealed that our language — even when used obliquely — can provide deep insights into the human condition. You may never look at language in quite the same way again. Allen Lane, £25; 499pp ffl £22.50 (free p&p) 08701608080 timesonline.co.uK/booksfirst

Author: Roberts, MichÈle
Title: Mr Golightly's Holiday
Full_text:
Mr Golightly's Holiday by Salley Vickers
The title of Salley Vickers's third novel echoes that of her bestselling first, M/7ss Garnet's Angel. The two share certain subjects and themes: Christianity, Jungian psychology, going away somewhere to find wisdom. In that earlier book the site of renewal was Venice; in this one, a village on Dartmoor. Here, God comes back down to earth to see whether the Bible story can be repeated. Vickers gives God writer's block and casts him as a sort of latter-day Mr Chips, affable and tolerant and sweet. God is alive and well and masquerading as a nice upper-middle-class English gentleman. Vickers's story is idea-driven. Her main concern is to reflect on the emotional life, suffering and redemption. Mr Golightly, her God-figure, rents a cottage in a pretty village, meets a host of neighbours and settles down to try to write. He is a bit of an old fogey, this God, baffled by e-mail and modern physics; this God who does not recognise quotations from the Book of Job when they mysteriously start to appear on his screen. Never mind. He is in Paradise, or England as some call it, going for frequent walks with new friends, observing the glories of nature, meditating on life and truth, offering kindness and advice. In her lengthy afterword, which quotes chapters of the Book of Job relevant to the plot, Vickers explains that the novel rose out of "a period of turmoil in my life ... personal drama ... when things stood around my bed in the small hours looking worse and worse". Without the help and support of certain people she "would have gone over to the side of Mr Golightly's rival (ie, the Devil), which would have resulted in a tragedy". MICHELE ROBERTS

Author: Chater, David
Title: TV Choice
Full_text:
0 TVChoice David Chater
THE BRITISH BOOK AWARDS Channel 4, 8pm
On the shortlist for the Book of the Year are two very different titles: Peter Kay's The Sound of Laughter (which went on to become the bestselling autobiography in the UK) and Professor Richard Dawkins's anti-religious polemic The God Delusion. The judges will be praying for divine guidance. There is an unusual entrant in this year's best biography category, with the memoirs of a labrador puppy competing with those of an ubiquitous chef. Ricky Gervais has been nominated for the children's book award with Flanimals of the Deep, while William Boyd and Griff Rhys Jones are on the shortlist for the lucrative Richard & Judy's Best Read of the Year award. All in all, a great night for dogs, comedians and book-lovers.

Author: Gatti, Tom
Title: The Dangerous Book for Boys
Full_text:
The Dangerous Book for Boys
Conn and Hal Iggulden
PUBLISHED IN JUNE (a week before Father's Day — providing a hint as to its real readership), The Dangerous Book for Boys is the publishing sensation of the year. It leapt into the Amazon top ten, generating enough column inches to take you to the Moon and back (possibly — my maths is a bit rusty). It has hardly been out ofthe bestsellers chart since. If you've been stuck down a mineshaft all year, you might need me to tell you that The Dangerous Book for Boys is an old-fashioned compendium of proper skills (tying a bowline knot), hardy activities (building a tree house), useful knowledge (Latin phrases "every boy should know") and classic tales of derring-do (the Battle of Trafalgar), lovingly compiled by the brothers Iggulden. Its success was a case of a great idea and even better timing. Children's movements seem subject to increasing surveillance (and intervention) from the risk-assessment mavens. Last year the Lord Chancellor lamented the fact that a "culture of fear of being sued" was "stopping good activities". This year a feature about "cotton-wool kids" in The Times quoted a sociologist's observations that in 1971 almost every 11-year-old child was allowed to walk to school alone; now the figure is 55 per cent and falling, even though there are no more child murders than in the 1970s — and far fewer traffic accidents. The Iggulden brothers' beautifully produced red-andgold hardback looks back further than the 1970s to the age of The Boy's Own Paper and Baden-Powell. The tone is set by the opening quotation, solid advice from Sir Frederick Treves, written in 1903: "Trust... to hard work, perseverance, and determination... Don't swagger... Be honest.
Be loyal. Be kind... Keep clean, body and mind." The essential message applies as much to office-bound adults as to pre-teen Xbox-addicts: whatever you do, don't spend your life in front of a screen. As explained in the section "Advice about girls", if nothing else, the opposite sex will be put off: "Play sport of some kind. It doesn't matter what it is, as long as it replaces the corpse-like pallor of the computer programmer with a ruddy glow." This is not an advocation of brawn over brains,
i
but an attempt to reclaim boyhood as a time of adventure. But what abput reclaiming girlhood? Well, perhaps the book isn't that exclusive. As the six-year-old-daughter of the author Frank Cottrell Boyce reasoned, if the book is dangerous for boys, surely it's perfectly safe for girls? TOM GATTI
HarperCollins, £18.99; 294pp S £16.99 (free p&p) Published: June 5 UK sales: 300,929

Author: Némirovsky, Irène
Title: Suite Francaise
Full_text:
books
Suite Frangaise Irene NeillirOVSky (translated by Sandra Smith)
RARE FOR A BOOK that tells an extraordinary story to have an extraordinary story behind it, but that is the case with Irene Nemirovsky's Suite Frangaise. This work — in a lucid, elegant translation by Sandra Smith — would, for its literary quality alone, be a highlight of any year; the story of its discovery makes it more remarkable still. Contained by the covers of Suite Frangaise sre two novels of a projected five, a chronicle of lives in Occupied France. Nemirovksy, born in Russia in 1903, fled in 1918 and settled in France. In 1926 she married Michel Epstein, a Russian emigre, and although both were Jewish they were, in 1939, baptised in the Catholic Church. By that time Nemirovksy was a bestselling novelist. Neither that nor her conversion, however, could save her from what was to come. In 1942 the Nazis informed the Vichy Government that France's Jews were to be sent "to the East". By that time the family — the couple and their two daughters, Denise and Elisabeth — had left Paris for the village of Issy-L'Eveque in Burgundy, and Nemirovksy had
begun work on Suite Frangaise. "All the time we were in that village, I just remember mother writing, writing, writing," Denise said decades later. She was writing, she knew, against time: she was arrested in July and died a month later, in Auschwitz; Michel was also deported and died that year. Their daughters escaped — told by the gendarme who arrested their father to flee. Denise took a small suitcase (pictured) that contained the leather binder holding Suite Frangaise, but did not look at it, or begin to transcribe her mother's minuscule writing until nearly 30 years later. More years would pass before she decided that publication was not a betrayal of her mother. It was published in France by Editions Denoel; in The Times, Carmen Callil noted that its founder was the most enthusiastic of French publisher collaborators. The book was hailed as a masterpiece: one "ripped from oblivion", Le Monde said. Callil —the author of a biography of Louis Darquier, commissioner for Jewish affairs in the Vichy regime — praised the prose, "lucid, bright, like one ofthe lit-
tie brown birds she so often describes. She misses nothing, not a blossom, a hen nor a bumblebee. Such acute insight means that her characters are full of life and diversity, as are the animals she so tellingly describes... Nemirovksy's embodiment of the people of France, suffering 'as birds must feel when hawks circle above them'. No other work of fiction as forcefully conveys the fate of France under the Nazis." The danger is that such history might put some readers off Suite Frangaise. Yet, while it is in no way light reading, it moves swiftly and is tender and — perhaps surprisingly — funny. It is too easy to look at photographs of refugees and see them simply as a mass of unimaginable humanity; Nemirovksy brings her characters — the self-important writer, the humble bank clerk, the worn-down but proud wife — to vivid individual life. Masterpiece is a word overused; and often wrongly. For a living writer it could be seen as marking an end. Here, it is all too appropriate: we will hear no more from Irene Nemirovksy, but Suite Frangaise ensures that her name will endure. Her body died in a concentration camp; her soul and mind survive. ERICA WAGNER

Author: Null
Title: Discover this year's best books for teenagers
Full_text:
Books
Discover this year's best books for teenagers
The Booktrust Teenage Prize rewards the best in teen fiction. Here the four young judges give their verdicts on the shortlisted books
& WZ FRAC E TAYLOR
THE FORESHADOWING by Marcus Sedgwick Orion, £5.99 El £5.69 (free p&p) Sasha Fox, a young woman growing up in England in 1917, is already haunted by her ability to see death before it happens. Her life takes a drastic turnwhen she is forced to foresee the death of someone she loves, and, as her brothers are swallowed into the current wartime effort in France, tragedy ensues. In an act of desperation, she too ventures to the front line. Throughout her journey, she pretends to be a nurse, faces the devastation of war and befriends the mysterious Hoodoo Jack. Amongst all the chaos she never forgets her vocation, dodging death and suspicion as she goes. This book will keep you hooked on every page, and concludes with a heart-stopping twist. You can't help but admire Sasha, as she attempts the unthinkable, in her own war against fate and destiny. EXCHANGE by Paul Magrs Simon & Schuster, £9.99 m £9.49 (free p&p) Simon is 16 years old. After the death of his mother and father, he ends up miles away, living with his grandparents. Tormented by local yobs and by the constant memories of all he has lost, he longs for escape. Seemingly out of nowhere appears the "Great Big Book Exchange", along with Kelly and Terrance, who begin to play large roles in both his and his grandmother's lives. Over time, the book exchange becomes more than just a shop, offering an opportunity for Simon to escape from his current life and for his grandmother to return to her past ■This story reminds you why people love to read books, as well as why people long to write them. It gives us the comfort that no matter how things change, there will always be something to link the generations.
THEO TEMPLE 14
HENRY TUMOUR by Anthony McGowan Doubleday, £10.99 m £9.99 (free p&p) Definitely the funniest, most obscenely wise book I have read in a long time. Henry Tumour, Anthony McGowan's second novel for teenagers, is written from the point of view of Hector Brunty, a teenager who likes maths (?), whose mum is an ageing hippy and whose brain has been invaded by a chatty alter-ego called Henry T. Everything seems to be against Hector — even the comfort of his own thoughts have been taken over. However, this little clump of brain cells seems to be able to help him out. Soon, Henry T. is giving Hector tips on fashion and snogging tactics; Hector seems to have risen to the schoolbreak elite (if only for a short while). But how far will Henry T. go and how far will Hector let him before they both go under the knife? BEAST by Ally Kennen Marion Lloyd Books, £6.99 m £6.64 (free p&p) This book reminds me of possible sequel to that famous book (and film) Kes. The plot is full of twists and turns. Stephen, who is 17 years old, and coming to the end of his time in care, tries to get rid of the "beast" he keeps in a cage at a nearby reservoir. The creature's needs take control of Stephen's life as he struggles to find hunks of meat to feed its ferocious appetite. Kennen has captured magnificently the love-hate relationship that exists between Stephen and the beast. Stephen has a bleak background and appears to have few prospects yet, by the end of the book, he becomes more of a hero — freeing himself and taking back control. If you like cheeky, realistic stories about people who aren't all that law-abiding, then this book is for you.
s> & **• ISABELLE ELLIS COCKROFT 15
A SWIFT PURE CRY by Siobhan Dowd David Pickling Books, £12.99 m £11.69 (free p&p) Since the death of Shell's mam, her father has lost touch with reality, leaving 15-yearold Shell to bring up her two younger siblings. Shell's parents were religious but, after the death of her mam, Shell lost her faith. When a new priest, Father Rose, comes to the small Irish town of Coolbar something extraordinary shifts in Shell's world and her mam's spirit seems to return to Earth. Then tragedy shakes Shell's life and she is swept up in^to the heart of a scandal that reverberates across the country. It takes all her courage just to carry on. This story is told with perfectly chosen phrases and words for every moment, lifting the story off the page and fashioning the fresh vivid imagery from which this heartwrenching story is woven.
RHONA CLARK 15
ANGEL BLOOD by John Singleton Puffin, £9.99 El £9.49 (free p&p) This is the story of four children — X-Ray, Cough Cough, Lights Out and Chicken Wings — and their life in the "Bin", a place for special children. It is written from the X- Ray's point of view, and chronicles how their life in the Bin deteriorates after the dastardly Dr Dearly and his team of unfriendly staff take over. An unexpected twist is added with the introduction of Nail, a hard man with his own story to tell, and his girlfriend, Natalie. Eventually, they escape with the help of Nail and Natalie. But after spending all their lives in the secure, sterile Bin will they be able to survive on the outside? This is an innovative, bittersweet book which not only tells the story of four children's struggle to reach the outside world but also of how the outside world views them.

WHAT DO ADOLF HITLER, MARY Whitehouse, Jimmy Greaves and Dick Emery have in common? Probably quite a lot if you do enough research, but the immediate answer is that all of them coexist quite happily up on my bookshelves. Moreover, they share a heritage particularly common on my bookshelves, which is that I have no memory of how they got there. Ooh You Were Awful ...But I Like You — the life story of Dick Emery as told to his — count 'em — sixth wife, Fay Hillier — has a reduced sticker from a shop called The Works on it (£15.99 down to £10, then to a further £4.99) and I do have a very vague memory of once being in The Works looking at remaindered books; but actually taking this one to the till, getting the fiver out of my wallet, and rushing home to read Fay's superbly detailed biog of the great man (if a little cursory, perhaps, on the subject of Dick's other five wives) — that's gone. Similarly, I noticed Jimmy Greaves's The Heart of The Game sitting by itself — as if picked out in a Waterstone's recommendation — on my shelves last week, but — perhaps like Jimmy in his drinking days — have no memory of how exactly it ended up there. The Mary Whitehouse book is a tome entitled Whatever Happened to Sex? I'd assumed it was a cri de coeur about the author's personal life, the answer to which, I have to say, is provided by the photo of Mary on the back — but it is, in fact, a learned argument against the permissive society, which, judging from the state of the cover, I rushed out and bought immediately on its publication in 1977, presumably in between buying a new protractor and Never Mind the Bollocks. But I have no memory of doing so. Hitler is a slightly different kettle offish, as I do remember buying most of my Nazi/ Holocaust books, some of which I've had for a while, others that came during the writing of my last novel, set during the war — but what I don't remember is the moment at which these went beyond the standard legal requirement for a North London Jew and became a full-on Hitler/Holocaust library section. Surely there was a moment when I thought: "Hold on... is this becoming a bit creepy? Am I going to be contacted any minute by Stormfront's book club?" But clearly not. It's one of the functions, I think, of being a bit bookish. The fact is, I buy a lot of books, on impulse, I get sent a lot of books, and I hardly ever throw out books — taking the Nazi
A Uf r% rt
hangover a stage further, a part of me feels it's only one step away from book-burning although, actually, I think organising one of those for the Hitler section may be not a bad thing. The trouble is, as one ages, of course, you can't remember why you ever bought half of them. And worse still, you realise that the assumption behind keeping all these books — that you will get round to reading them al one day — is, with time, looking shaky. Will I ever get beyond, for example, just flicking through the photos in Backstage Passes, the biography of Angie Bowie (described as "wickedly funny" by the Atlanta Journal And Constitution)? How heartbreakingly hopefu was it of me to buy Pier Paolo Pasolini's Ragazzi di vita, in the belief that I would one day read it in the original Italian? What am I doing owning a copy of W. E Davies's Make Your Own Fishing Tackle? And presiding over them all, the King, of course, of the Great Unread, The Dauphin of "I'm Definitely Going to Do It One Day", my
much-thumbed, and much put-down, copy of Swann's Way, the first volume of A la recherche du temps perdu. It's a great thing, though. When bored, I can browse through my shelves like a lucky dip. Some books serve as biography, reminding me of mental things about my youth — I have a copy of Mary Cadogan and Patricia Craig's You're A Brick, Angela! (The Girls' Story 1839-1985) because, when I was 11,1 was the youngest member — by about 80 years — ofa society called The Old Boys Book Club, to which Mary (not so sure about Patricia) was also affiliated. And some, like the aforementioned, are just mental. Flicking through Mary Whitehouse's book now I notice a sentence that begins "Alice Cooper, the male 'pop star' is ..." as if the phrase pop star was just some ridiculous affectation, held in quarantine away from Mary's nose by the inverted commas. This makes me want to read the whole thing. I won't, of course. But I won't throw it out either.

Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: 'Take a browse through a writer's bookshelves'
Full_text:
Erica Vagner 'Take a browse through a writer's bookshelves'
AS MY COLLEAGUE NEXT DOOR points out, summer vacation, as I used to call it, is nearly over. What that calls to mind for me is not only the books that I might read in the autumn, as Jeanette suggests, but the lists we used to have to keep in the holidays ofthe books we'd read when we weren't at school. If memory serves, our teachers handed out a list, and you were supposed to choose at least a few from there, then you were on your own. I don't do that any more, but perhaps I'll start again. I have been inspired by a book that just landed on my desk: The Reader, it's called, and underneath that it says: "Ali Smith". It doesn't say "by", because it isn't; it is, rather, "the first in a series of anthologies of favourite writing chosen by writers". And it is a real treat. It is more than a commonplace book — a wonderful thing in itself, but anecdotal and made in the moment. It is more like a leisurely browse through a
writer's own bookshelves. And since I am a person who likes almost nothing better than browsing through other people's bookshelves, especially, of course, people I like, what could be better? Smith's book — I long to know who else will take part — is divided into sections: "Girls", "Dialogues", "Journeys", "The World", "Histories", "Beliefs". In "Girls", you'll find Nell Dunn and Jane Austen, among others; in "Beliefs", Calvino and Shakespeare. What she takes from Austen is simply a sentence: "No one who had ever seen Catherine Morland in her infancy would have supposed her to have been born an heroine." That's enough, isn't it, to send you back to Northanger Abbey. Some pleasures come not in fragments but in wholes: I didn't know I needed reminding of Larkin's The Trees, but I did: "Yet still the unresting castles thresh/ In fullgrown thickness every May./ Last year is dead, they seem to say,/ Begin afresh, afresh, afresh." The books that you read can be the architechture that supports you — you don't have to be a writer for that to be so. We take from books the equipment that we need to cross chasms or climb mountains or swim rivers; and it's good, sometimes, to be able to look back at how far you have come and see, perhaps, how you got there. Your list of the books you have read will be a good guide. The Reader: Ali Smith (Constable, £12.99; offer, £11.69 from 0870 1608080)

— presumably because his books contain a lot of characters — and to Kurt Vonnegut, perhaps because of his jokey style. But there the similarities end. Until I Find You is typical Irving; over-long, facetious and packed with tiresome sex scenes, generally involving passive men and dominant women. It opens with Jack Burns, aged 4, travelling with his mother Alice, a tattoo artist, in search of his philandering father, William, who has abandoned them both. The best thing about this part of the novel — which moves from Edinburgh, where Jack is conceived, through various European cities, to the red-light district in Amsterdam — is its description of the tattooist's art. Irving is nothing if not thorough, at his research. Jack's schooldays at a Toronto girls' school where he is the only boy are described in similar detail, as is his deflowering by an older woman. Later he becomes a cross-dressing actor, then a Hollywood film-star. He meets more thrillingly assertive women. His mother gets cancer and dies. Finally he tracks down his father. All these developments are given exactly the same weight, and are depicted in exactly the same dull prose. This book will doubtless sell as well as its predecessors have, but it is difficult to see why.
UNTIL I FIND YOU by John Irving Black Swan, £8.99 ® £8.54 (free p&p) Irving is, by any standards, an extremely successful writer, with a string of awards and bestselling novels — several of them filmed — to his name. He has been compared to Dickens
he Divide
warmth as his earlier bestseller, The Horse Whisperer. The dead girl is Abbie Cooper — who, with her German eco-terrorist boyfriend Rolf — is on the run from the FBI for a string of crimes, including murder. The trail that leads from Abbie's privileged New York home to a lonely death in the wilds of Montana is one of the novel's concerns; another is the failing marriage of her parents, Ben and Sarah. The failure of this relationship when Ben meets a younger woman is detailed with painful honesty, as is the guilt that Ben feels at his daughter's rejection. His gradual realisation that abandoning the family for his young mistress may have triggered Abbie's extremism is powerfully conveyed. With novels of this type, written with Hollywood adaptation in mind, there is always a danger that sentimentality will prevail. Unfortunately that is the case with the ending here, in which the warring parents are reconciled, surviving family members affirm their love for each other and the horrors of what went before are swept under the carpet. But until this point there are some good dramatic moments and some trenchant comments, made via the mouthpiece of Abbie and her eco-warrior friends, about the US Government's iniquitous environmental record.

Lucas, it emerges, has an ulterior motive in visiting Florence, of which even his wife is unaware. Fifteen years earlier, he had been at the centre of a tragedy that shocked the city and whose effects are still being felt. These include Luisa Cellini, who runs a dress shop, and her husband Sandro, a policeman, whose investigation into a brutal killing awakens memories of an earlier, unsolved murder. A Ukrainian gangster, an anorexic beggar and an eccentric artist all have parts to play in what follows, but their exact roles become apparent only much later, by which time the tension has been ratcheted up nicely. As well as her evident relish for Italian art, architecture and fashion, Christobel Kent is adept at creating believable characters — a great advantage for a thriller writer. Thus, Celia's dismal love-life, the troubled marriage of Luisa and Sandro and the joys of shoe shopping add interest to the central mystery, but do not distract from it.

Author: McKinstry, Leo
Title: Which decade really swung?
Full_text:
Books
Society Leo KcKinstry Which decade really swung?
oe'-TfTPR'S'Jr-^
WHITE HEAT A History of Britain in the Swinging Sixties by Dominic Sandbrook SEVENTIES The Sights, Sounds and Ideas of a Brilliant Decade by Howard Sounes SELF-CONFIDENT revisionism and an eagerness to challenge conventional wisdom usually make for lively history. These two highly readable books prove the point. In his compelling narrative of Britain during the 1960s, Dominic Sandbrook demolishes the myth that traditional society was swept aside by a flower power, free love and student unrest. In reality, he argues, most of the country remained deeply conservative throughout the decade with the supposed social revolution taking place largely in the lifestyles of an affluent, selfregarding metropolitan elite. The imagery of the Beatles and mini-skirts, of Concorde and LSD, now part of our national folk memory, is actually only a small part of a much more complex, often depressing, story. A more daring, if narrower thesis is pursued by Howard Sounes, whose remarkably catholic output includes biographies of Bob Dylan and the serial killers Fred and Rosemary West. Although the 1970s now tend to be regarded as a cultural wasteland, dominated by kitsch pop music, vulgar entertainment and disastrous fashions, Sounes claims that it was actually an age of astonishing creativity, especially in cinema. According to Sounes, many of the films, buildings, books and paintings produced then have stood the test the test of time far better than the art works of less despised eras. For too long, he says, the brilliance of the 1970s has been ignored, since these years tend "to be dismissed a silly, jokey interlude between the Beatles and the 1980s". Because of the strength of its historical research and its placing of culture in a wider historical context, Dominic Sandbrook's case is made more effectively. Sounes is excellent on many icons of the Seventies, such as the movies of Woody Allen or the music of Lou Reed, but refuses to engage in
K SS a ;, w.
anything but the most superficial discussion of the important political developments that shaped this turbulent decade. Harold Wilson is mentioned just twice, Jim Callaghan once and Ted Heath not at all, yet movements such as punk rock or the comedy of Monty Python owed much to a sense of anger or absurdity at the remorseless decline of Britain under this trio. In contrast to the limited, sometimes idiosyncratic, range of Sounes's book, Sandbrook's could hardly be more impressive in its scope. He writes with authority and an eye for telling detail on every subject he covers, be it the musical influences on Paul McCartney or the tactical
TTwo thirds of brides in 1968 were still virgins1
approach of the World Cupwinning manager Alf Ramsey, the crisis over the devaluation of the pound or the start of the Troubles in Northern Ireland. Although the awesome depth of his knowledge is obvious, he is never ponderous. Every chapter is enlivened by humour — in describing the establishment of pirate radio stations in the North Sea, he says that the "the disc jockeys themselves cultivated a youthful, cheeky classless style that was only occasionally interrupted by bouts of seasickness". He is particularly funny on the ridiculous earnestness of avant-garde theatre, recounting an incident in 1964 when a group of actors were carrying out an experimental play at a small theatre in London, involving bottom-baring, wet
fish, polythene bags and the flogging of a policeman. Suddenly the theatre's caretaker burst on to the stage to complain that one of the actors had left the tap running in the dressing room. The pretentious audience took this to be part of the show. "I think you're the best thing in the entire evening, a most interesting performance," one said to the caretaker afterwards. Despite his subtitle, Sandbrook's central theme is that Britain did not really swing at all in the 1960s. Contrary to the myths about sexual freedom and progressive youth, Sandbrook points out that in 1968 two thirds of women were still virgins on their wedding night, Engelbert Humperdinck was more popular than the Beatles, and opinion polls showed that young people held even more reactionary attitudes towards hanging and immigration than their elders. Far from being filled with optimism, for most people the Sixties was a time of economic stagnation, as the Wilson Government limped from one crisis to another. The stench of failure hung over most government initiatives. Attempts to reform trade unions, establish state control of economic planning, maintain the value of sterling or bring democracy to Rhodesia all ended in humiliation. Wilson himself is the supreme symbol of this failure. The dynamic, popular figure of 1964 had been reduced by 1969 to a paranoid, exhausted wreck, loathed by the public and colleagues alike for his duplicity and self-delusion. It is impossible not to be struck by the parallels between Wilson and Tony Blair, another youthful, electionwinning Labour leader who came into power on a programme of modernisation but
achieved little beyond building a reputation for slipperiness, cronyism, gimmickry and empty rhetoric. In supporting his belief that the Seventies were uniquely rich, Sounes has assembled some fascinating material, much from his own original research. He opens with a description of a critical scene from the quintessentiaJ'y 1970s film, Five Easy Pieces. Directed by Bob Rafelson and starring Jack Nicholson, it heralded a quirky, naturalistic style that moved away from the slick Hollywood productions of the past. With some justification, Sounes argues that a host of groundbreaking films such as Nashville, American Graffiti, Annie Hall and A Clockwork Orange left a lasting imprint on our collective consciousness. Sounes's other choices of cultural highlights are quixotic, including the Pompidou Centre in Paris, designed by Richard Rogers, the writings of Hunter S. Thompson and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, and the paintings of David Hockney. Sounes is full of arresting insights, such as the fact that three of the bestselling novels of the era, Frederick Forsyth's The Day of the Jackal, Peter Benchley's Jaws and Mario Puzo's The Godfather, were produced by authors in near penury. Sounes's argument is interesting if not entirely credible. After all, Harold Wilson was Still Prime Minister halfway through the decade, hardly the sign of "a brilliant decade". Every chapter is enlivened by sometimes in describing the establishment of pirate radio stations in the North Sea, he says that the the disc jockeys themselves cultivated a youthful, cheeky classless style that was only occasionally interrupted by bouts of seasickness. He is particularly funny on the ridiculous earnestness of the- world theatre, recounting an incident incident in 1964 when a group of actors were carrying out an experimental play at a small theatre in London, involving bottom- baring, wet fish, polythene bags and the flogging of a policeman. Suddenly the theatres caretaker burst on to the stage to complain that one of the actors had left the tap running in the dressing room. The pretentious audience took this to be part of the show. I think that the best thing in the entire evening, a most interesting performance, one said to the caretaker afterwards. Despite his subtitle, Sandbrooks central theme is that Britain did not really swing at all in the 1960s. Contrary to the myths about sexual freedom and progressive youth, Sandbrook points out that in 1968 two thirds of women were still virgins on their wedding night, Engelbert Humperdinck was more popular than the Beatles, and opinion polls showed that young people held even more reactionary attitudes towards hanging and immigration than their elders. Far from being filled with optimism, for most people the Sixties was a time of economic stagnation, as the Wilson Government limped from one crisis to another. The stench of failure hung over most government initiatives. Attempts to reform trade unions, establish state control of economic planning, maintain the value of sterling or bring democracy to Rhodesia all ended in humiliation. Wilson himself is the supreme symbol of this failure. The dynamic, popular figure of 1964 had been reduced by 1969 to a paranoid, exhausted wreck, loathed by the public and colleagues alike for his duplicity and self- delusion. It is impossible not to be struck by the parallels between Wilson and Tony Blair, another youthful, the Labour leader who came into power on a ase of democracy but achieved little beyond building a reputation for slipperiness, cronyism, gimmickry and empty rhetoric. In supporting his belief that the Seventies were uniquely rich, Sounes has assembled some fascinating material, much from his own original research. He opens with a description of a critical scene from the quintessentiaJy 1970s film, Five Easy Pieces. Directed by Bob Rafelson and starring Jack Nicholson, it heralded a quirky, naturalistic style that moved away from the slick Hollywood productions of the past. With some justification, Sounes argues that a host of groundbreaking films such as Nashville, American Graffiti, Annie Hall and A Clockwork Orange left a lasting imprint on our collective consciousness. Souness other choices of cultural highlights are quixotic, including the Pompidou Centre in Paris, designed by Richard Rogers, the writings of Hunter S. Thompson and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, and the paintings of David Hockney. Sounes is full of arresting insights, such as the fact that three of the bestselling novels of the era, Frederick Forsyths The Day of the Jackal, Peter Benchleys Jaws and Mario Puzos The Godfather, were produced by authors in near penury. Souness argument is interesting if not entirely credible. After all, Harold Wilson was Still Prime Minister halfway through the decade, hardly the sign of a brilliant decade.
