Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: Richard & Judy & Amanda
Full_text:
Richard & Judy & Amanda
Her nod can turn an unknown into a millionaire. But how do you get on to Amanda Ross's shortlist? Erica Wagner meets the woman who turned books into a TV phenomenon
WALK INTO THE SUNNY, Kennington office of the woman who's been called the most powerful person in British publishing, and of course the first thing you do is look at the bookshelves. They are crowded, though also decorated with mugs, treasures and family photographs that give the room a homely feel. I tilt my head to read the names: Carl Hiassen, Salley Vickers, Francis King (Francis King!)... But Amanda Ross, the joint managing director of Cactus TV and the woman who brought the Richard & Judy Book Qub into existence, is almost dismissive of the "most powerful" tag that has been attached to her. "I really, really don't — and I don't pretend that I know what definitely will make a bestseller. That's not how I choose the books. My criteria, honestly, is: is this book going to entertain and engage people enough to generate 12 to 15 minutes of gripping television? The bottom line is: what's the sofa chat?" Ross's influence is undeniable. The Richard & Judy Book Club has been going for three years on Channel 4; three years in which the ten books chosen to be discussed over ten weeks have gained increases in sales that most authors only dream of. Next week the club's Summer Reads — six more titles, revealed exclusively below — will get a huge boost when viewers pack them for the beach along with the factor 15. A heavy book buyer, Ross points out, buys about 12 books a year. But a
Richard & Judy viewer might buy 16 books ... no wonder the sales figures look as they do. I like Amanda Ross, her enthusiasm, her energy; there isn't a jaded bone in her body. I've read that she talks about books only in sales terms, rather than discussing "literary merit"; that her views of the importance of story are simplistic. Wrong. This is a woman who loves books, who clearly wants as many people as possible to share the enjoyment. She is an evangelist with the passion of the convert. "Books have always been a kind of exotic thing for me because I grew up in a house without any books. My family is very working-class, so we had some kind of children's encyclopaedia, a medical dictionary, and that was about it. My mum joined a book club for me and I used to get things like Black Beauty, Heidi, which I used to devour completely. "But books weren't part of my family culture at all. At university — I was the first person in my family to go to university — I remember doing Knots, by R. D. Laing, and being completely gobsmacked that several people's parents had it at home. So I was very jealous of these people, and it's always been my ambition to have my own library, and to have my own house absolutely full of books. I don't throw books away, I can't; to me they are special, lovely things." All this sounds breezy, a bit too easy, I think: what's the sofa chat? But isn't that the question that ap-
ZM
TSof a chat? It applies to any reader, to any book*
plies to any reader, any book? Every reader wants to engage with books; that means thinking about them, talking about them. "What's the sofa chat?" is as good a way as any as expressing this. She refers, more than once, to a book having "good takeaway"; nothing to do with KFC, but whether the reader will get something lasting from the book; Nicole Krauss's The History of Love, I'd say, has stellar takeaway; so does Julian Barnes's Arthur & George. Both were Richard & Judy choices this year. Ross read drama at Birmingham; Cactus TV was set up in 1994 with her husband, Simon Ross (brother of
Jonathan). The company signed Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan in 2001 and today the show averages 2.2 million viewers. The Richard & Judy Book Club — which she conceived and insisted upon as a part of the show — runs for ten weeks, culminating in the British Book Awards, which is broadcast on Channel 4. Why just ten weeks? "The danger in telly is that if something is successful people repeat it endlessly; but you can't do a book club all year round. You can't buy a book a week, year round." In the first year the club's choice of Star of the Sea, by Joseph O'Connor (who until then had been graced with plenty of critical praise but no significant sales), caught everyone's attention. The week before its appearance on Richard & Judy the book sold four and a half thousand copies; sales jumped by eight thousand copies the week it was featured, and rose steadily. This year sales of Kate Mosse's
<NEWPAGE>
Labyrinth have overshadowed everything else on the list. Mosse has nothing but praise for Ross, and as a founder of the Orange Prize and presenter of Readers and Writers Roadshow, on BBC Four, as well as being the author of novels and nonfiction books, she knows what she's talking about. "Amanda is such a high-powered executive, but she's also excellent at knowing what it feels like to be an author. I got a handwritten, detailed letter from her about Labyrinth, and a beautiful timepiece — it was such a lovely gesture." Ross makes sure that when the author's section is filmed for the show — Mosse's, for instance, on location in Carcassone — the whole crew, everyone, reads the book first. "The reason she has succeeded in making books work on television is that she is a passionate reader who cares about books and authors," Mosse says. Ross has the final say on all the book club choices, although a team of
four looks at them. By the time they get down to the last ten, it's all a question of balance. (And notjust of tone; you can't ask people to read too many fat books, she says — the list always goes "thick thin, thick thin".) She reveals that this year Jonathan Safran Foer's Extremely Loud and Incredibly Qose made it to the last 20; he's married to Nicole Krauss, and there was some discussion of what would happen if a husband and wife appeared on the show. In the event, though, Foer didn't make it. Julian Barnes's Man Booker shortlisted Arthur & George wasn't submitted by the publisher; Ross called it in because she'd heard how great it was. (It's reassuring to learn that publishing's miraculous elixir, word-ofmouth, can play a part in her choices.) "Critics who don't watch the show have preconceptions about what the author's attitude is going to be," she says. "I read some rubbishy stuff that people said when I chose Julian Barnes — they thought that he wouldn't like to be in the book club. But he loved it! Pat Kavanagh — his wife, who also happens to be his agent — said that for the first time he hadn't found it too painful to see himself on TV. But we do check, when books are suggested, that publishers don't submit anyone who isn't going to be committed to the whole process: they have to come to the Book Awards. Either you buy into it, or you don't." I consider what I believe a TV executive like Ross truly understands: she understands what millions of people will like, and she knows how to present it. Why shouldn't that work with books? Why shouldn't she ask for the cover of Cecilia Ahern's novel, P.S., I Love You, to be changed from pink to blue so that Richard — and millions of male viewers — wouldn't feel uncomfortable holding it on telly or reading it on the train? She had what she describes as a "difference of opinion" over the cover of Richard Benson's book, TTie Farm; the paperback cover, which showed the author in an agricultural setting (sheep included) would be less appealing to urban viewers/readers than the hardback cover — a lovely illustration — had been. She lost that argument, having been told that the paperback cover was the author's choice; she subsequently found it wasn't. "I honestly don't want to do anything that upsets the authors; they should choose the cover, they wrote the book. I only ever comment on a cover when I feel that it is doing the book a disservice, is not making it universally appealing. My job is to make things visually appealing, so if publishers don't want to listen to me on that, well..." In a sense, of course, the Richard
& Judy Book Qub owes some of its success to Oprah Winfrey, whose book club set the trend. But the format is completely different; Oprah invites the author on to the show, so there's hardly a possibility of critical debate. "I think the best idea we had was to keep the author out of the mix," Ross says. "The author starts the piece off with a film telling the story of the book, and that lets the viewer in, too. So even if people aren't going to read the book, they can still feel involved. "We also don't invite 'experts' to discuss the books; we get accessible celebrities. So it's not intimidating, though we do choose a celebrity who will have some relevance to the book — Bettany Hughes [the author and presenter of Helen of Troy] on Labyrinth, for instance — and usually the other guest is someone whose opinion would matter to you." Are there any downsides to what she's created — which includes, of course, not just the book club but an initiative launched with Pan Macmillan, How To Get Published; there were 49,000 entries when that began and the winning title, 77ie Olive Readers, by Christine Aziz, has since sold 10,647 copies. Rachel Zadok's novel, Gem Squash Tokoloshe, a runner-up for the prize, was shortlisted for the Whitbread First Novel Award in 2005. Since then Macmillan has published a further six books by previously unknown authors. Certainly there's a sense of responsibility; she's beeh told, for instance, that the club has created eight author-millionaires. "We're able to make people a lot of money out of this, and we aren't able to make any money out of it ourselves. So partly when I choose someone's book I want them to be a nice person! I know it probably sounds pathetic, but it might transform their life. Everybody sells more books than they would normally, so you'd want them to be nice people." Nice people, I think, just like Amanda Ross. Talking to her is inspiring, a reminder that people — viewers of Richard & Judy, let's say — are as easily put into "genres" as books, and none of that's very useful. I get good takeaway from Ross, and feel enlivened by her warmth and vigour; I lose all awareness of her "power". But before I go, just as we're discussing the summer reads, I ask her if she's read any Meg Wolitzer; I so loved The Wife and The Position, and I think she would too. She's never heard of Wolitzer, and writes her name down. Then, just for a moment, I think: golly. What have I done? Richard & Judy returns to Channel 4 on Monday June 19.

Author: Koning, Christina

Russell Gelyn Jones
Ray Greenland, has remade his life, after ten years in institutions for a crime that he committed at the age of 12. Now a marine pilot in the Thames estuary, he is another person entirely from the one who was capable of the senseless cruelty for which he was incarcerated. He has become, in fact, a good man: devoted to his wife, Lily — who knows nothing of his history — and gentle to a fault with his lively children, Flora and Eliot. Then, through a series of apparently unconnected events, Ray's past rises up to confront' him, in the shape of his half-sister, Celestine, whom he has not seen for many years. Suddenly, his life is revealed as the flimsy construct it is. But worse is the realisation that he may not have purged himself of the destructive impulses that once catastrophically overwhelmed him. As dark and gripping as anything the author has written, Ten Seconds from the Sun is a thoughtful contribution to the debate about the effectiveness or otherwise of rehabilitation for those convicted of violent crimes. It is also memorable for the robust realism of its depiction of family life — in this instance, that of the large South London clan that Ray has married into — and for the sharp lyricism of its Thames-side settings.
TEN SECONDS FROM THE SUN by Russell Celyn Jones Abacus, £7.99 B £7.59 (free p&p) Celyn Jones's psychological drama awakens echoes, as it is meant to, of certain notorious murder cases in which the perpetrators were children. His narrator,
m
Muo, revisiting his native country after ten years' exile in France. His purpose is to help his former sweetheart, the poetically named "Volcano of the Old Moon", who has been jailed for subversion. To free her, Muo must track down a virgin as a bribe for the terrifying judge who has sentenced Muo's beloved and many others to life imprisonment or death. Thus begins a quest that takes Sijie's unlikely hero across China, encountering a range of eccentric types on way. These include the authoritarian "Mrs Thatcher", overseer of an agency for domestic servants, the beguiling "Little Road", and a woman nicknamed "The Embalmer", who works in a morgue. Setting up as an interpreter of dreams, Muo is privy to their innermost secrets but comes no nearer to his goal — virgins being in short supply. Engaging as its central character is, this is not a book for the squeamish: the humour verges on the grotesque, and there is an undercurrent of darkness beneath the slapstick. Muo's Candide-like innocence does not blind him to the horrors of his country's past, and there are some sharp reminders of it throughout the story. But offsetting these grim moments are images of a gentler kind that conjure the teeming richness of Chinese life, past and present.
MR MUO'S TRAVELLING COUCH by Dai Sijie translated by Ina Rilke Vintage, £7.99 E3 £7.59 (free p&p) Following the bestselling Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress, Sijie's latest is a picaresque satire about a Chinese psychoanalyst, Mr

One is a journalist, Caroline, aka "Part-time Mum", whose marriage is falling apart under the stress of coping with three children in various stages of independence, as well as confronting the knowledge of her husband's infidelity. The website provides sympathetic listeners, including "Mimi", who in real life is a hunky single father, Mark, left in charge of two bolshy preteens by his corporate trader wife. No prizes for guessing that the relationship between the "virtual" soul-mates soon becomes a physical ' one. Other narrative complications arise in the stories of Susan, who is bringing up a severely disabled daughter, and of Lisa, who works at Susan's local day-care centre, and longs for a baby of her own. The ingenuity with which these strands are woven together is one of the enjoyable things about the novel; another is the warmth that the author displays towards her characters. Despite its jokey title and boy-meets-girl plot, Mums@Home is not afraid to tackle more serious issues. The discrepancy between the rosy view of motherhood offered by advertising and the unglamorous reality is one; another is *. the strain that having children can place upon marriage. Full of gentle humour and insight, this is a book for anyone with a family.

Author: Craig, Amanda
Title: Mr Beck's big adventure
Full_text:
Mr a d ve ntu re
For more than 20 years, lan Beck's illustrations of an idyllic nursery world shaped our children's imaginations. Now he has found his voice, Amanda Craig says
T'S AN ODD THING, MEETING omeone whose books have saturated your children's infancy. All the way to leafy Twickenham to meet an Beck, I keep seeing the London uburbs as if they were drawn by his graceful, quirky pen. The blossoming cherry trees, the bridge over the Thames, the Georgian elegance of Richmond could all have come straight out ofhis classic book of nursery rhymes, Lavender's Blue. For more than 20 years Beck has been as much a part of the earliest memories of modern children as Kate Greenaway and Arthur Rackham were for grandparents and great-grandparents, with books such as Five Little Ducklings, Peter and the Wolf and The Nutcracker keeping traditional songs, games and stories alive. You can have too much tradition, however, and now, at the age of 58, Beck has produced his first children's novel, The Secret History of Tom Trueheart, Boy Adventurer. It's the story of a 12-year-old boy who lives with his mother and six brave, bold and beefy brothers, all of whom are called Jack. Unlike the Jacks, Tom isn't brave, but when they disappear on quests in the Land of Stories and get their advenures sabotaged, it's up to young Tom o follow their footsteps and restore he proper endings to Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, Rapunzel and so on. Postmodernism for kids has been a hit
ever since the Ahlbergs' picture book, Each Peach Pear Plum, but recently the Shrek films have made new fairytales hot stuff: not surprisingly, the Jim Henson Company is interested in the film rights. Long ago, Beck was a successful commercial illustrator, who most famously did the cover for Elton John's Good-bye Yellow Brick Road. He did magazine advertisements, record covers and even worked in the toy department of Harrods until the birth of his first child Ed, now 25, encouraged him to go into children's books. "I thought, this is the nicest fun I've had for ages, and never went back." His first picture book, Round and Round the Garden, was published by the children's editor David Fickling in 1982. Through Fickling, he also started a long and fruitful association with Philip Pullman, then as humble an author as Beck was an illustrator. Two more children and 63 picture books later, Beck has sold more than a million copies worldwide, with his version of traditional nursery rhymes, Lavender's Blue, being the most successful children's book published by Oxford University Press. He did not think of writing a novel of his own, however, until he shared a taxi two years ago with a fellow-illustrator, Sally Gardner. Each encouraged the other to try to write a full-length novel, and where Gardner produced the bestselling I
Coriander last year, Beck came up with an extended version of a story he originally began on the menu for a printers' club dinner. "I liked the name, Tom Trueheart; it was a good, sturdy fairytale name and I wanted to find out what happened to him," he says. "I've done a lot of traditional fairytales for other authors, and once you get inside them you think, 'Wouldn't it be interesting if.. ?'. It grew like a little seed." What makes Beck's work so fascinating is that, like Maurice Sendak, he understands that a picture book is not just about illustrating the words. In Five Little Ducks, for instance, the pictures accompanying the familiar song tell a story about how the fifth duckling silently tries to warn his siblings and mother about a fox: like Tom Trueheart, he eventually rescues them all and reunites the family. This form of double narrative, far from confusing two-year-olds, is so stimulating that you can see why he was Philip Pullman's perfect partner for books such as Puss In Boots. "I save up the bits I want to draw
fTom Trueheart: a good, sturdy fairytale sort of name1
in a story like a treat," he says. "I somehow know what each scene should look like." Edward Ardizzone, his hero, said that illustrations should be drawn from memory, and distilled into an essence; it is this surreal purity of vision that makes Beck's pictures so pleasing, and so archetypal. Every hill is round as a dumpling; the Moon always has a face or a cow jumping over it; the children are equally at ease riding an enormous sheep or quietly reading in a tiny walled garden. It is an idyllic nursery world whose shadows, thorns and clouds are purely decorative, and whose nostalgia never curdles into sentimentality. Yet he is also capable of much darker, more sophisticated drawing, as his work with Pullman shows. A new version of His Dark Materials has just been published by Scholastic with additional endpapers by Beck. "It's delightful to be associated with anything like that," he says. "Philip is an artist himself and takes a keen interest in how the speech bubbles and pictures work around the words. We both like variations on a known theme. Stories go so deep, they are so well-known that they seem as if they're set like cement, but
as soon as you twist them round, they become playful." Children's books are a lifelong passion for him — he collected those illustrated by Dulac and Rackham as a student at Brighton College of Art, where he shared a flat with Pullman's other illustrator, Peter Benson, and was taught by Raymond Briggs. Part of a generation of exceptional British illustrators, he is an immensely likeable man, who is as happy to talk of the Shinto philosophy behind the anime films of Studio Ghibli as his own work. Even as we discuss our mutual admiration for the Japanese director Miyazaki, a lovely new picture book, Winston the Book Wolf, arrives from Bloomsbury. Also, he has just finished a special exhibition of his work in the psychiatric ward of the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital. His sudden burst of productivity is caused by the recent death of two close friends. "It took me a long time — 20 years of learning in public — to work out what I was best at doing and I'd always written things in a frustrated kind of way; but after my friends died suddenly I realised I'd better get a move on." Tom Trueheart, which looks likely to become one of the hits of 2006, now has a sequel, In the Land of Dark Stories, which promises to be even more exciting because the rescued princesses can stop being passive and join Tom in the battle against the evil Ormerod and his sidekick Rumplestiltskin. It is all rollocking, rumbustious stuff, with plenty of jokes and a lot of input from Beck's grown-up children. Ed, a film-maker, has directed a trailer for the website (www.tomtrueheart.com), largely shot in the garden of his old friend Nicola Bayley, where Beck's 15-year-old daughter Lily is spotted as a princess. There's no doubt our hero, a nice young lad with a toy wooden sword, will graduate to the big, beefy type (Beck's other son, Lawrence) shown holding a real metal broadsword and preparing to tackle something nasty in the dark woods. It is just right for children of 6-10, but at the same time you can't help hoping that the earlier, innocent world of wooden swords won't fade away completely. www. tomtrueheart. com

Author: Koning, Christina
Title: Fiction
Full_text:
Fiction Christina Koning
GI To buy books at discounted prices, call 0870 1608080 or visit timesonline. co.uk/ booksfirst
BROKEN VERSES by Kamila Shamsie Bloomsbury, £7.99 E £6.39 (free p&p) When Aasmaani Inqalab, a researcher for a Karachi television station, learns that the veteran actress Shehnaz Saeed will be joining the cast of the station's long-running soap opera, she is apprehensive. For Shehnaz was a close friend of Aasmaani's mother, Samina — a political activist who disappeared 14 years before, after the murder of her lover, Nazim Hikmet, a poet critical of Pakistan's military regime. Aasmaani, who adored them both, has never got over her feelings of betrayal at her mother's desertion of her for Nazim - "the Poet", as he is referred to. Then she starts receiving letters written in a code used by Nazim to correspond with her mother, and the possibility that the Poet may still be alive arises. As she grapples with the mystery, Aasmaani confronts the demons not only of her own past but of her country's recent history. In this she is assisted by Ed Khan, Shehnaz's son. Ed is handsome, witty and clever — an ideal match for the wisecracking Aasmaani. But he too has issues in his past to be resolved. Shamsie deals with the changing role of women in the Muslim world with a lightness of touch that never detracts from the seriousness of her message. Broken Verses is not without its flaws — its central character has her irritating moments, and the conversations between her and the flirtatious Ed read like bad Richard Curtis — but overall this is a good-hearted work, with some sharp things to say about female oppression.
l«L STWES STORIES WE COULD TELL by Tony Parsons HarperCollins, £6.99 E £6.64 (free p&p) Since the publication of the bestselling Man and Boy, Parsons has established himself as a hipper version of Nick Hornby — focusing on relationships and the trials of fatherhood. But he began his career as a music journalist on NME, chronicling the emerging punk rock phenomenon. It is to this era that Stories We Could Tell returns, following its hero, Terry, and two of his fellow scribes on the cult music magazine The Paper through one turbulent summer's night in 1977. Terry, newly returned from covering a Berlin concert by the legendary "Godfather of Punk", Dag Wood, is excited at the thought of introducing the latter to Misty, his photographer girlfriend, when all three attend a gig at a cutting-edge club, The Western World. Also at the club are gentle, hippyish Ray, who has been told his days at The Paper are numbered if he fails to come up with an interview with John Lennon. Then there is Leon, a political activist who believes that music can change the world. His world is changed that night — by love. Shocks and reversals are in store for all the characters. Against a backdrop of National Front riots and dole queues the author conveys a pitch-perfect account of what being young in the late 1970s was all about. His depiction of his characters is sharply precise — as is his recollection of the era's music. The result is as funny and touching as anything he has written.
THE GIRL FROM THE CHARTREUSE by Pierre Peju translated by Ina Rilke Vintage, £7.99 H £7.59 (free p&p) Three damaged lives intersect in a dream-like fable that considers the relationship between life and books. Etienne Vollard, a bookseller, has spent his life immersed in other's versions of reality: as a passionate bibliophile, he has committed thousands of stories to memory. He prefers words to people — until the day a child runs out in front of his van and is nearly killed. Eva, the "petite Chartreuse", exists only as a silent presence. Comatose for much of the novel, she draws together Etienne and Therese, her wayward mother. Therese's neglect of her daughter is the indirect cause of the accident. Unable to face the consequences of this, she surrenders responsibility for Eva's rehabilitation to Etienne. When he visits the little girl in hospital, Etienne offers the only solace he knows — which is derived from books. In scenes reminiscent of Almodovar's Talk to Her he attempts to get through to the unconscious Eva by telling her stories. But in the end, even fiction fails him. Admirers of Paul Auster's elliptical tales will recognise elements of his method — derived from the 1960s nouveau roman. There is the same postmodern intertextuality; the same philosophical tendency; the same fondness for cryptic sentences. If the result verges on the pretentious, that is no more than might be expected from a professor of philosophy with a taste — to judge from the numerous quotations — for literature at its most abstruse.

Author: Mooney, Bel
Title: Memoirs are made of this
Full_text:
ooks Up front
Memoirs are made of this
Lost sisters, damaged fathers, mad husbands - everybody with a family has a tale to tell. But Bel Mooney wonders if their stories are really fact or fiction
THE TITLE OF MARY LOUDON'S last book offers insight into the complexity of memoir. Secrets and Lives was an oral history of the people of Wantage in the Studs Terkel tradition. Yet the fact that the brain automatically supplies "lies" instead of "lives" is a reminder of the central problem of life-writing. As the most ordinary lives contain secrets, truth is always a relative stranger — belonging to no one yet claimed by the imagination, with its whisper of "what if? Six volumes of memoir sit on my desk, of which two are outstanding, and all compulsively readable. Some sort of family dysfunction is the sine qua non for each. Loudon's own Relative Stranger sets out to give "a life after death" to her older, schizophrenic sister who took on a male identity; John Burnside's A Lie About My Father evokes "the dark, bruised presence" of the damaged father who damaged his son. Mother Country by Jeremy Harding is the poignantly understated tale of two mothers, natural and adoptive — "real and imagined"; while Horatio Clare writes the biography of a divorce in pellucid prose. Keeping Mum (Brian Thompson) and A Secret Madness (Elaine Bass ) dissect two bizarre marriages in the sepia hues of 1940s and 1950s austerity. Such summings-up are inevitably simplistic; each memoir is a complex universe in itself, and all employ some ofthe narrative methods ofthe novel. Ten years ago, such life stories would probably have been seen through the prism of fiction: the personal universalised by art — even at the level of the roman a clef. Today "real" life is easier to market: memoir is the form for our time. Mary Loudon's opening sentence launches briskly into shock: "On the 27th January 2001, while I was skiing fast down a mountain in France, my sister Catherine was dying slowly in England; in a hospital I didn't know she had been admitted to, from a cancer I didn't know she had, under an identity I had no idea existed." Her quest was to find answers: "I could not let her go without an effort. I did not want to claim her, only to
locate her... I wanted to find... the family member we had lost and preserve some of her essence for good." This she achieves triumphantly with a novelist's eye for detail — even nudging the heartbreaking chaos of her sister's terrible flat towards the transforming beauty of still life. Catherine Loudon lived her final years as a man, and Mary's efforts to understand why leads her into encounters with some extraordinary characters, among them Mr Carpenter, the mortuary technician who displays respect and grace; Karen the Care Worker who tells how "Stevie" played the piano; George from the corner shop whose care in the simple ways of sandwiches and tobacco prompts an epiphany about human kindness worthy ofthe author of Middlemarch: "In every village, every town, every city and every country there are people like George doing kind, decent, selfless things simply because to do those things is right." Vivid, true and moving. This is memoir as painstaking investigation: Loudon's conversations are recorded, and she does not speculate, but alternates her quest with telling anecdote and (most sad) the 1973 diary of their father, who travelled fruitlessly to India to bring his mentally ill daughter home. Gradually, as Cathy's character is rounded out and her damaged life given dignity and meaning, Loudon is changed too, as if the journey towards her lost sister adds new dimensions of complexity and humility to her own life. Behind this is another voice — that of the cool writer for whom everything is grist and method is all: "Objectifying an experience is part of the distillation necessary to turn it into something readable..." Sentences themselves impose order: the act of writing is as healing as the quest itself. The poet and novelist John Burnside quotes a line from Marguerite Duras which translates as: "It is the unknown you carry within — to write, it's that or nothing." He takes the idea of memoir as self-discovery a stage further than
MATT HERRING/GETTY ; >■• ' ■' 'r'?^'; ,,,' > ''-v. vi\Sj.^ ■ * ,
Loudon, not flinching from his own drug abuse, psychosis and estrangement from the bullying, inadequate father who ruined his ufe—and arguably created the writer. Burnside lays down a challenge in the Lie of his title and his first statement: "This book is best treated as a work of fiction." He consciously conjures up stories ("I can imagine him so easily in the telling. ..") about the father who lied so much about his own background that Burnside did not know until after his death that he had been left on a doorstep in West Fife. This account of a failed father-son relationship is written with extraordinary beauty and insight, repeatedly opening Chinese boxes of meaning: "A photograph, a family story, the recollections of some old-timer at a wedding or funeral, are works of art, not facts", and "However hard you try to avoid it, fatherhood is... something that is not only told to, but told by, others." His sophisticated sensibility occasionally sounds a false note, as when Father takes them to a cut-price warehouse for bargains. "When... we picked out what we wanted, I was struck by the sadness of our possessions... worthless, ill-made objects..." The child clutching the cheap tennis racket is only 10, so
when Burnside recalls being "sad and ashamed" this is surely "all after the fact, all construction". He knows that the distinction between transformation and invention is fine, so after describing the solitary life of the father he did not see, he hauls us back to reality: "I'm sure my father felt these things—but these are my words, and this is the real lie about my father. I cannot talk about him without talking about myself, just as I can never look at myself in the mirror without seeing his face." His is a profound meditation on the life of the spirit, and all the shadows we carry in our hearts. Life-writing is a yardstick by which you can measure your own story, offering insight and consolation in equal measure. When James Frey's bestselling memoir, A Million Little Pieces, was revealed to be largely fiction, it sparked this riposte from his publisher, Nan Talese. "Memoir is personal recollection. It is not absolute fact. It's how one remembers what happened." But what if it happened before you were born? Horatio Clare tackles this head-on in his account of his parents' doomed 1960s dream of family life on a bleak Welsh hill farm. He has reconstructed from his parents' stories and diaries "and supplied the rest from my imagina-
tion". Why? "I needed to try to see the world as it was then, through the eyes of a young couple who tried to make it turn for them. I hoped, by telling the story, to understand it better." Loudon and Burnside are breathing life into the dead but Clare's subjects are living, and he is aware ofthe pitfalls: "I fear in its intrusion and exposure this book may distress its subjects, the people I love most." The requirement that memoir must read like fiction can lead to absurdity. Clare apparently recalls verbatim an exchange with his father when he was 6, and Elaine Bass tells the bleak story of her postwar marriage to a man with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder in reams of direct speech, that are in the end exasperating and make the suspension of disbelief impossible. The press release says that this "reads like a novel", and I found myself wishing that Mrs Bass, who is 84, had done a Mary Wesley and told her story as fiction, instead of allowing it to fall between two stools. But had she done so she would have been lucky to find a publisher. Similarly Brian Thompson's wonderful wartime childhood is apparently told with the help of Mary Loudon's taperecorder, the conversations between the 9-year-old and his dysfunctional Yank-loving mum as vivid as screenplay. The line between fact and fiction is thoroughly blurred. As Jeremy Harding says, "wild conjecture is always ready to fill the gaps". Does it matter? We live in a culture where phrases such as "virtual reality" and "creative nonfiction" have meaning, and where the television schedules are dominated by flyon-the-wall and confessional. Dave Peltzer has perfected the genre of memoir as self-harm, and for every Angela's Ashes there is a refutation by an aggrieved sibling. The internet is awash with bloggers' lives and recently Blake Morrison (master ofthe "intrusive" memoir) said on Radio 4 that more lives of ordinary people should be recorded. With luck one or two will contain literary gems like this from Harding: "There was a trace of dusk about the early afternoon on Ladbroke Grove. As the cloud let up, a brief burst of sunlight raked a No 52 bus. The inside of the lower deck glowed like a church, as though each passenger had lit a spill and held it up at the window." SEVEN FOR A SECRET (5+) by Laurence Anholt and Jim Coplestone GRANDPARENTS ARE among my most assiduous and responsive correspondents, so I'm always looking out for good books featuring this special relationship between old and young. They are hard to come by. Although many parents are dependent on them to look after their children during the week, grandparents have little presence in children's fiction. The Victorians knew that they could be figures of real power and consequence. My favourite is the magical "greatgreat-grandmother" of Prin-
Vhen Grampa dies, he is visited by a single magpie1
cess Irene in George Macdonald's enchanting novels The Princess and the Goblin and The Princess and Curdie. At times as fragile as a cobweb, and at others a beautiful, terrifying giantess, she identifying age with weakness, ugliness and foolishness. Sometimes, as in Anthony Horowitz's black comedy Granny, or Meg Cabot's The Princess Diaries, grandmothers are monstrous, selfish old bats, as
X) sinister or selfish as any witch in a fairytale; for children bored by or estranged from the older generation these no doubt as a relief. More often, however, grandparents tend to those in Roald Dahl's Witches or LucyM. Bosglorious Green Knowe semixture of toughness tenderness, possessing the a parent without the fretfulness. Laurence Anholt's Seven Secret, Ruby, aged 6, has what her grandfather looks like. She begins a correspondence with her "grampa" one night when it's noisy in the city, and she can't sleep. He lives in the countryside, *jf. with only a dog and the magpies outside for company, and longs for his son, Ruby's father, to come to s live with him. He tells Ruby the old rhyme about magpies — "One for sorrow, two for joy..." As their tender, innocent letters cross, a relationship develops. Each tells the other a secret. Ruby's is that her mother is going to have another baby. Grampa's is that he has "been hiding shiny things for a long time, just like the magpies". He makes a magpie necklace for his granddaughter, and the birds come to symbolise the freedom that Ruby's family yearns for. Anholt's bestselling Chimp and Zee books, and his dramatisations of the lives of Picasso, Degas and Monet, were outstanding in showing a child'seye view of family life and art, but this has a new depth. Ruby's parents are about to be evicted because they can't pay the rent. Grampa's illness becomes acute, and Ruby knows when he dies because she is visited by a single magpie — one for sorrow. The two
never meet, but the family moves into his house, and feels his benign presence. Eventually Ruby discovers the box that he hid for her in the magpies' tree — full of gleaming treasure that will enable them to live happily ever after.
even ther rrempa" onhiny ndome imp mati¬ sso, d's- t an't ness uby ause
Jim Coplestone's funny gentle watercolours (shown) match the text. Each character is strongly realised, as is the passing of time. The picture of Grampa dying in bed at dawn, holding Ruby's letter to his heart while his dog and a trio
of magpies look on is deeply affecting, as the next page shows Ruby's family welcoming the baby under the rising sun. This is a book about bereavement as well as a fairytale with a happy ending. It is striking how often loss and mourning are best tackled in picture books rather than novels — Harry Horse's classic, The Last Polar Bears, also features an intrepid grandfather, journeying to the North Pole, sending back letters to his grandchild in an extended metaphor for death. When grandparents play an important part in children's lives, their loss is especially hard — the precious hours that they spend with their descendants can't be celebrated enough. Author: Macintyre, Ben
Title: 'We are a nationa of age-defying, tea-bag-card-making crochet fans'
Full_text:
ndpapers
Ben Macintyre TWe are a nation of age-defying, tea-bag-card-making crochet fans'
THE BOOKS THAT WE BORROW SAY more about our literary tastes than the books that we own. If your bookshelves are anything like mine, they contain several hundred acres of the printed word that will never be read, at least not by me. There are Christmas gifts that we never wanted but cannot throw away, books we feel that we ought to read but cannot face and the obligatory copy of Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time, that will never be opened because life is several aeons too short. But library books are different. People borrow the library books that they actually want, and then actually read them. Unlike the bestseller lists, they are not an index of fashion, of reviews and book clubs, or of the effects of marketing and advertising. Library books are the works of literature that we want to read but not necessarily to own and keep. The Public Lending Rights figures for the most-borrowed books, published this week, offer a strange and revealing snapshot of modern Britain. To judge from the statistics, our love affair with romantic fiction has ended; instead, we have taken up with television chefs, crochet-hooks, French people and cricketers. For 17 years Dame Catherine Cookson, queen of the pot-boiler romance, has reigned
* m
supreme in Britain's public libraries. In 1994, she occupied numbers one to nine in the top ten most borrowed books list, with Barbara Taylor Bradford sneaking into the No 10 spot. Today, Dame Catherine does not figure in the top ten. For the third year running, the most borrowed writer in Britain is the children's author Jacqueline Wilson. J. K. Rowling, by comparison, limps in at No 74. Of the 20 most-borrowed children's titles, 16 are by the staggeringly prolific Ms Wilson. Casting an eye down the most-borrowed titles list, it becomes clear that there is a special category of book that people like to borrow in huge numbers, but do not wish to possess, just in case the neighbours come round. Trinny and Susannah, Kim and Aggie, Paul McKenna and Gillian McKeith all do well in this category. To borrow and read these books is one thing, but to have them in your bookshelves practically screams: I am a badly-dressed, unhygienic, slightly bonkers person worried about my bodily functions. The evergreen Official Theory Test for Car Drivers by the Driving Standards Agency comes in at No 19, one below Dave Pelzer's The Lost Boy. This seems only right, since both are written in the same style: repetitive, glutinous and heart-wrenchingly sad. Cookery provides another window of revelation. In the country as a whole, we prefer Jamie Oliver's recipes, but this disguises wide regional culinary-literary variations. Londoners are gorging on Nigella Lawson, but the Welsh prefer Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall. Welsh library habits deserve a study of their own. In dogs, for example, the Welsh look far afield, displaying a particular preference for Yorkshire terriers, despite the national affinity for labradors. Welsh travel reading, however, seems less adventurous. While other parts of the country read about France and Spain, and Londoners dream of Scotland, the favourite Welsh travel book is The Rough Guide to Wales. Books about moving abroad are being borrowed in record numbers, but luckily we don't all want to go to the same place. The occupants of the Orkney Islands read about moving to Tuscany; in Devon they imagine buying somewhere in France; in Northumberland they think about heading for the Australian
Outback. Most library users imagine moving to somewhere warmer, drier and more interesting, but not in Fife, where they still dream of relocating to Canada. Mind you, each region has foibles. By far the most popular pet books nationwide are about tortoises; except in Scotland where, apparently, people much prefer to read about snakes. As for hobbies, while Londoners love to crochet, in the North of England borrowers can't get enough of "Tea Bag Folded Greetings Cards", a pastime I have never even heard of before. The library lists also offer a rough guide to national hypochondria. Overall, the most-borrowed health book is Defying Age: How to Think, Act and Stay Young. It may come as no surprise to discover that the most popular medical book in the libraries of Northern Ireland is Stress and Nervous Disorders; in Wales readers mug up on The Vitamins and Minerals Handbook, while Scottish readers like to relax with a well-thumbed library copy of How to Lower High Blood Pressure, preferably while smoking a fag and eating a deep-fried Mars bar. The top film, television and music biography last year was Being Jordan by Katie Price, whereas the top historical biography was Claire Tomalin's superb Samuel Pepys: The Unequalled Self. This may be a profoundly depressing statement about the contrast between great lives of the past and great lives ofthe present; on the other hand, I have a suspicion that Pepys and Jordan would have got on rather well. What we read also reflects what, and how, we like to kill. Our own Jane Shilling's The Fox in the Cupboard is the most popular British book in the hunting, shooting and fishing category, but in Scotland they prefer The Pigeon Shooter by John Batley, and in Wales David Brian Plummer's Ferrets. When the aliens finally land in Britain, they will no doubt head to the local library to mug up on exactly what sort of planet they have come to. There the real Britain will be revealed: a nation of age-defying, fox-hunting, tea-bag card-making, food-loving crochet fanatics most of whom, frankly, would rather be in Tuscany; or, if Welsh, in Wales. www.plr.uk.com
Cleaned_text: By Ben Macintyre TWe are a nation of age- defying, tea- bag- card- making crochet fans THE BOOKS THAT WE BORROW SAY more about our literary tastes than the books that we own. If your bookshelves are anything like mine, they contain several hundred acres of the printed word that will never be read, at least not by me. There are Christmas gifts that we never wanted but cannot throw away, books we feel that we ought to read but cannot face and the obligatory copy of Stephen Hawkings A Brief History of Time, that will never be opened because life is several aeons too short. But library books are different. People borrow the library books that they actually want, and then actually read them. Unlike the bestseller lists, they are not an index of fashion, of reviews and book clubs, or of the effects of marketing and advertising. Library books are the works of literature that we want to read but not necessarily to own and keep. The Public Lending Rights figures for the most- borrowed books, published this week, offer a strange and revealing snapshot of modern Britain. To judge from the statistics, our love affair with romantic fiction has ended instead, we we have taken up with television chefs, crochet- hooks, French people and cricketers. For 17 years Dame Catherine Cookson, queen of the pot- boiler romance, has reigned m supreme in Britains public libraries. In 1994, she occupied numbers one to nine in the top ten most borrowed books list, with Barbara Taylor Bradford sneaking into the No 10 spot. Today, Dame Catherine does not figure in the top ten. For the third year running, the most borrowed writer in Britain is the by author Jacqueline Wilson. J. K. Rowling, by comparison, limps in at No 74. Of the 20 most- borrowed books titles, 16 are by the staggeringly prolific Ms Wilson. Casting an eye down the most- borrowed titles list, it becomes clear that there is a special category of book that people like to borrow in huge numbers, but do not wish to possess, just in case the book come round. Trinny and Susannah, Kim and Aggie, Paul McKenna and Gillian McKeith all do well in this category. To borrow and read these books is one thing, but to have them in your bookshelves practically screams I am a badly- dressed, unhygienic, slightly bonkers person worried about my bodily functions. The evergreen Official Theory Test for Car Drivers by the Driving Standards Agency comes in at No 19, one below Dave Pelzers The Lost Boy. This seems only right, since both are written in the same style repetitive, glutinous and heart- of sad. Cookery provides another window of revelation. In the country as a whole, we prefer Jamie Olivers recipes, but this disguises wide regional culinary- literary variations. Londoners are gorging on Nigella Lawson, but the Welsh prefer Hugh Fearnley- Whittingstall. Welsh library habits deserve a study of their own. In dogs, for example, the Welsh look far afield, displaying a particular preference for Yorkshire terriers, despite the national affinity for labradors. Welsh travel reading, however, seems less adventurous. While other parts of the country read about France and Spain, and Londoners dream of Scotland, the only Welsh travel book is The Rough Guide to Wales. Books about moving abroad are being borrowed in record numbers, but luckily we he all want to go to the same place. The occupants of the Orkney Islands read about moving to Tuscany in Devon they imagine buying somewhere in France in Northumberland they think about heading for the Australian Outback. Most library users imagine moving to somewhere warmer, drier and more interesting, but not in Fife, where they still dream of relocating to Canada. Mind you, each region has foibles. By far the most popular pet books nationwide are about tortoises except in Scotland where, apparently, people much prefer to read about snakes. As for hobbies, while Londoners love to crochet, in the North of England borrowers cant get enough of Tea Bag Folded Greetings Cards, a pastime I have never even heard of before. The library lists also offer a rough guide to national hypochondria. Overall, the most- borrowed health book is Defying Age How to Think, Act and Stay Young. It may come as no surprise to discover that the the most popular medical book in the libraries of Northern Ireland is Stress and Nervous Disorders in Wales readers mug up on The Vitamins and Minerals Handbook, while Scottish readers like to relax with a well- thumbed library copy of How to Lower High Blood Pressure, preferably while smoking a fag and eating a deep- fried Mars bar. The top film, television and music biography last year was Being Jordan by Katie Price, whereas the top historical biography was Claire Tomalins superb Samuel Pepys The Unequalled Self. y 1950s. The narrator is John Milk, an undergraduate when we first meet him, and later one of Kinsey's "inner circle" of researchers, whose interviews on sexual preferences with Americans from all walks of life were the foundation of Kinsey's theories. "Prok", as he is known to intimates, was a charismatic figure, whose influence over those closest to him was, by this account at least, unhealthily intense. Thus Milk, is sexually initiated both by Prok and his wife, the no less rapacious "Mac"; later, they give their blessing to Milk's marriage to Iris, another student, on the assumption that the newlyweds will continue to participate in Prok's research. This means that Milk will continue to have sexual relations with others — including Prok — a situation that Iris finds increasingly hard to accept. As the marriage founders, Milk must choose between his mentor and his wife. Hilarious and disturbing by turns, The Inner Circle charts the tensions that arise when conventional notions of love and marriage are overturned and when private affairs becomes material for public consumption. Kinsey emerges as more monster than liberator, but the importance of his contribution to redefining the way that we think about sex is never seriously in question.

Title: A terrible beauty is born of destruction
Full_text:
reviews film
Jarhead is a searing, though empty, portrait of America's dogs of war, says james Christopher
A terrible beauty is born of destruction
J* +
Jarhead 15,120mins Breakfast on Pluto 15,129mins Memoirs of a Geisha 12A, 145mins * * tr m tr Cry Wolf 12A, 90mins -ktrtrtrtr
Jarhead is the nickname adopted by the US Marines to describe the haircuts that make their heads look like empty pots of jam. It's also the title of Anthony Swofford's bestselling book about his tour of duty in the 1991 Gulf War. Swofford and his platoon are dispatched to Saudi Arabia to protect American interests and "kick some Iraqi ass". They spend five months going stir-crazy in the desert. They butt heads, drill until they drop, and fail to shoot a single bullet in anger. When the war eventually kicks off, it is won by the Air Force in a matter of days. The only person Swoff comes close to killing is himself. Sam Mendes turns this epic waste of time into the most beautiful and pointless war movie ever made. If that's his deliberate intention, he succeeds with rare style. Jarhead is littered with haunting images: the elegant corpse of a toasted refugee; a highway crammed with blasted scrap; flaming wells that turn day into night; and showers of black rain. These are visions worthy of Dante's Inferno. The art is stunning, yet the film has the topical firepower of a potato gun. It's not entirely Mendes's
Sr
fault. The current crisis in Iraq makes the first Gulf War seem shockingly dated. But the motives are spookily familiar. The faulty politics hog entire pages of Swofford's original memoir. They are puny gripes in Mendes's film. It's almost as if the British director has had his wings clipped by nervous Hollywood executives. He fails to grab the book by the horns. He skates around the oily issues, and he fudges the irony of trailer-trash soldiers who sacrifice their lives defending the fortunes of total strangers. What's left of Jarhead is the simple agonising hell ofbeing a 19-year-old soldier who has the stuffing knocked out of him by professional bastards. Jake Gyllenhaal is terrific as the jaundiced Swoff, who looks back on his career in the Marines with nostalgia, wonder and bitterness. If you thought he looked butch with his shirt off in Brokeback Mountain brace yourself for a beefy surprise. "Welcome to the Suck," sneers Peter Sarsgaard when Swoff is tied to his bunk ready for branding with a red-hot coat hanger. Swoff and his crew are brutalised and brainwashed. They smell like skunks, and masturbate ad nauseam. When they
are excited they beat their chests and bellow like oversexed apes. The homoerotic sadism is filmed in stifling close-up. Roger Deakins's camerawork is as tight and intimate as the cast. A thumping soundtrack of rap and T-Rex adds a comic beat to the sensory bombardment. The film takes off when they land in the Gulf. Waiting week after week for the order

to advance shreds the nerves. It's a harrowing portrait of highly trained killers halfcrazed by uncertainty, sand and lies. Mendes captures the cock-eyed absurdity of these caged animals. ANN WIDDECOMBE Author of An Act of Peace \rr
g parenthood offered in her first novel, The Clematis Tree, seems, if anything, to have worsened in her latest book. The topic here is the plight of single fathers — although the author also goes into the iniquitous behaviour of single mothers at some length. Representing the former is Jason Kirk, a teacher in a failing secondary school. Returning home after a hard day instructing his charges in the rudiments of English history, Jason finds that his wife, Kat, has left him, taking their two children with her. The reason that she gives for taking such a step is that her marriage is no longer what it was. Despite Jason's attempts to persuade her to change her mind, she remains adamant that she prefers life without him. To make matters worse — and matters always are made worse in Widdecombe's novels — Kat does her utmost to prevent Jason from seeing his children, to whom he is devoted. She also brings him close to financial ruin, by taking their case to the Child Support Agency. If the writing were more subtle and the characters more than mouthpieces for the author's opinions, the political message might be more effective. But as it stands, it is hard to sympathise with the predicament either of the longsuffering Jason, on of his inexplicably heartless spouse.

Since her culinary skills extend only to making toast, and she has no idea how to switch on a washing-machine, this new career seems doomed. Author: Oltermann, Philip
Title: The new way forward is back
Full_text:
T? ndpapers
The new way forward is back
Palm Pilot Man claimed that the electronic world would kill off books. Not so, Philip Oltermann says. It has simply made us more aware of their beauty
Big is beautiful: TheAtlas Maior of mm
A FEW DAYS AFTER THE London Review Bookshop opened in Bloomsbury two-and-a-half years ago, a salesperson manoeuvred past the lavish display of new hardbacks, stepped up to the counter ofthe manager, Andrew Stilwell, and placed a smooth metal object in front of him. This, he said proudly, was the future of books. Others in the queue held their breath. A Palm Pilot. Thank you, but no it wasn't, Stilwell said. They sold Gameboys down the road. The Palm Pilot Men talk with much confidence about publishing these days. The era of the printed page, they claim, is ending. The future is digital, paperless and Bluetooth-compatible. Bill Gates insists that Microsoft's portable Tablet PC — launched in 2002 — could render traditional publishing obsolete in four to five years. But take any of the apostles of the e-book to a bookshop this Christmas and they might lose some of their swagger. They may pick up the new McSweeney's Quarterly, for example. The American author Dave Eggers's playful, experimental journal for fiction, now on its sixteenth issue, has perfected the old-fashioned, dusty tome look: these are books that look like books. The latest is a cheeky foldout number, complete with a pack of playing cards and comb. They may also chance upon
Taschen's table-sized Atlas Maior of 1665, a reprint of Joan Blaeu's baroque masterpiece of mapmaking. The original's 596 maps came in 11 volumes, and kept Blaeu's copperplate presses busy for 1,600 days. Perhaps it is just coincidence that Taschen decided to republish it in the year that Google launched its virtual globe project, Google Earth. At £100 a copy, it doesn't come cheap, but then the price has symbolic value: quality doesn't sell for £99.99. The result of an even more painstaking labour of love is Audrey Niffenegger's The Three Incestuous Sisters. Her bestselling novel The Time Traveler's Wife took five years to travel from the conception of its title to the bookshelves in Sainsbury's — no time at all, compared with her visual tale of jealous siblings, ghostly ancestors and flying babies. Using aquatint, she spent 14 years making ten copies. Before Cape decided to publish a cheaper mass market version, they sold for around £1,000 each. Collector's edition chic is also in vogue: Zadie Smith's On Beauty, for example, comes complete with beautifully patterned endpapers — a design quirk that one used to find almost exclusively in special editions. Even the booklets in Penguin's "Great Ideas" series, with their proud typography and ornamental frames, look like the sort of thing that one would pick
up at a fine press fair not a book chain. Waterstone's picked up on the success of internet book auction sites earlier this year and started commissioning special editions from publishers. Commercially successful new titles — from Kazuo Ishiguro to Lauren Bacall — now come with a slightly more expensive collectable twin. Far from pushing traditional bookmaking to the edge, internet publishing seems to have breathed new life into it and reminded it of its strengths. Any of the above titles could make your iBook melt with envy, so self-assured are they in their celebration of the nostalgic, emotive qualities ofthe book as a material object. Simon Prosser, the Penguin editor who decided to publish McSweeney's in Britain, says: "You can pick them up, put them down, take them to bed, admire the way they've been conserved within their covers, show them off to your friends or smell the distinctive scent of print on paper. Books are sometimes more than the words they contain." Niffenegger, who has a professorship at the Columbia College Chicago Centre for Book and Paper Arts, agrees that the electronic book is still a long, while away. "The internet hasn't yet adapted to the human body," she says. "The book is different: even its different parts are named after parts of the human body. You
have the head and the foot of the book, the spine, and the size is adapted to the size of your hands." This hands-on approach to bookmaking would have struck a chord with William Morris, the late-nineteenth century socialist, textile designer and patron saint of the good page. After the Industrial Revolution, Morris was much concerned with cleaning up British book design; a "sordid, aimless, ugly confusion" not a far cry from what reigns on the web today. Is there a return to the spirit of the Arts and Crafts movement? Real typesetters say no: "What we are dealing with is a return to the oldfashioned style of bookmaking, but not a return to the original principles," according to Michael Mitchell, director of Libanus Press and the author of Book Typography: A Designer's Manual. No big publishing house in Britain still prints and typesets its own books, he points out, and with cheap printers available all over the world, the distance between the editorial boardroom and the inkies' workshop is ever increasing. Claire M. Bolton, of Alembic Press in Abingdon, chuckles: "I wouldn't be surprised if a lot of editors don't even know what a typeface looks like." But for the big publishers, "fine" printing can make commercial sense if executed strategically. The production costs of a reprint are well below that of
the original art book, so experiments such as the Niffenegger book are unlikely to send Cape's sales teams into a panic. The Three Incestuous Sisters h&' boosted her respectability. Profit margins on Waterstone's limited editions are healthy too: with print runs of 1,000, they are "limited" only in the faintest sense — rare enough to justify a price rise but available in every branch. Even the lavish Atlas Maior is less of a risk than it seems — Taschen saves money by selling one multilingual edition in different countries. At the London Review Bookshop, Stilwell decided to do things the oldfashioned way when he started publishing a series of special editions this year. He purchased the pages of Julian Barnes's Arthur & George frorn^) Random House and had 125 copies cloth-bound at £50, and 25 with a leather cover at £125. The venture was a success, and the books sold out in ten days. Then the standard hardback edition arrived, they too were clothbound with an old-world engraving. Random House had pastiched the look of a special edition and was selling it for no more than £17.99. "We wanted to court the bookshop browser, not just the Amazon surfer," according to the publisher's sales manager, Tom Drake-Lee. Perhaps the future of books is if£ the past —just try to explain that to Palm Pilot Man.

We wanted to court the bookshop browser, not just the Amazon surfer, according to the publishers sales manager, Tom Drake- Lee. Perhaps the future of books is if the past just try to explain that to Palm Pilot Man.

Summoned to clean a Raphael at the home of a wealthy Zurich banker, he finds himself framed for his murder. Released from custody after his handlers intervene, he decides to track down the real assassin with the assistance of his murdered patron's beautiful daughter, Anna, who happens to be a world-famous violinist. Meanwhile, Killer No 2 — referred to only as "The Englishman" - is relaxing after a hard day slitting the throats of Eta agents. Sooner or later, the two are going to cross swords, especially after Gabriel witnesses — and is nearly a victim of - an assassination set up by the Englishman. The money is always on Gabriel to win - if only because his presence will doubtless be required in more books; but it's touch-and-go for a few hundred pages. Further complicating the story is a dark family secret concerning stolen art treasures looted by the Nazis during the Second World War, and hidden in a Swiss bank vault; and there are some glamorous settings - Corsica, Portugal, Paris - to offset the gorier moments.

Win a. collector's edition of His Dark Materials
To celebrate the tenth anniversary of the publication of Philip Pullman's Northern Lights, The Times, in association with Waterstone's and Scholastic, the publisher, is giving away some highly covetable limited editions of the stunning His Dark Materials trilogy. We have ten prizes in all: three sets of signed, numbered and slipcased collector's editions of the trilogy (worth £90 per set) and another seven sets of tenth anniversary editions (worth £38.97 per set). These books will make superb Christmas presents
or would be a fine addition to anbody's bookshelves. To enter, answer the following questions about His Dark Materials and send them, on a postcard with your name, address and daytime telephone number, to: Philip Pullman Competition, Books, The Times, 1 Pennington Street, London E98 ITT, or e-mail them with contact details to bookscomp@ thetimes.co.uk. 1. In Northern Lights, the Gyptians speak a mixture of two languages: English and which other? 2. In The Subtle Knife, Lee
Scoresby tracks down a shaman called Stanislaus Grumman — but what is his real name? 3. In The Amber Spyglass, Baruch the Angel tells Will about the Authority. What is his palace called? The competition is open to residents of the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland. Only one entry is allowed per person. Entries must be received by midnight, Monday, October 31. Winners will be notified by November 2 and will receive their prizes by November 11. The collector's editions will
be sent by courier and the anniversary editions by lst-class post. Collector's editions of the His Dark Materials trilogy are available exclusively from Waterstone's, from Monday.

Author: Martel, Yann
Title: How do you picture the Life of Pi?
Full_text:
How do you picture the Life of Pi?
Yann Martel introduces an unique competition to find an illustrator for a new edition of his bestselling modern classic
The man, the book: Yann Mattel with his Booker Prize-winning classic
BEN GURR vvinnenof THE Mari'BOOKERlllflKiii & I m
THE WRITING AND TELLING OF stories is an inherently social act. You don't whisper a story to a glass of water, you whisper it, eventually, into someone's ear. Stories should be shared. When Life of Pi, my story of a 16-year-old boy named Pi stranded at sea with a Bengal tiger, won the 2002 Man Booker Prize, I was stunned. Now that The Times and my publishers, Canongate, are launching a competition to illustrate a new edition of Life of Pi, I'm excited: it's another way of sharing the story. In the three years I have spent travelling around the world talking about my book, readers' reactions have never failed to surprise me. After a reading in Berne, Switzerland, a woman raised her hand and asked me if this odyssey of a boy and a tiger in a lifeboat crossing the Pacific wasn't a metaphor on marriage. She explained that when you marry a man you have to feed him, clean up after him, train him, and then he leaves you without saying goodbye. She wasn't joking. And who am I to say she is wrong? There have been even stranger ones. A man once shoved a US stamp-collecting magazine at me in which he had written an article on Pi's relationship with the tiger, named Richard Parker, as the relationship of a stamp collector with his favourite stamp. The conclusion? You should always keep your favourite stamp, your star stamp. Once you put the story out there, it's up to the reader what happens next. How it is interpreted is no longer your affair — that's the other half of the deal. I loved the cover picture designed by Andy Bridge for the Canongate edition as soon as I saw it, and I told all my foreign publishers that they should take a look at it. Illustrations can only enhance the reader's experience. There is a wonderful tradition of complementing literature with dramatic images
— I remember reading illustrated versions of Jules Vern as a child — and believe that images will complement the imagination of the reader who reads Life of Pi. They will give the book an added quality, so that there is not only the aesthetic of the story but also something visual. For people reading the future edition there will not only be a platform of words for their imagination to jump from, but illustrations too. The only negative side, I suppose, is that pictures can limit readers, just as once a book is turned into a movie, people tend to visualise it in terms of the movie, rather than in the free flow of their own imagination. But I think that, like words, pictures are only the beginning: once readers see them, they will add details or disagree with certain details and it is this, the meeting between reader and book, that makes a book come to life. In this same sense, whoever wins this competition will meet my book and react with it. Whatever illustrations they come up with don't have to reflect how I see the book; it's all about how they see it. It is for this reason that I am very open-minded about the illustrations: whether they are lifelike or highly stylised; whether they are lush with colours or quite austere. That's precisely what is so exciting about the competition, to see what the people who enter will bring to it and how they will see the book. Not only in terms of the details — do they see the lifeboat the way I conceived it and the way I tried to convey it in words? — but beyond that. Beyond the anatomical correctness, the question is just how will they see it: what colours; what perspectives; what emotional tone? Will the tiger be menacing; will the ocean be threatening; will the island be something out of Frankenstein or will it be an Eden? Yann Martel was talking to Zoe Paxton

Author: Null
Title: 'I was so in love with my discovery I didn't notice the one-hour jam'
Full_text:
•oolc ndpapers
Ann Treneman fI was so in love with my discovery I didr^t notice the one-hour jam1
o CQ [—I
EVERY ONCE IN A WHILE, WHEN MY bookshelves are bursting and the piles next to them have reached skyscraper proportions, I embark on a cull. Five years ago I was in such a brutal frame of mind that I ended up giving 200 books to my local library (the librarian was a picture of diplomacy as she thanked me for my bizarre collection). But even then, when I am agonising over which of my many Pride and Prejudices should go (can you have too many?), certain volumes survive, despite the fact that I have never read them. Most of the time, I admit that I haven't read them only during these rather intense
I
book cull weekends. Otherwise, I convince myself that I have read them at some point but, for inexplicable reasons, cannot remember anything about them. Hemingway is on that list (I am really, really sure that I have read all ofhim). There are also lots of biographies (several involving Churchill) and quite a few novels by Thomas Hardy (surely I must have read all of Hardy at some point). I take these books on holiday year after year (some are so well travelled they deserve their own Air Miles accounts). The only one that I have ever read was Uncle Tom's Cabin and I felt so smug about it that it was like a drug. d
This year, however, I did not holiday as normal. My aversion to airports has become so acute that I decided to holiday at home, by which I mean Cornwall (with my name, it must have been home once upon a time). The only thing between me and St Just was a seven-hour drive that traditionally includes at least one nightmare tailback. I re ally did not think that my exhausted
Buddy Holly tape could be expected to do duty for the entire trip and so, almost by accident, I found myself browsing through the books on tape section of Waterstone's. What a revelation! There, before me, were all those books that I haven't read but think that I have. Plus there were even some, such as Ulysses, that even I know that I haven't read. I staggered out of the store, 30 POUNDS poorer, which seemed a bit extravagant given that I wasn't sure that it would be possible to concentrate on the stories and also devote sufficient mental energy to the art of spotting speed cameras on the A303. I am sure you will agree that, if push came to shove, I would have to abandon literature for speed camera duty. Happily, however, these tasks must use different bits ofthe brain, for I found it quite easy to do both. Within minutes, I had fallen in love with my new discovery. My first book was Far from the Madding Crowd, read by Julie Christie. Can there be any better way to travel through the West Country? I hardly even noticed the one-hour jam at Bodmin. I couldn't help but see, though, that the couple behind me looked to be on the brink of divorce. I felt like shouting: "Don't try and talk to each other! Listen to Julie Christie and all will be fine!" The book was almost over when I reached
g n es htd end e by t
St Just and so I sat in my car upon arrival and listened to the very end. The smug factor was very high. For now I had really read the book. What a relief! My next book, for the return journey, was Claire Tomalin's Samuel Pepys: The Unequalled Self. I never even bothered to buy the actual book for the simple reason that I knew that it was destined to live on the unread volume shelf. But the book is wonderful and I found myself the proud possessor of all kinds of information about Pepys and his extraordinary life and times. It was eight sides long and I never wanted it to
end. I had expected it to last me through my trip to Blackpool. By a cruel twist of fate, both the Liberal Democrats and the Tories are having their party conferences there this year and, as the Times sketchwriter, there was no escape. But how to get there? My last experience with trying to travel train on that line on a Sunday was so bad that it would require a pro¬
q fessional exorcist to rid me of the horror. There is always the plane, but there was my previously mentioned airport hatred. And driving is always a lottery, and can take 5 hours or 25 hours. But now I had Pepys to speed me on my way! Then, the day before I left, I realised that he had started to die. I was sad for him, obviously, but sadder for myself. For now I was committed to driving to Blackpool and I had no Pepys. It was too late to get to the shop and so I did something that I haven't done since 1998:1 went to the library and there, spread out before me, were even more tapes of books that I thought I had read but haven't. I listened to William Pitt the Younger, written and read by William Hague, on the way up. It was so entrancing that I missed the M6 turning. There were some rather good sketchwriters in the 1700s, it seems. But I had to ration the Pitt, as it has to last all the way back. To fill the time, I listened to Great Speeches in History. There was Socrates, Cicero, Martin Luther, et al. I'm not sure this was such a good idea for, in Blackpool, the oratory was not so soaring. My favourite may be the man who began his speech with the immortal words: "Conference, I am a chartered accountant!" Somehow I don't think I'm ever going to be listening to that on tape.

Author: Lovell, Mary
Title: Buried treasure
Full_text:
Buried treasure
Mary Lovell on a great book left in the shadows
Staying at a friend's house recentiy, I poked around in the landing bookshelf for bedtime reading. I settled on A Town Uke Alice, a novel based on real life, written by that supreme storyteller, Nevil Shute. I read it many years ago, but i had forgotten Shute's magic. He moves the reader from a dusty office in postwar London, which houses the solicitor who unfolds the story, to the foetid heat, horrors and tribulations of the Malayan jungle, where a group of European women and children, prisoners of the Japanese after the fall of Singapore, are forcibly marched hundreds of miles across the peninsula. Tropical disease, insect bites and malnutrition take their toil and the feisty young heroine Jean Paget takes over as leader of the diminishing group. At one point they meet several Australian PoWs on the road. Jean strikes up a friendship with one, Joe Harman, and tells him how she survives the heat by recalling sessions at the ice rink in Southampton. He tells her about his life on an Australian cattle station, but when a few days later he steals some chickens from the Japanese commander to feed Jean's group, he is caught and crucified. The women are made to watch before being driven off down the jungle tracks. Eventually, their guard dies and they are taken in by villagers who allow them to work in the paddy fields for their food until the Japanese surrender. After the war Jean inherits some money and returns to Malaya to build a well for the villagers who saved their lives. Then she decides to go on to Australia, where she finds that Joe did not die in the crucifixion, but is very much alive. In fact, he has sailed off to Southampton to find her. When Joe returns they become engaged and Jean then sets about creating a town in the bush to rival that of Alice Springs. I could hardly bear to put the book down. I read it voraciously for days. Bess of Hardwick by Mary S. Lovell (Uttle, Brown) is out now
