Author: Chater, David
Title: TV Choice
Full_text:
Main channels
0 TVChoice David Chater
THE SECRET UFE OF ARTHUR RANSOME BBC Two, 9.10pm Griff Rhys Jones (above) travels to Russia to tell the astonishing story of Arthur Ransome, the author whose novels — Swallows and Amazons, Coot Club and We Didn't Want to Go to Sea — have captivated thousands of middle-class ten-year-olds. Ransome, it transpires, was no Boy Scot In tweeds. He went to Russia for the first time in 1913 to get away from his wife, and ended up with a ringside seat at the Russian Revolution. He was recruited by British Intelligence, but fell in love with Trotsky's secretary. Although he was a man of exceptional courage and resourcefulness, It was never entirely clear which team he was supporting. Rhys Jones is an enthusiastic storyteller, and he tells a sensational story of intrigue and passion.
ASHES FEVER Channel 4, 4.10pm Highlights from this most gripping of Test series — from the nerve-shredding finishes at Edgbaston and Trent Bridge to the climax at the Oval - are given extra impact by the insights of those involved at first hand. How, for example, did England regroup after the humiliation at Lord's? How, in fact, did a series of cricket matches come to define the spirit of the summer of 2005? James Jackson m/50: ANT & DEC'S GAMESHOW MARATHON ITVl, 6.10pm Continuing ITV's season of self-congratulation, Ant and Dec celebrate some of the
channel's most popular game shows. The first on their list is The Price is Right, which will be played in front of a celebrity audience. Six audience members will be asked to join in, and the winners each week will go through to the next game.
These will include Bullseye, Play Your Cards Right, The Sale of the Century and Family Fortunes. But don't let me put you off. JUUAN FELLOWES INVESTIGATES A MOST MYSTERIOUS MURDER BBC One, 9.10pm As actors recreate the events surrounding a series of unsolved murders, the bestselling writer Julian Fellowes shimmers in and out of the action commenting on the events as they unfold. In 1902, a pregnant servant girl called Rose Harsent was stabbed to death in the middle of the night during a summer storm in a small Suffolk village. Her lover - a married man and a leading light in the Methodist chapel - was twice tried for her murder, but the jury was unable to reach a verdict. Fellowes offers his own theory about who was responsible, but there is still plenty of reasonable doubt. 02ZY OSBOURNE: IN MY UFE ITVL 10.10pm From abattoir worker in Birmingham to rock lunatic to eccentric national treasure, Ozzy Osbourne (below left) is perhaps most remarkable for his longevity. In this latest bout of indulgence (in a film named after his favourite Beatles song) he talks openly about such topics as his former alcoholism and drug addiction, his time in jail for the attempted murder of his wife Sharon, and how he lost his best friend and guitarist in a freak plane crash (the band's tour-bus driver was flying the plane at the time). JJ BEST OF THE REST... ZIPPY AND GEORGE'S PUPPET LEGENDS Channel 4,10.55pm From Gordon the Gopher to Spitting Image's Mrs Thatcher.

Author: David, Saul
Title: A very long way from Blighty
Full_text:
►ooks iionfiction
Nonfiction Saul David A very long way from Blighty
SAHIB: The British Soldier in India 1750-1914 by Richard Holmes CHILDREN OF THE RAJ by Vyvyen Brendon THE RAJ IS CLEARLY ALL the rage. Already this year we've had books on Thugs, curry and General Dyer, the perpetrator of the Amritsar massacre. And now two studies on the Indian experiences of two very different groups of Britons: soldiers and children. Richard Holmes's Sahib is very much a follow-up to his recent bestselling books on the British soldier in the preCrimean and First World War eras. He is canny enough to realise that colonial history is a minefield of national sensibilities and so chooses not to enter the lively debate about the "rights or wrongs" of the Indian Empire. Instead his book illuminates the "central paradox" of the Raj: how a relatively small number of soldiers gained and held most of the subcontinent for almost 200 years. It also explains why they went there, how they lived and how they died. As with previous studies, Holmes uses a thematic approach to contrast the different eras. The journey to India, for instance, shortens from a six-month voyage in a sailing vessel round the Cape of Good
Hope in the mid-18th century to just a matter of weeks in a steamer, via the Suez Canal, at the end of the 19th. The downside of this approach is that it sacrifices chronological order and narrative flow. Holmes partly gets round that by including, at the outset, a brisk overview of the many wars fought by the British in India before 1914. But in devoting so little space to such a huge period he is forced to rely on generalisation and, occasionally, misrepresentation. General Elphinstone is again fingered, unfairly in my opinion, as the villain ofthe disastrous retreat from Kabul in 1842; and the cartridges that sparked the mutiny at Meerut in 1857 are described as the "new" greased version when in fact they were the same ungreased bullets that the sepoys had been using for years. Yet so jaunty is Holmes's tone, so insightful his comments and so colourful, relevant and pithy his quotes that all is quickly forgiven. One of
TThe biggest killer, as always,
was disease1
the fundamental reasons that Britons were prepared to risk untold hardships, disease and death in India, he tells us, was because of the possibility of loot. It persuaded some men to join up in the first place, and "gave most soldiers a personal stake in the successful outcome of a campaign". Some of the statistics are shocking: the mortality rate

for soldiers in Indian garrisons in 1852 was, at 58 per 1,000, far higher than in the worst British slums (drink was a big factor, with one regiment, in 1833, consuming almost 6,000 gallons of spirits). Their superiors fared little better: between 1760 and 1834 only a tenth of officers reached retirement age. Nor were British children always safe. Ofthe several million who went out to India during British rule — so many, Vyvyen Brendon tells us in Children of the Raj, that "almost every family in the country has some Indian connection" — tens of thousands did not come back. The biggest killer, as always, was disease, but hazards included floods, earthquakes, snakes and war. The most brutal conflict was the Indian Mutiny of 1857 when, Brendon explains, the rebels targeted their rulers' offspring. She does not say as
much, but the reason for this policy of extermination was that it tarred all members of a mutinous regiment with the same brush and gave them nothing to lose by rebelling. Famously many British children were saved by loyal servants and the debt was repaid, at least in part, in 1947 when Britons hid retainers during the communal bloodshed between Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs. Most child casualties were infants: partly because they were weaker, and partly because most children over the age of 7 were educated in Britain. This could mean being separated from their parents for many years, and one of Brendon's chief preoccupations is to assess the psychological impact of such abandonment. She cites an academic study which concludes that many children of the Raj developed "a detached character as a defence against the fear of rejection", making it harder for
ing relationships. While her own interviewees do not conform to such a "bleak picture", a minority agree that their insecure childhoods have led to later "trouble with relationships". The flip side, says Brendon, is that the long British tradition of sending children away from their parents has helped to form the type of self-reliant, gritty national character that proved so useful in both world wars. Whether all those poor abandoned children of the Raj would feel the sacrifice was worth it is another matter. Famously many British children were saved by loyal servants and the debt was repaid, at least in part, in 1947 when Britons hid retainers during the communal bloodshed between Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs. Most child casualties were infants partly because they were weaker, and partly because most children over the age of 7 were educated in Britain. This could mean being separated from their parents for many years, and one of Brendons chief preoccupations is to assess the psychological impact of such abandonment. She cites an academic study which concludes that many children of the Raj developed a detached character as a form against the fear of rejection, making it harder for ing relationships. While her own interviewees do not conform to such a bleak picture, a minority agree that their insecure childhoods have led to later trouble with relationships. The flip side, says Brendon, is that the long British tradition of sending children away from their parents has helped to form the type of self- reliant, gritty national character that proved so useful in both world wars. Whether all those poor abandoned children of the Raj would feel the sacrifice was worth it is another matter. Author: Reynolds, Margaret
Title: Will you still read them tomorrow?
Full_text:
Up front Books
you still read them tomorrow?
Margaret Reynolds examines the choices of a poll to find 'future classics'
WHAT MAKES A "CLASSIC"? For me, it's a book that transcends its own time and context to speak to the anxieties of a different time and context. From next week I'll be writing about a different "classic" every week and I'll be asking that question: why should we still read this? What is it about One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest or The Divine Comedy that keeps them on our bookshelves, in our classrooms, open in our hands? The publishing imprint Vintage has been asking the same question — or a very similar one. To celebrate its fifteenth birthday next month Vintage has asked 500 readers from 48 reading groups across the country to nominate 15 of their titles as "future classics". Not their favourite book, not their marking-an-epoch-in-mylifetime book, not the book they most wish they had read if they were the person they wanted to be. Instead, readers were asked to think about what makes a classic, and to predict which titles will become classics. To start everyone off, Vintage sent the reading groups a longlist of 100 titles from its present catalogue. All the names are here, from Kingsley Amis to Toni Morrison. Some of the older books on the list are, arguably, already considered classics — To Kill a Mockingbird, for instance — but others, like Captain Corelli's Mandolin, are in the "future" category of books that are too young to have classic status, but might conceivably still be read and studied a hundred years from now. As Vintage acknowledges, and as I will show in my column, a book doesn't have to be huge and ancient to be a classic. The shortlist of 15, announced today, is telling. It is a very intellectual list — don't look for any light summer reads here unless you are prepared to take your dictionary and your brain to the beach. Which is not to say that these books are not enjoyable. There's plenty to laugh at even in the dystopian Brave New World. There's plenty to weep over in All Quiet on the Western Front and Birdsong. It's also a wideranging list, with books in translation and books set in Europe, America and the Far East. A clear set of themes comes out of the list. There are a number of books about war (Captain Corelli, Catch-22) — partly because we are all still coming to terms with the events of the past century. There are books that
fVe have become sophisticated readers, but wary too1
deal with memory and its inconvenient slipperiness (The Time Traveler's Wife, Memoirs ofa Geisha). There are books about justice and injustice (To Kill a Mockingbird), about political exploitation (One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich), about change and loss (The Star of the Sea) and about hidden histories (The Name of the Rose). Over and again the question of point of view and testimony appears — in, for instance, Atonement or The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time or The French Lieutenant's Woman. Other key topics include: chance, mystery, time, identity, the child's-eye view, the failure — and the consolation — of love. One thing in particular stands out. All of these books are about storytelling — about how the story gets told, and by whom. In the early 21st century instant communication, rolling news, soap opera, propaganda and political spin have made us sophisticated readers of both truth and fiction. Sophisticated and wary. We have long been threatened with the demise of the book. But, as this list shows — just now, with so many interests competing to tell us their story their way — we need books about storytelling to help us learn how to read between the lines to get at the truth. Any book that can offer us a glimpse of that truth — across the boundaries of time and place — can justly be called a classic.

Title: The Mighty Wolitzer

The Mighty Wolitzer
It's funny, wise and full of the richness and sadness of family life. What more does a girl have to do to write a Really Important Novel, asks Erica Wagner

Roz and Paul (perhaps unsurprisingly) divorce, sundered, in part — though not as you'd expect — by success. Holly, the eldest, caroms /" J Everyone — and I mean the real everyone, not the pundits — should read it this summer. If only — at least — because by now you must be dying to find out exactly what Electric Forgiveness is.... THE POSITION by Meg Wolitzer THE POSITION IN QUESTION is called Electric Forgiveness. It is, we are assured, "a wonderful way to achieve climax quickly and lovingly after a scene of anger or stress". It is offered up wholeheartedly to an eager public by Paul and Roz Mellow, who find themselves, in 1975, the bestselling authors of a groundbreaking sex manual called Pleasuring: One Couple's Journey to Fulfilment. Aside from examining their most intimate encounters in this very public way — made even more public by the graphic line drawings, unmistakably of Paul and Roz themselves, that accompany the text—the Mellows are a pretty ordinary couple. They have four kids: Holly, Michael, Dashiell and Claudia. They live in a big, comfortable house just outside New York City. Then they become avatars of the sexual revolution, and, as Meg Wolitzer's hilarious, humane and wonderfully serious novel relates, everything changes. Every so often a novel comes along that Everyone decides is an Important Novel. These Important Novels are meant to tell us something about the human condition, about our times, our mores, the
culture. Certainly: for that's what all novels try to do, though in general the best ones don't set out, self-consciously, to do it. Who is Everyone? You know: the usual cabal of critics, publishers and booksellers. These books, the Important Ones, usually have two things in common. The first is that they are, almost always, by Americans. What is it about Americans and their monopoly on state of the nation/soul? Roth, Updike, Bellow, Irving, Franzen, Eugenides: those are the boys who can tell us where it's at. Over on these shores there's a kind of desperate scrabble to find a British novelist who addresses, with equal (perceived) grandeur, "large themes": the laurel seems to have fallen, by default, on the brow of Ian McEwan, though his recent sanctimonious books are, alas, far less worthy of his readers' attention than his earlier, edgier works. The second thing they have in common is... well, you'll note that I wrote "those are the boys". Important Novels? Those would be by men, then. I'm sorry. In the main I like to think I believe in the level playingfield, but sometimes I despair. I know: we've had all this with the Orange Prize — the big literary award that only girls can win. Is this fair, goes the argument. Where's the prize for men? The answer comes: men do just fine, thanks, and anyhow all prizes have to make some sort of category selection. Is there a difference between "women" (the Orange) and "British and Commonwealth writers" (Man Booker)? Recently we've read that it's women who increasingly dominate the bestseller lists (hello, Jo
which it would be difficult to offer concrete proof. All I can say is: I've been around, it's not my inclination to think this way... and still, I find myself thinking along these lines. Perhaps it was reading Meg Wolitzer's last novel, The Wife, that put me in this frame of mind. The Wife is the story of a woman who, in the 1950s, sacrificed her own literary ambitions to serve those of her husband, who duly became ... see above, A Great American Novelist, in Wolitzer's hands a funny, chippy, Mailer/Roth composite. Things, it turns out, are not quite what they seem: along the way, Wolitzer's understanding both of human relationships and literary machinations illuminate her tale. The Wife was a terrific novel; but The Position is an even better one. Its 300 pages race by; and yet it's a book that in some ways seems more capacious than it is, so full is it of the richness, humour and sadness of family and marital life. The Mellows' children — aged,
TThis is and isn't a book about sex. Sex is a metaphor*
in 1975, between 6 and 15 — find the book, of course, and their feelings, or at least some of them, may be imagined. What would you think if those were your parents in The Joy of Sex, the tome on which Pleasuring is clearly based? Exactly. Wolitzer tracks back and forth h lif hild
off into a lost world of drugs, drink and near-homelessness, Before opting for the even more far-removed environment of middle-class marriage to a doctor in LA. Michael is a software genius whose run-in with antidepressants has left him impotent; Dashiell is gay, which is fine, but he's also — horror of horrors! — a Republican. Claudia is — well, Claudia doesn't really know, and her character is one of the novel's most endearing. The mechanism of the novel is a publisher's desire to reprint Pleasuring for its 30th anniversary; this has the effect of bringing the family together. This is and isn't a book about sex. Sex is a metaphor, a motor; it can drive us and it can cost us dear. It can be communication and silence. Wolitzer, with wit and sensitivity, reminds her readers of its price, pain, and joy. Her characters are absolutely real and true: they come right off the page and speak to us, somehow, about our own lives while remaining, always, precisely themselves. This is no small gift in a novelist. This is one of the best and most human books I've read all year. Yet I found myself thinking that because its author fits into one of the categories I mentioned above (American) but not, crucially, the other (boy), it might not get, on either side of the Atlantic, quite the notice it deserves. I'm not saying it won't be praised; but that's different from being heralded as Important. But as women have for so long, perhaps Wolitzer will remind herself that power often operates most effectively by stealth, and will trust that in the end, no one could possibly see this as a "girl's book".

Author: whittell, giles
Title: A Russian's revolution
Full_text:
Books Grime pays
A Russian's
Boris Akunin is a sensation. He has created a popular hero to equal Sherlock Holmes and James Bond in his bestselling whodunnits. Giles Whittell met him
A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO the Ukrainian mafia, broadly defined, paid Boris Akunin an elaborate compliment. It produced a book bearing his name. He didn't write a word of it, but someone did, by all accounts extremely badly. It has sold a few thousand copies and put Akunin in illustrious company: the Kievan mqb is also doing a brisk trade in something called The Last Merovingian, "by" Dan (da Vinci) Brown. Akunin relates this story indulgently, as well he might. Any damage being done to his reputation by Ukrainian conmeri will be easily outweighed by the English publication of The Death of Achilles, the fourth translated Volume in a series starring a foppish but tungsten-tipped tsarist detective who has already made Akunin rich, envied, happy and free to roam the real world in as much style as he used to roam the literary one. For those who haven't heard of this prodigiously productive pioneer of period post-Soviet crime fiction, a little background: he wrote his first novel, in six weeks flat, in 1998. He has since produced ten more in one series, four in two others and three in a fourth, the latter all written on a three-month P&O cruise last year, He writes in a blur of speed: two hours a day, after which he reckons to have ten typewritten pages ready for his publisher. He then reads (strictly nonfiction), drinks with friends and plays computer games. Akunin's finest creation and the star of his first 11 titles is Erast Fandoriri — genius, gentleman, polyglot, kickboxer and all-round inordinately lucky bloke. In Russia, three Fahdorin books have been made into films so far and two of them into television series as well. Outside Russia, Fandorin is coming sooner or later to a screen near you; Paul Verhoeven, who directed the notorious Basic Instinct, has the rights. Whatever you make of his writing, Akunin (real name: Grigory Chkartashvili) is a phenomenon; the only Russian writer to reach a mass audience abroad as well as domestically since the Soviet collapse. Each of his three titles already out in English (The Winter Queen Murder on the Leviathan and Turkish Gambit) has sold more than 50,000 copies in the UK alone In Russia, meanwhile, he has shifted more than 10 million books in seven years, and his success there says much about his perspicacity but even more about his country. It was all minutely planned on a premise that the new Russia has produced a new type of Russian who craves a hew type of reading. That's the perspicacity bit. And then the premise turned out to be correct. The middle class emerging from perestroika and the Yeltsin mess had Tolstoy and Dostoevsky on the one hand and pulp fiction on the other, but nothing in between. "In Russia nowadays the middle class is the revolutionary class," Akuniyi says. "It did not exist before It's very energetic very active arid
in need of everything a class needs, like ideology, ethics, aesthetics and, well, easy reading." He's 49, married without kids, and looks in profile like a slimline, youthful Alfred Hitchcock. He talks quietly, with the fluency and concision of someone who's had time to organise what's in his head. We meet not in Moscow, where he lives, but in London, where he has been driven nuts all morning by a demolition crew bringing down an office block next to his corporate apartmerit near St Paul's. He peers round a blind and mutters that he "never thought British workmen could be so industrious". Not that he has any such illusions about his fellow writers. Not any more. When he identified the gap in the Russian book market that he has since filled, it was the mid-1990s. He wasan intellectual, supplementing a laughable wage as a literary editor by translating foreign fiction into Russian at ten pages an hour. Loath to sully his own keyboard with the breathless whodunnits he had in mind, he asked his mates to give them a try. "They were talented writers, poets, critics, and at first I simply wanted to organise them to write this sort of fiction... But these Russian writers, they are so lazy." So he offered to construct their plots for them. Still nb takers. "After a while I'd had enough and decided to set an example, to write
^HeVnot very sure of himself, he doesnft always win*.
just one novel in the style that I mean, and that is how the first one appeared." Russia has plenty of crime and crime writers, but no one had come up with anything like the Holmes-Bond^Oblonsky mix that is Fandorin. Akunin thinks this is because his creation embodies so much that modern Russians aren't. He's "understated, dignified, reserved". He's also the straight-up action hero whom Akunin never found in his own voracious reading of the Russian classics as a boy, unable to pick the wrong pistol in a dud arid so spiffing at martial arts (picked up on a six-year attachment to the Russian Embassy in Tokyo from which he returns at the beginning of The Death of Achilles) that he can do back-flips off the ceiling and whack you in the back of the neck on his way down. Yet Fandorin is still Russian, "He is not very sure of himself. He's reflective. He doesn't always win, and when he does, sometimes he regrets it. This is one of the features typical of the Russian intelligentsia that I find attractive." Fandorin's fey look is that of a scion of the von Meek family that befriended Tchaikovsky and built railways for Alexander II. Akunin picked up his portrait in a Moscow flea market.
Russian, un-Russian, whatever. Fandorin caught on, riot just because of who he is but when he operated. No one has revived the tsarist twilight with quite Akunin's energy and affection, which he insists is less for the period than the novels it produced. His books are adazzle with grandeur and grotesqueries borrowed joyfully from the greats, which most of his Russian readers know almost as well as he does. This saves space, he says, not joking. "I just have to draw a few [word] pictures" — of a befurred aristo pulling up outside a snowbound restaurant in the manner of Prince Oblonsky, say — "and my reader knows exactly what sort of person this is. I don't have to spend pages and pages describing his or her life story." It also transports the reader to a unique time between absolutism and the Soviet ice age when Russia was a place of wild schemes and optimism, not just those vast impersonal forces leading to 1917. A smart move simply from the point of view of reader morale, one would have thought. But Akunin also argues that his country was wrestling then with many of the issues that confront it now. It's a serious point and he offers an example in Dostoevksy's clairvoyant passages on modern political terrorism in The Devils. Not long ago, this might have been an attempt by Akunin to suggest some important purpose behind his new life as a bestseller writer. Not now, though. He is unembarrassed and delighted by his success. And somewhat reconciled to having spent the first half of his life trapped in the Soviet Union. "When I was young I felt very sorry for myself that I was born in this awful, boring country," he muses. "Now I think of this rather as a bonus, because growing up in a country like that stimulated your brain. You had to distance yourself from what was surrounding you, and besides, when you live in a quiet country you might live to the end of your life without really understanding what sort of person you are." Ouch? It gets worse. In the West, says the sage from the country with an average male life expectancy of 57, people live till they die of Alzheimer's at 95 "because their heart is strong and they have watched their cholesterol all their life without life ever really testing them". Akunin has some experience of Western gerontocracy. The three volumes he knocked off last year, comprising a mini-series he has called Tiie Genres, sparked accusations in Russian papers that he was getting "literary slaves" (his own phrase) to do some of his work. Not true, he says. He wrote them all in a cabin on Deck 11 of the Aurora cruise liner on a roundthe-world tour from Southampton to Southampton, "The average age of the passengers was about 85,'? he says, "and it was an incredibly boring experience. It was the perfect setting for tik"

In Russia nowadays the middle class is the revolutionary class, Akuniyi says. It did not exist before Its very energetic very active arid in need of everything a class needs, like ideology, ethics, aesthetics and, well, easy reading. Hes 49, married without kids, and looks in profile like a slimline, youthful Alfred Hitchcock. He talks quietly, with the fluency and concision of someone who had time to he whats in his head. We meet not in Moscow, where he lives, but in London, where he has been driven nuts all morning by a demolition crew bringing down an office block next to his corporate in near St Pauls. He peers round a blind and mutters that he never thought British workmen could be so industrious. Not that he has any such illusions about his fellow writers. Not any more. When he identified the gap in the Russian book market that he has since filled, it was the mid- 1990s. He was intellectual, supplementing a laughable wage as a literary editor by translating foreign fiction into Russian at ten pages an hour. Loath to sully his own keyboard with the breathless whodunnits he had in mind, he asked his mates to give them a try. They were talented writers, poets, critics, and at first I simply wanted to find them to write this sort of fiction... But these Russian writers, they are so lazy. So he offered to construct their plots for them. Still nb takers. After a while Id had enough and decided to set an example, to write HeVnot very sure of himself, he would always win. just one novel in the style that I mean, and that is how the first one appeared. Russia has plenty of crime and crime writers, but no one had come up with anything like the Holmes- BondOblonsky mix that is Fandorin. Akunin thinks this is because his creation embodies so much that modern Russians know. Hes understated, dignified, reserved. Hes also the straight- up action hero whom Akunin never found in his own voracious reading of the Russian classics as a boy, unable to pick the wrong pistol in a dud arid so spiffing at martial arts picked up on a six- year attachment to the Russian Embassy in Tokyo from which he returns at the beginning of The Death of Achilles Achilles that he can do back- flips off the ceiling and whack you in the back of the neck on his way down. Yet Fandorin is still Russian, He is not very sure of himself. Hes reflective. He is always win, and when he does, sometimes he regrets it. This is one of the features typical of the Russian intelligentsia that I find attractive. Fandorins fey look is that of a scion of the Russian Meek family that befriended Tchaikovsky and built railways for Alexander II. Akunin picked up his portrait in a Moscow flea market. Russian, Non- Russian, whatever. Fandorin caught on, riot just because of who he is but when he operated. No one has revived the tsarist twilight with quite Akunins energy and affection, which he insists is less for the period than the novels it produced. His books are filled with grandeur and grotesqueries borrowed joyfully from the greats, which most of his Russian readers know almost as well as he does. This saves space, he says, not joking. I just have to draw a few word pictures of a sk and pulling up outside a snowbound restaurant in the manner of Prince Oblonsky, say and my reader knows exactly what sort of person this is. I just have to spend pages and pages describing his or her life story. It also transports the reader to a unique time between absolutism and the Soviet ice age when Russia was a place of wild schemes and optimism, not just those vast impersonal forces leading to 1917. A smart move simply from the point of view of reader morale, one would have thought. But Akunin also argues that his country was wrestling then with many of the issues that confront it now. Its a serious point and he offers an example in Dostoevksys clairvoyant passages on modern political terrorism in The Devils. Not long ago, this might have been an attempt by Akunin to suggest some important purpose behind his new life as a bestseller writer. Not now, though. He is unembarrassed and delighted by his success. And somewhat reconciled to having spent the first half of his life trapped in the Soviet Union. When I was young I felt very sorry for myself that I was born in this awful, boring country, he muses. Now I think of this rather as a bonus, because growing up in a country like that stimulated your brain. You had to distance yourself from what was surrounding you, and besides, when you live in a quiet country you might live to the end of your life without really understanding what sort of person you are. Ouch? It gets worse. In the West, says the sage from the country with an average male life expectancy of 57, people live till they die of Alzheimers at 95 because their heart is strong and they have watched their cholesterol all their life without life ever really testing them. Akunin has some experience of Western gerontocracy. The three volumes he knocked off last year, comprising a mini-series he he has called Tiie Genres, sparked accusations in Russian papers that he was getting literary slaves his own phrase to do some of his work. Not true, he says. He wrote them all in a cabin on Deck 11 of the Aurora cruise liner on a on- world tour from Southampton to Southampton, The average age of the passengers was about 85,? he says, and it was an incredibly boring experience. It was the perfect setting for the See critics chart, page 19

has returned.to the 18th-century setting of an earlier bestseller, Chatterton. , Mingling fact and fiction to entirely plausible effect, The Lambs of London is set in the mid-1790s, when Charles Lamb, then a few years into what was to be a 30-year career at the East India Company, was recovering from a nervous breakdown. Nursing him was his beloved sister, Mary — herself on the verge of the fit of insanity that was td cause her, a year or two later, to murder their mother. Among the other characters who people this vividly realised world is the antiquarian bookseller and sometime forger William Ireland. The platonic but intense romance between the latter and Mary Lamb is the focus of the story, which ends — as, indeed, does the love affair — when Ireland is unmasked as a fraud and Mary, distracted by grief, commits the terrible crime for which she remains notorious. The author's re-creation of these events is masterly. His feeling for the language of his chosen period is as sharp as one has come to expect. But it is in the realisation of the characters — poor, troubled Mary and her dipsomaniac sibling; gifted, over-reaching Ireland, and a host of others — that Ackroyd excels. Tender, funny and humane, this is as good as anything he has written.
THE LAMBS OF LONDON by Peter Ackroyd Vintage, £6.99 El £6.64 (free p&p) Ackroyd's wonderful novel continues what seems to have become a lifetime's exploration of London's past. After Clerkenwell Tales, which was set in medieval London, he

p Head-hunted by PopCo, a multinational toy company, she is at first enthusiastic about her job, devising problem-solving games for nine-year-olds, which enables her to reconnect with her own unconventional childhood. But then she is asked to participate in a top-secret project aimed at teenage girls. Gradually, she starts to understand the insidious nature of PopCo's marketing strategy, and to realise that she no longer wants to be part of it. While some interesting points are made about the way that children have been inveigled by big business into becoming avid consumers, the novel is more than just a timely anti-capitalist rant. Full of cryptograms, digressions on treasure hunting, the politics of vegetarianism, and code-breaking lore, it offers much more subtle pleasures. The best thing, in fact, is the character of Alice — a self-confessed "geek" with a fondness for mathematical theorems, homoeopathy, and stylishly unstylish clothes. Brought up to prefer books to television, and ideas to fashion, she feels like an outsider in a materialist world. Like an escaper from an Iris Murdoch novel unaccountably caught up in a Douglas Coupland plot, it is she who keeps the reader reading on when the worthy rhetoric begins to pall.
POPCO by Scarlett Thomas HarperPerennial, £7.99 El £7.59 (free p&p) Thomas's enjoyably cultish novel on the evils of globalisation is narrated by Alice, the descendant of Bletchley Park code-breakers and a professional setter of crossword puzzles.

and overall generosity of outlook, it is in much the same vein as Jewell's bestselling debut, Ralph's Party. Here, as in her earlier books, the ups and downs of relationships are dissected, and the improbability of true love ever running smooth is wryly pointed up. When 19-year-old Vince meets shy, beautiful Joy on a Norfolk campsite, it seems as if his problems with girls are over. But then the couple are separated by one of those misunderstandings so common in this kind of fiction, and don't meet again until years later, by which time both are on the verge of getting married to someone else. Nor is this the end of their troubles. A possessive husband, an ill-timed pregnancy and a certain mutual inertia seem likely to keep them apart indefinitely. Fortunately, help is at hand in the form of a psychic cat... ' Like all romantic comedies, Vince & Joy has its predictable side — but that doesn't mean that it lacks suspense. The skill with which the author delays the inevitable moment when the two main characters get together keeps the reader guessing as to the outcome right up to the end. And there are some well-observed vignettes of contemporary urban life, as well as a quartet of loveably eccentric flatmates to add zest to the mix.

What's up? A team of friends zapped by cosmic rays during a space mission return to Earth with special powers — elasticity, invisibility and force fields, bursting into flames (without burning up) and incredible strength as an orange monster. What's familiar? If there's a comic-book movie in the multiplexes, then it must be summer. Stan Lee's Marvel Comics creations from the 1960s featured in several animated TV series and in an unreleased 1994 movie. And can we take this family of superheroes seriously after The Jncredihfes sent them up? Fun for? A PG-rated audience, though very little ones may find a flaming man a little bit scary. Critics' view "It reduces its power-packed heroes to figures of innocuous low comedy, turning their 'normal' selves into soapropera ciphers." (Entertainment Weekly). Yet despite a critical drubbing from US critics, the film earned nearly $60 million in its opening weekend in the United States. In cinemas July 22.

Author: Craig, Amanda
Title: Children's History Books
Full_text:
review books
CHILDREN'S HISTORY BOOKS AMANDA CRAIG
L§m£J$mm*rLjfii4:i%i ■ M t"jV:
Embattled as we are by the unintelligent prescriptions of the national curriculum, we desperately need good history books. Yet while nonfiction is storming ahead with series such as Terry Deary's Horrible Histories, historical fiction has never regained the heights it achieved in the 1960s when books by Geoffrey Trease, Roger Lancelyn Green and Rosemary Sutcliffe made us all history boys and girls. One writer who is helping to fill the gap is Caroline Lawrence, whose Roman Mysteries series deserves its devoted following. The Colossus of Rhodes takes our quartet of multicultural detectives out of the city and across the sea towards Greece, into danger at the hands of a brutal slave-dealer. Though its dialogue lacks subtlety, it compensates with a lively, detailed knowledge of classical history. Eleanor Updale's burglarturned-gentleman, Montmorency, is now middleaged, and anxious for the safety of his friendls nephew, Frank. The rise of both trade
its pases c&mmi A MYSTERIOUS corse, a mmm of SENET AND tmm INFORgvUTION
unionism and the Mafia in Italy, England and America put the young aristocrat at the heart of a conspiracy in Montmorency and the Assassins, and he has to use every scrap of acting ability leamt from our hero to survive. A complex and satisfying thriller, its enjoyable features include advances in Victorian radiology, and the intertwining of real-life people such as Edison and Puccini with a fictional cast. There is even more derring-do with Michael Molloy's Peter Raven Under Fire, a Hornblower for youngsters that will make them experts on Napoleonic naval techniques in the wake of a terrific, rip-roaring adventure about slaves, piracy and the Caribbean. K. M. Grant's Green Jasper, the sequel to her excellent debut, Blood Red Horse, is set in the time of Richard the Lionheart. The crusades feature heavily in Key Stage 3 history, and this swashbuckling , romance about a kidnapped bride and a noble horse loved by both Christian and Muslim is a romping read.
For students of the Victorian era, Dorothy Edwards's A Strong and Willing Girl is also captivating It is based on her aunt's experiences of being in service as a 10-year-old in 1887, and displays an artless authenticity that charms. Of nonfiction books, Paul Dowswell's Introduction to the Second World War, written under the auspices of the Imperial War Museum, is superb. It lays out information in clear, vivid paragraphs, lavishly illustrated by dramatic, period photographs. The Battle of Britain, the defeat of Japan and the role of the Resistance are covered in detail, and the book offers recommendations for film and TV, plus valuable links to the internet Highly recommended. Book House has had the inspired idea of turning the lives of great leaders into graphic novels. Each has four pages of biographical overview, then plunges into Marvel comic-style action accounts of the lives of such figures as Queen Elizabeth I, Alexander, Julius Caesar, Hernan Cortes and Spartacus, with battles and murder looming large. It isn't Art Spiegelman, but an amazing amount of information is packed into this dramatic format, which will persuade reluctant junior historians to keep reading. The most enchanting history book of all, however, is Egyptology. Purporting to be the diaries of Miss Emily Sands, an archaeologist iri 1926, its pages contain a mysterious curse, a game of senet, fabulous foldouts and much information. The burnished gold cover, with its jewelled Horus, enthrals children even before they open it and fall in love with the past — which is what all history books should make us do, but seldom manage. The Colossus of Rhodes (9+) by Caroline Lawrence (Orion, £8.99; offer £7.64, call 0870 1608080). Montmorency and the Assass/ns (10+) by Eleanor Updale (Scholastic, £12.99; offer £10.39). Peter Raven Under Fire (10+) by Michael Molloy (Chicken House, £12.99; offer £10.39). Green Jasper (10+) by K. M. Grant (Puffin, £4.99; offer £4.24). A Strong and Willing Girl (9+) by Dorothy Edwards (Jane Nissen, £6.99; offer £5.94). Introduction to the Second Wor/d War (11+) by Paul Dowswell (Usborne, £12.99; offer £1039). The rise of both trade its and and A MYSTERIOUS corse, a part of SENET AND the INFORgvUTION unionism and the Mafia in Italy, England and America put the young aristocrat at the heart of a conspiracy in Montmorency and the Assassins, and he has to use every scrap of acting ability is from our hero to survive. A complex and satisfying thriller, its enjoyable features include advances in Victorian radiology, and the intertwining of real- life people such as Edison and Puccini with a fictional cast. There is even more and- do with Michael Molloys Peter Raven Under Fire, a Hornblower for youngsters that will make them experts on Napoleonic naval techniques in the wake of a terrific, rip- roaring adventure about slaves, piracy and the Caribbean. K. M. Grants Green Jasper, the sequel to her excellent debut, Blood Red Horse, is set in the time of Richard the Lionheart. The crusades feature heavily in Key Stage 3 history, and this swashbuckling, romance about a kidnapped bride and a noble horse loved by both Christian and Muslim is a romping read. For students of the Victorian era, Dorothy Edwardss A Strong and Willing Girl is also captivating It is based on her aunts experiences of being in service as a 10- year- old in 1887, and displays an artless authenticity artless authenticity that charms. Of nonfiction books, Paul Dowswells Introduction to the Second World War, written under the auspices of the Imperial War Museum, is superb. It lays out information in clear, vivid paragraphs, lavishly illustrated by dramatic, period photographs. The Battle of Britain, the defeat of Japan and the role of the Resistance are covered in detail, and the book offers recommendations for film and TV, plus valuable links to the internet Highly recommended. Book House has had the inspired idea of turning the lives of great leaders into graphic novels. Each has four pages of biographical overview, then plunges into Marvel comic- style action accounts of the lives of such figures as Queen Elizabeth I, Alexander, Julius Caesar, Hernan Cortes and Spartacus, with battles and murder looming large. It is Art Spiegelman, but an amazing amount of information is packed into this dramatic format, which will persuade reluctant junior historians to keep reading. The most enchanting history book of all, however, is Egyptology. Purporting to be the diaries of Miss Emily Sands, an archaeologist of 1926, its pages contain a mysterious curse, a game of all, fabulous foldouts and much information. The burnished gold cover, with its jewelled Horus, enthrals children even before they open it and fall in love with the past which is what all history books should make us do, but seldom manage. Title: 20 Inspiring Reads Week 7

20 INSPIRING READS WEEK 7
The Queen's Fool by Philippa Gregory
99p when you buy The Times, The Sunday Times or The Times Educational Supplement from WHSmlth next week Into a Tudor court on the brink of treason comes Hannah, a young Jewish girl on the run from the Inquisition. Sworn into the service of handsome Robert Dudley, she is sent as a Holy Fool to spy on Princess Mary Tudor, the forgotten heir to King Edward's throne. Instead of the tyrant of popular legend, Hannah finds a woman waiting for her chance and only wanting the best for the kingdom — while her sister Elizabeth longs for her death. Caught in the enmity between the rival daughters of Henry VIII and torn between her infatuation with Dudley and duty to her family, Hannah must find a safe path through a dangerous time. Philippa Gregory is the bestselling author of many novels, including The Other Boleyn Girl, which was adapted into a BBC drama in 2004. Here is an edited extract from The Queen's Fool: "The girl, giggling and over-excited, was running in the sunlit garden, running away from her stepfather, but not so fast that he could not catch her. Her stepmother, seated in an arbour with Rosamund roses in bud all around her, caught sight of the fourteen-year-old girl and the handsome man chasing around the broad tree trunks on the smooth turf and smiled, determined to see only the best in both of them. "He snatched at the hem of the girl's swinging gown and caught her up to him for a moment 'A forfeit!' he said, his dark face close to her flushed cheeks. They both knew what the forfeit would be. Author: Sutherland Bayley, John Stephen
Title: Bird with a brain

review books
Bird with a brain
The Penguin paperback, offering high culture at low cost, is 70 this month. John Sutherland and Stephen Bayley mark a proud chapter
It is, wrote Sir Stanley Unwin, easy to become a publisher, but devilish hard to remain one. Unwin was among the minority who managed to hang on and collect their publishing knighthood. So, even more successfully, was Sir Allen Lane, the founder of the Penguin empire. Penguin (now a segment of the Longman Pearson combine) celebrates its 70th year this month. Fruit-fly stuff compared with the Methuselahs of the trade, Cambridge and Oxford university presses, with their five centuries of trading. But in its three score and ten the cheeky Penguin has achieved more for the uplift ofthe British mind than even the leviathans of Oxbridge. When he retired in 1964, E.V. Rieu (the chief editor of Penguin Classics) hailed his list — headed by his own bestselling translation of TTie Odyssey — as "the greatest educative force of the 20th century". It was
not hype. Penguin's achievement was the more impressive in that Lane himself was no intellectual — there are probably penguins on the ice-floes of Antarctica better read than he. One of his colleagues doubted
gd if he'd ever read a book cover to cover. But he was, as Jeremy Lewis describes in The Life and Times of Allen Lane, "shrewd" and, if he didn't do Homer, he could "read the spirit ofthe age". In 1935 Lane saw what the age needed: good books, cheap books and lots of books. After spending a weekend visiting Agatha Christie, and urged on by his wife, the young publisher launched his pioneer batch of Penguins, including one by Christie, at a tanner apiece, in the "3d and 6d" emporium, Woolworths.

Thereafter it was up all the way — until, that is, last year when the firm's woes made headlines in the financial pages. Suddenly, it seemed, the Penguin was an endangered species. Heads rolled, takeovers were rumoured. Clouds gathered over 80 Strand. Typically, Penguin's recent problems arise from its attempting a daring leap forward — a new, high-tech warehousing system which, as such things do, went phut. That, and the strength of sterling (in an industry which exports about 40 per cent of its products) has rather scooped the icing off the birthday cake. Penguin has always taken chances; never stood still. There were, for example, the batch publications of classic authors — ten volumes of Shaw, Wells, Lawrence, slamming into the bookshops. There were any number of spun-off imprints with quaint ornithological names,
passed. He delegated command to editors of genius. He bureaucratised publishing. It was Penguin which (ironically) pioneered modernised warehousing at Harmondsworth, west of London, in the 1950s. That vast bookbarn gave them the volume capacity to feed the "paperback revolution". It was Penguin that redefined "permissibility" by daring to publish Lady Chatterley's Lover in 1960. When the list looked stuffy in the 1970s they imported an American whiz-kid, Peter Mayer, to shake them up. They
from Puffins (Penguins for juniors), through Pelicans (Penguins for egg-heads) to Peregrines (Penguins for students). Only the tiny peewit remains un-Penguined. Lane realised that the days of the "dynastic" house (with its trailing "and sons") had
forged a trendsetting Anglo-American alliance with Viking. Think of a smart move in publishing and Penguin got there first. Above all, its product was superb. It published only the best books, new and reprint. The Penguin imprint gave you hardback quality at paperback price (the price of 20 cigarettes was Lane's rule of thumb — it still holds, almost). Staying at the top is hard. Competitors are always seeking to beat you at your own game. The reading public is fickle. Over the decades Penguin has never adulterated its product, but it has lost the supremacy it once enjoyed. Bookshops no longer have their "Penguin section". It used to be that Penguin meant paperback. Now itjust means one brand of paperback. To commemorate this anniversary year the firm is making a determined effort to regain its former brand supremacy. Its strategy is what it has traditionally been: carpet-bombing the market with quality books. Over recent months we have had a blockbuster batch of ten volumes by H. G. Wells, in special dump-bins, and the new Penguin Classics livery — blood red and Belgian chocolate dark. It will get a collateral boost from Spielberg's War of fhe Worlds later this year. More ambitious are two series, intended to retake the intellectual and cultural high ground that Penguin has always seen as its own. The first is the "Great Ideas" series, with 20 titles ranging from Seneca's On The Shortness of Life (read it, you publishers) to The Communist Manifesto, to Woolf, Freud and Orwell. The other series is 70 "Pocket Penguins" with a line-up that resembles the Sergeant Pepper cover. Here comes everybody, from Homer (in the cave of the Cyclops), to Kafka (at The
<NEWPAGE>
Great Wall of China), to India Knight (shopping in Selfridges) and Jamie Oliver (cooking for the weekend). The books are beautiful to look at and lovely to hold. The design of the Great Ideas titles harks back to the austerely handsome typographical jacket that Lane preferred. That ofthe Pocket Penguins has the jazziness that one associates with the most brilliant of Lane's editors, Tony Godwin. As a mark of confidence that great books speak for themselves, there is no apparatus. One thing marks these series out from the Penguin of yore. They are short on words. At 54 pages of text, the Pocket titles represent an hour's unstrenuous reading. Nor are Great Ideas, at 100 pages, greatly strenuous. In most cases, what the editors have done is fillet a sample taster. Thus Gibbon's massive The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire is represented by a snippet on The Christians and the Fall of Rome. These are not books; they are booklets. But they are in keeping with "the spirit ofthe age" — our age. Penguin, innovative as ever, is tabloidising book publishing. Of course, people will still read big books — even The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. And they will find those big books in the Penguin catalogue. But in between the main events, the modern reader wants fast reads that stretch the mind, not fill it. What to call these latest Penguins? How about Peewits. JS versities, but I learnt more from Penguin than A COVER STORY Three shillings and sixpence. Britain's coinage went decimal only in 1971 and, for anybody at school before then, 17.5p was the price of entry into a well-designed world of modern novels, need-to-know classics, literate crime, serious history and real poetry. Three shillings and sixpence bought access to great writing and great ideas and, incidentally, a teach-yourself guide to the best in contemporary graphics as well. This was what you paid for a Penguin paperback. I went to a good school and two good unifrom any teacher or lecturer. After all, I had my own library. Appropriately, in this context, it was the Penguin edition of Sartre's Nausea that taught me what "autodidact" meant. Looking at a bookstore in 2005 with its ziggurats of .profligate, foil-blocked, shrink-wrapped "product" piled high in a polychrome clamour
of sensational claims and seductive offers, it is hard to recall what that retail landscape looked like 40 years ago. Outside London or the big university towns, bookshops were rare. You really had only W. H. Smith, in any case more interested in selling stationery and weird-smelling gardening magazines with gravure illustrations than books. It was in suburban Liverpool that I discovered Penguin when I precociously bought the new edition of Nikolaus Pevsner's Pioneers of Modern Design in the same year that I had cannily bought the last edition of The Times with classifieds on its front page. A habit was formed. I haunted Smiths, wait¬
ing for each month's batch of new Penguins, which duly arrived, high-concept capsules of style and writing, to release me from a dingy environment and arrange internal transport to Graham Greene's Cuba or Andrew Marvell's garden. Bright kids in the late Sixties also learnt from The Sunday Times Magazine (where Mark Boxer was editor) and from BBC2's Late Night Line-Up (where Joan Bakewell was the thinking man's English muffin), but they learnt most of all from Penguin Books. Allen Lane did not invent the paperback, but he did realise its potential. Paperbacks had hitherto been cheap or inferior. Lane saw them as something in their own right, a consumer product that needed to be packaged, branded, promoted and distributed as professionally as soap. Design could help. And 1935, when the first
< a, o x v- PKXi ARIEL ANDRE MAU ROIS -< X o o
Penguin appeared, was just the moment that that quintessential media professional, the graphic designer, was emerging as an autonomous, stylish creative figure from the anonymity of the print trade with its hot metal, warehouse coats, glue and cloth bindings. The first ten Penguins (Maurois's Ariel was the actual number one) were designed in-house and were distinguished enough with their tripartite grid, agreeable proportions and strong Gill Sans type (Times New Roman for body copy). But Lane was ever more ambitious. He failed to lure Oliver Simon from the Curwen Press, so travelled, instead, to Switzerland, the scriptural home of modern typography. Here he found Jan Tschichold, the son of a Leipzig signwriter. Tschichold's visit to the first Bauhaus exhibition in 1923 inspired a polemical manifesto called Elementare Typographic that same year. Three years later, Tschichold published Die neue Typographic, a persuasive, instructive and authoritative account ofthe benefits of uncluttered book design. In 1947 Tschichold joined Penguin and brought the Bauhaus to the British bookstore, transforming national taste with his strict grids, severe typography and disciplined layouts as much as Allen Lane transformed national literacy with Penguin's ever expanding, easily accessible list of established classics and imaginative commissioning. Penguin succeeded because, without being patronising or condescending, it flattered the consumer. It is one ofthe most compelling case studies in the effectiveness of design in the service of sales. Thirty years before Terence Conran's Habitat showed that British consumers would buy decent modern furniture if offered it, Allen Lane had established the principle with books. And after Tschichold's stern typography there were other influences. In 1960 a protean Italian called Germano Fagetti was appointed creative director and Penguin became a design academy. Anybody with a run of Penguins from the Sixties and Seventies has a collection of cover art that is the history of graphics in miniature. Alex Comfort's Sex in Society (1964) had a cover by Jock Kinneir, who designed Britain's motorway signs. Updike's Rabbit Run cover was illustrated by Milton Glaser, who later gave the world the famous Dylan posters and that annoying "I Love NY" motif with a heart icon replacing the L-word. Galbraith's American Capitalism (1970) was by Alan Fletcher, Britain's greatest graphic designer. Even more interesting was the adroit use of historical reference: the Sutton
the year ofthe Skylon, the first volumes in Pevsner's astonishing Buildings ofEngland appeared. The entire Penguin edifice is described in a meticulous and inspiring book. Penguin By Design: A Cover Story 1935-2005 by Phil Baines respects all the Penguin principles. Except one. It costs sixteen pounds nineteen shillings and ninepence-halfpenny. istorical Hoo treasure on the cover of Beowulf (1963) and, unforgettable for me, Richard Hollis's cover of John Berger's Ways of Seeing (1972). Seventy years after the first Penguin, the achievement is honoured next month in an exhibition at the Victoria & Albert Museum. In 1946 (when Penguin published its first classic, a new translation of The Odyssey) the V&A organised an exhibition called "Britain Can Make It". With Penguin, we always want to make connections. 99p when you buy The Times, The Sunday Times or The Times Educational Supplement from WHSmith next week What happened to Flashman, the bully of Tom Brown's Schooldays, after he was expelled from Rugby School in the 1830s? For a century his fate remained a mystery — until in 1965 George MacDonald Fraser decided to discover a collection of manuscripts. Since then the scandalous saga of Flashman, Victorian hero and scoundrel, has emerged in a series of bestselling memoirs in which the arch-cad reviews his exploits in bed and battle. In this first instalment of fie saga, Flashman is r jluctantly employed as a secret agent in Afghanistan. Here is an edited extract from the opening: "Hughes got it wrong, in one important detail. Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: The outsiders
Full_text:
review books
The outsiders
How does a writer achieve cult status? By being Will Self or dreaming up Discworld? Erica Wagner seeks out the stars with exclusive appeal
ALLEN GINSBERG/CORBIS « ^
Tripping: a shirtless Neal Cassady with Timothy Leary, the LSD guru, in Ken Kesey's psychedelic bus in 1964
I called A. L. Kennedy to see how she would define the term "cult fiction". What made a cult author? "Someone with a loyal, slightly flaky following," she offered. "I was defined as cult when they thought that might work, because my fan base is loyal and flaky. You'd hope it meant that certain books were looked after and cherished by readers in the face of public opinion — but more and more that's happening full stop: the idea of reading non-bestselling fiction, the stuff that isn't on Richard and Judy, is becoming a kind of cult in itself." A somewhat despairing take; but one that must be allowed given the impossibility, it seems to me, of any kind of narrow definition. The new Rough Guide to Cult Fiction is just published —we print some examples of quirky writing lives opposite — and causes a reader to ask: just what do they mean? The editors note in an introduction that Toby Litt once said that in their purest form, cult books ought to have been out of print for ten years — and that might be a good way to start. By those lights, though, this is no rough guide: Jonathan Franzen, author of the bestselling, Oprah-impressing The Corrections, a cult author? I wouldn't have thought so, but you'll find him in these pages. A. S. Byatt was as puzzled as I was when I
remarked on Franzen's inclusion. I wondered if (aside from a desire the editors might have felt to put into their book authors at least some people had heard of — though you could argue that defeats the object; OK, we could go around in these circles for ever) there might be some confusion between cool and cult. Franzen: cool, yes; cult, no. Byatt herself doesn't appear in these pages, and yet when she described the behaviour of some of her fans to me there was something cultish to it. There's a woman in California who makes ftirniture based around Possession; another in New York who makes tapestries drawing on all of Byatt's oeuvre. She didn't think that sales were necessarily anything to do with the matter: she considers one of her favourite authors, the bestselling Terry Pratchett, a cult author because readers either adore him or feel completely excluded from his work. When she travels in America and sings his praises, no one has ever heard of him. But aspiring to cult status, she thinks, can be dangerous. She is a great admirer of the novelist Tibor Fischer; but felt worried by her certainty that "he would love to have a cult". Will Self, at least according to the editors ofthis guide, has one: he's included. How does he feel .about that? "I'm happy tp be
included in anything," he says. "I was the boy who wasn't picked for sports at school." According to Self, "cult" is a genre like any other "a kind of sanitised avant-garde". Inquiring after the Rough Guide's standards, Kennedy fired off a series of four names, only one of which met the RG's criteria, whatever they might be. For the record, that was James M. Cain, author of The Postman Always Rings Twice. The others were: Venedikt Yerofeev (the author of Moscow Stations); Boris Vian ("pataphysician, trumpeter, writer and bon vivant," it says on one website), author of I Spit on Your Graves; and Frederick Exley,- American author of A Fan's Notes_ and Pages from a Cold Island. As she noted, the advent of the internet has made seeking out "cult authors" much easier than it used to be. In a sense, each book that speaks strongly to an individual reader creates its own cult: there can be many subcults along the way. A simple "I have heard of him, you haven't" might be a good definition of cult — then nearly anyone can be let into this somehow elite and yet infinitely expandable club.
The Rough Guide to Cult Fiction is published by Rough Guides, £8.99 (off&,t£7&l) on April 28

Author: Wood, Christopher
Title: New Books
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS A guide to the gay world and a memoir on the last hours of Hitler are an eclectic mix for Christopher Wood
THE BENT LENS by Lisa Daniel and Claire Jackson, Roundhouse, £9.99 UNTIL THE FINAL HOUR by Traudl Junge, Phoenix, £7.99 THE 19th London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival wrapped up this week, but for those already itching for the 20th, consolation comes with The Bent Lens, an encyclopaedia of what some critics call "queer cinema". In fact, this new edition of The Bent Lens takes account of a further development: "new queer cinema", whose advent was noted by an ever-alert critical fraternity in 1992. The encyclopaedia's remit is broad, covering both films where sexuality is the central theme and those where it is more tangential. American Beauty is there for its male kiss — although the bits I was awake for suggested that its main argument was something else. And then there are films such as the wonderful American comedy But I'm a Cheerleader, about a holiday camp to which parents send their children for the correction of early signs of homosexuality, where gayness is the core subject of the film.
Going back in time, in movies as in other art forms, coyness, obliqueness or symbolism were unavoidable for the representation of gay themes. In the Sixties, mainstream movies were just about out of the closet, with films such as V7ct/m, The Children's Hour and The Killing of Sister George. But before that, social pressures^ when dealing with the love that dare not speak its name resulted in such bizarre artefacts of high camp as Nicholas Ray's kinky western Johnny Guitar, where Marlboro Country offers something quite different from your average swarthy, cigarette-puffing hero. The Bent Lens also tries to out certain films that I would never have suspected qf harbouring such tendencies — John Ford's The Long Voyage Home for one. A much better candidate would have been Hitchcock's Rebecca, in which Laurence Olivier is camper than a row of tents and Mrs Danvers's feelings for her late mistress are clearly not the usual ones between a housekeeper and her employer. Or maybe they are. Who knows what really goes on in our country houses? Those who have seen the film Downfall, currently doing the rounds, may want to look
at the memoir it is loosely based on, Until the Final Hour by Traudl Junge. She was Adolf Hitler's secretary from November 1942 until her employer shot himself in April 1945, and was present in the bunker in Berlin when he did it. Downfall, despite being in German, will probably reach a wider public, but it is Junge's apparently artless memoir that provides the subtler and more perceptive portrait of the seductiveness of Nazism — written by someone who was herself seduced, and was racked with guilt over it right up to her death in 2002. For one thing it was written in 1947, before reactions to the Nazi experience had been channelled into their prescribed forms. In the film we see Hitler on the edge of reason, twitching, ranting, arbitrarily arresting and appointing, flailing, foundering and foaming. No one could easily be taken in by such a grotesque apology for a human being. The Hitler Junge encountered, however, was a model employer — correct but informal, courteous and gentlemanly. It is as well to remember that the worst people sometimes have the best manners.

My first book a literary adventure
A typescript hidden in a bottom drawer, a cathartic story of a lost sister... five leading writers remember their first faltering step towards a life in letters
FINN CAMPBEIX-NOTMAN I 'U<«4"<& 3ft "^f^3 » 1#. A » tft •«' * w
ANTONY BEEVOR
My first novel, thank God, was never published. The typescript still lies at the bottom of some drawer box, its pages no doubt yellow and impregnated with dust I have not destroyed it because, even though ashamed, I am grateful to it Even the shame is a mixed feeling. I still feel slightly appalled that I could have dared to try to write a novel, having failed both my English
and history A levels at Winchester—a rare distinction which pleased neither parents nor school. Even with the advantage of hindsight, I can do no more than attribute this arbitrary decision to write to the utter ignorance and arrogance of youth. And yet if I had realised for a moment how utterly disqualified I was, life would have been sadly different. Careers can turn out to be such curious, unpredictable creatures, almost with a life of their own. As a child, I had Perthes disease, in which the hip bone goes soft. I was
on crutches between the ages of four and seven, and it was clearly during the subsequent period, when bullied at school, 21^d£^m^St perversity, having refused to work at Winchester, I suddenld df
y started to educate myselfwhen serving with a cavalry regiment in Germany. I did not play polo or race, and there was not much else to do n one's spare time, except to drink or read. Then, after I had finished a long spell commandng a troop of tanks in Germany and back in England, I was sent to North Wales. In dismal surroundings and much less congenial company than with my regiment, I suddenly had the idea of writing a novel. My mother's side of the

family had all been writers, so why not, I thought, with naive optimism. I will not burden you with the plot, except to say that it was about a young cavalry officer. I even thought of calling it The Cavalryman's Tale. The reason I remain grateful to what would otherwise have been a work of embarrassing juvenilia is that it literally changed my life. I thought that I was writing about a fictional character, but then I suddenly recognised myself. I faced the uncomfortable truth that my real reasons for joining the Army had been distinct-
nately, I was still young and innocent enough to think that I would soon be giving up a fill-in day job. Anyway, I was lucky in more ways than one. Most writers probably cringe at the memory of their first novel, but I still have one great advantage. Nobody can stumble across an old copy of mine through the internet Antony Beevor's /atest book fe The Mystery of Olga Chekhova (V/k/ng, £16.99; offer, £13.59)
gy ly unheroic. To put it bluntly, it had all come from a deep physicai inferiority complex 15 years before. It was quite a shock to find I had been living a lie tp myself for well over half my life. But having left the Army, what should I do then? Fortu¬
<NEWPAGE>
DAVID ALMOND
Some folk thought I was mad when I quit my teaching job, sold my house and took up residence in a Norfolk commune. I was 30, and had published a handful of short stories in little magazines. The year that followed was idyllic. I helped to revive the commune's ancient overgrown garden, to renovate its ruined mansion. I wrote more stories. I fell in love. But as winter came, the commune started to founder on infighting and disillusionment. I left with my girlfriend and a woodturner and his gentle dog, and we rented a half-ruined Suffolk farmhouse. Months passed. The proceeds from the sale of my house declined. All of us were on the dole. We were very happy. I worked in a little timber-panelled room while hail pattered on the windows and the frosts came and went One day, almost in a dream, I wrote a story called Where Your Wings Were, which left me in tears. It grew out of the death of my sister in my childhood. It seemed so personal, so simple, so innocent. I could do nothing with it. I put it away. As the year turned, a letter arrived. It was from Peter Mortimer, the editor of the small northeastern Iron Press. He wanted to publish a collection of my stories. That evening, we cycled across the icy farm tracks to the pub in St James. We drank to literary celebrity and bestsellerdom, then we wobbled and skidded home again. Next day, I started to consider the contents of the book and didn't even think of finding a place for the story with the wings. It would take two years for the book to appear. By then, my money had gone. The book was called Sleepless Nights, it was 80 pages long, 500 copies were printed, and I was paid £50. But this little book, my first, helped to keep me calm and optimistic in the years that followed. I published more stories in more magazines. I had readers, even a handful of fans. I taught parttime. I wrote a novel, Seances, that was rejected by every UK publisher. One evening I found Where Your Wings Were in an old box file. The years had given it some distance from me. I rewrote it and sent it to Radio 4. It was broadcast The little story, left alone in the dark for so long, was proving to be some kind of seedbed. I rewrote it again, and a cluster of new, unbidden stories called Counting Stars grew out from it and from my childhood. When these were done, a new tale grew, about a boy with a poorly sister and about a creature with wings. When this book, Skellig, was published by Hodder, I was called a new writer. It was as-
MARGARET ATWOOD
The book appeared when I was 21. If it can be called appearing, that is. The location was Toronto, not at that time — to the naked eye — a hotbed of literary activity. They were still telling "the Toronto joke", then: first prize a week in Toronto, second prize two weeks in Toronto. If you were a young person who was serious about writing, you were expected to flee the place like a rat in the Dracula shipwreck scene, and that I duly did. But not before I had published this book. By "published", I mean that the book in question was sold in bookstores and reviewed in at least one periodical. It was not otherwise published. True to the Zeitgeist, I took a hand in the book-making: most young Canadian poets then
THEY MyST HAWE f HOUCWT 1 WAS A FOOL, A LOUA¥IC 01 - IU THE PAY - DIFFERENT
did something ofthe sort, as the few extant publishers were not clamouring for their wares. The book consisted of seven poems — short poems, luckily — for which I had won a university prize. It was printed in a cellar, on a flatbed press owned by a friend and colleague. Along with a fellow poet, I set the type. We had to do each poem separately, as there was a shortage of letter As. We ground out 300 copies of each poem, then folded the pages and stapled them together. The final edition was about 250, due to attrition. The cover was done with a lino-block: I carved the block, then set it into the flatbed. The stapled pages were glued into the cover with rubber cement — a mistake, because the glue dried out, as well as smelling odd. Then — how did I get the nerve? — I actually went around to various bookstores and got them to place the book. Bookstores were different then: small, individually owned, run by kindly gnomes with a tolerance for eccentricity. They must have thought that I was a fool or a lunatic, or — in the Toronto parlance ofthe day — "different", but this did not seem to bother them. As the book was small, it sold for 50 cents. I should have kept 249 of the things, as the price has now gone up considerably. The title of this tiny but peculiar effort was Double Persephone; the poems rhymed and scanned, and were about sex and death, with some rebirth tossed in: my optimism was showing early. As I recall, the word chthonic was in them, so it was pretty deep stuff. What do I think of them now? They weren't very good, but at least they were — oh, killing term — promising. I've been cheered up since by reading the juvenilia of other poets whose mature work I admire: Tennyson, for instance, has one that begins, "Airy, fairy Lilian". Best advice for young writers? This is a risky business. You're on a tightrope. Below is Niagara Falls. Courage. One step at a time. Don't look down. Margaret Atwood's latest novel is Oryx and Crake (Virago, £7.99; offer, £6.79)

I took a friend with me when I went to sign the contract. My editor would be a fellow English literature student, the jacket would be designed by someone at the art college, and one of my tutors would act as proof-reader. I was on the road, but had no idea how long and strange the trip would be. Ian Rankin's latest book is Fleshmarket Close (Orion, £17.99; offer, £14.39)
