would you take your own books with you? We laughed, and said no. My first book was lucky to come out at all, first because it was a collection of short stories. These are doomed in the trade, as all short story writers know, because publishers are constantly telling us so. Short stories "don't sell; readers don't buy them because readers don't like them". Actually, readers tend to love short stories. Everywhere I go, and everywhere I read to audiences, audiences tell me they love short stories. You'd never know this from, for example, The Big Read, because if you voted for a book of short stories on this scheme your vote was automatically discounted. No small reads allowed. It's harder to find short stories in bookshops. They go almost immediately on publication straight on to the shelves, whereas novels tend to lie around on tables and in display units for months, so there's hardly any browser purchase on stories. They get less review coverage. Publishers tend to pay much less for marketing them via book reps and sellers. Publishers would soon change their tune about short stories if there was, say, a major money prize, or a short story category on the Whitbread. I sent out my first collection, Free Love and Other Stories, to several publishers in 1994 and kept getting the same kind of letter back. We like these, but they're short stories. Can you write a novel? Eventually Virago took a chance and accepted them. I was ecstatic. I went to their offices in Camden and met my future editor, Ruth Petrie. The next day I heard she'd left and the company was going bankrupt. Oh, no! Then Virago got bought by a conglomerate. My book was sure to get lost in the scrum, I thought. But doughty Lennie Goodings brought it out, a small print run in a quite unusual shape, long and thin. Lennie kindly let me have the cover I wanted, a picture of Louise Brooks from the G. W. Pabst film Diary of a Lost Girl (1929). There were a few reviews. It won a prize. Virago was pleased. They asked: next time, can you write a novel? AH Smith's latest book is The Whole Story and Other Stories (Penguin, £7.99; offer, £6.79)
sumed that it must be my first book. No one had heard ofthe little Iron Press or the little Sleepless Nights. But both books shared a starting point in a room in an ancient Suffolk farm, and both were similarly important to me, in building that unpredictable pursuit called a literary career. David Almond's latest book is Kate, the Cat and Moon (illustrated by Stephen Lambert), Hodder Children's Books, £10.99; offer, £8.79
My first published book was a long time coming. I wrote a novel when I was 15 or 16. It was penned longhand on stolen school jotters, and concerned a teenager who, misunderstood in his small-town home, flees to the seedy glamour of London, where he ends up jumping into the Thames and drowning. My follow-up was a themed collection — poems, short stories and a novella — on the loose subject of room/space. The novella was an updating of Lord of the Flies to a comprehensive school, where a poster of Mick Jagger was having a demonic influence on the younger kids,. So far, so bad. When I reached university, I drifted from the novel to the poem. (I say "novel", but doubt that these early efforts would have stretched beyond 20 or 30 typed pages.) I was 22 when I started work on a comedy set in a Highland hotel. It was called Summer Rites and featured a one-legged, schizophrenic librarian, a famous American author kidnapped by the paramilitary wing of the Scottish National Party, and a young kid with paranormal powers. I sent this off to various publishers, none of which could see the genius of the piece. It probably didn't help that, although the thing was put together on a typewriter, I had yet to learn to put a space after each punctuation mark and two after a period. (It was single-spaced to boot.) Putting Summer Rites behind me, I started work on a long short story, which eventually became the opening section of The Flood. I was 23 and doing a doctoral thesis on the novels of Muriel Spark. But really I was spending more time on my own writing. Living in Edinburgh, I peered enviously across to Glasgow, where writers such as Alasdair Gray and James Kelman were igniting Scottish fiction. No more Miss Jean Brodies. The Flood was a fairly traditional narrative, a typical Bildungsroman in that it dealt with the town of my youth, none too well disguised. When the novel was finished, I took it in person to a publisher called Polygon. At that time, Polygon had just published Kelman's first collection of short stories, and was about to publish his first novel. Moreover, it was owned by the Edinburgh University Students' Publication Board. Soon, I began hearing rumours that the book would be accepted. The letter arrived at my bedsit, announcing that Polygon would be happy to print up 200 hardbacks and 800 paperbacks. They would pay me £200.
I've never sat down and re-read any of my own books. Why would I? I still remember them pretty much off by heart. I know what happens in them. I'd want to change things. I'd just get annoyed with myself. Maybe when I'm an old old lady in my nineties, if I live that long, I'll look at them again. But I doubt it; I think there'll always be something else, new or old, I'd rather read. Gertrude Stein on her death bed lamented the shortness of life and the too-many-books of it. Why would you ever want to read your own? When the first bound copy comes through the door from the publisher, that's it — finished. I was recently on a Desert Island books panel at the Edinburgh Festival with a couple of other writers; someone in the audience asked,
IAN RANKIN
ALI SMITH

But this little book, my first, helped to keep me calm and optimistic in the years that followed. I published more stories in more magazines. I had readers, even a handful of fans. I taught me. These are doomed in the trade, as all short story writers know, because publishers are constantly telling us so. Short stories and sell readers and buy them because readers ont like them. Actually, readers tend to love short stories. Everywhere I go, and everywhere I read to audiences, audiences tell me they love short stories. Youd never know this from, for example, The Big Read, because if you voted for a book of short stories on this scheme your vote was automatically discounted. No small reads allowed. Its harder to find short stories in bookshops. They go almost immediately on publication straight on to the shelves, whereas novels tend to lie around on tables and in display units for months, so not hardly any browser purchase on stories. They get less review coverage. Publishers tend to pay much less for marketing them via book reps and sellers. Publishers would soon change their tune about short stories if there was, say, a major money prize, or a short story category on the Whitbread. I sent out my first collection, Free Love and Other Stories, to several publishers in 1994 and kept getting the same kind of letter back. We like these, but the short stories. Can you write a novel? Eventually Virago took a chance and accepted them. I was ecstatic. I went to their offices in Camden and met my future editor, Ruth Petrie. Pabst film Diary of a Lost Girl 1929. There were a few reviews. It won a prize. Virago was pleased. They asked next time, can you write a novel? But both books shared a starting point in a room in an ancient Suffolk farm, and both were similarly important to me, in building that unpredictable pursuit called a literary career. I wrote a novel when I was 15 or 16. It was penned longhand on stolen school jotters, and concerned a teenager who, misunderstood in his small- town home, flees to the seedy glamour of London, where he ends up jumping into the Thames and drowning. My follow- up was a themed collection poems, short stories and a novella on the loose subject of me. The novella was an updating of Lord of the Flies to a comprehensive school, where a poster of Mick Jagger was having a demonic influence on the younger kids,. So far, so bad. When I reached university, I drifted from the novel to the poem. I say novel, but doubt that these early efforts would have stretched beyond 20 or 30 typed pages. I was 22 when I started work on a comedy set in a Highland hotel. It was called Summer Rites and featured a one- legged, schizophrenic librarian, a famous American author kidnapped by the paramilitary wing of the Scottish National Party, and a young kid with paranormal powers. I sent this off to various publishers, none of which could see the genius of the piece. It probably could help that, although the thing was put together on a typewriter, I had yet to learn to put a space after each punctuation mark and two after a period. It was single- spaced to boot. Putting Summer Rites behind me, I started work on a long short story, which eventually became the opening section of The Flood. I was 23 and doing a doctoral thesis on the novels of Muriel Spark. But really I was spending more time on my own writing. Living in Edinburgh, I peered enviously across to Glasgow, where writers such as Alasdair Gray and James Kelman were igniting Scottish fiction. No more Miss Jean Brodies. The Flood was a fairly traditional narrative, a typical Bildungsroman in that it dealt with the town of my youth, none too well disguised. When the novel was finished, I took it in person to a publisher called Polygon. At that time, Polygon had just published Kelmans first collection of short stories, and was about to publish his first novel. Moreover, it was owned by the Edinburgh University Students Publication Board. Soon, I began hearing at that the book would be accepted. The letter arrived at my bedsit, announcing that Polygon would be happy to print up 200 hardbacks and 800 paperbacks. They would pay me 200. Ive never sat down and re- read any of my own books. Why would I? I still remember them pretty much off by heart. I know what happens in them. Id want to change things. Id Id just get annoyed with myself. Maybe when Im an old old lady in my nineties, if I live that long, Ill look at them again. But I doubt it I think it always be something else, new or old, Id rather read. Gertrude Stein on her death bed lamented the shortness of life and the too- many- books of it. Why would you ever want to read your own? Author: teeman, tim
Title: Inter Alia Tim Teeman
Full_text:
books review
INTER ALIA TIM TEEMAN
■ Sunita hasn't had the best week on Coronation Street: tied up, tortured, and then set on fire by her love-rival Maya. So, a relief to know that in quieter moments the actress who portrays her, Shobna Gulati, is writing her first novel. "I've been working on it today," Gulati tells me, "and it's going well. I've written quite a lot of it already and I returned to it recently after a long break and cut lots and switched bits round." Gulati says the story focuses on a British Asian woman and is "quite autobiographical — it's my first novel, what do you expect?" Her friends have been positive. "I've shown a few people some chapters and they're desperate to know what happens next." Just like The Street, then. ■ William Fiennes, author of the bestselling travel book The Snow Geese, will relate this week how he went through a "life-changing experience" while travelling in Honduras with Oxfam. While there Fiennes picked organic coffee and blackberries and helped to make soap and wine and shared dirt-floored rooms with ducks and pigs. He also went to a remote community where the kids can't go to school in the winter because they risk getting washed away by a river. In a lighter moment he danced to Ace of Base in a village hall that is HQ for a women's group. To hear more, turn up at St Cross College, St Giles, Oxford, on Wednesday at 7pm. H Lynne Truss is staying faithful to the small publisher that took on her Eats, Shoots and Leaves. She has given her new book on modern manners, out next autumn, to Profile Books again — and also to the same American publisher, Gotham. ■ Dan Brown's super-soaraway bestseller The Da Vinci Code will be filmed next year. According to Variety, Tom Hanks is on the brink of a deal to play the hero. ■ A postscript from Ian Rankin who wrote in Weekend Review a couple of weeks ago about unwelcome guests at his Edinburgh home. "The six intruders returned, to my next door neighbour, who poured water over them," he reports. books@thetimes.co.uk

Author: Wood, Christopher
Title: New Books
Full_text:
SCREES CHRISTOPHER WOOD
GETTING INTO FILMS AND TELEVISION by Robert Angell, How To Books, £10.99 THE GUERILLA FILM MAKERS HOLLYWOOD HANDBOOK by Genevieve Jolliffe and Chris Jones, Continuum, £25 100 AMERICAN INDEPENDENT FILMS by Jason Wood, bfi, £13.99 "THE MASS of men," Henry David Thoreau correctly pointed out, "lead lives of quiet desperation." I don't suppose women fare better. The reason is our parched, monotonous lives, from which every droplet of glamour has evaporated under the merciless sun of labour. The solution is — somehow, anyhow, at the expense of our grandmothers if need be — to get into movies. Robert Angell has written the entry-level guide. He explains what everybody does in the film industry, and helps the reader aim at the right job (director, thank you). Courses are listed, as well as •who to pester to give you work. Debased, lesser media such as television and commercials are discussed. Angell can be guilty of stating the obvious ("Be patient, do thejob well and use the time to make contacts"), but if you know nothing about the film world beyond the certainty that you will die ifyou don't get into it, this could be a place to start. The Rolls-Royce of how-to fiim guides, however, is1 the Guerilla (sic) series, whose first incarnation in 2000 was The Guerilla Film Makers Handbook. Reprinted five times since, the book clearly succeeds in being, as the cover boasts, "The Ultimate Guide to Independent Film Making". That first book was aimed at the UK market. Now the authors have brought out
BRITISH FILM INSTITUTE
a Hollywood edition, in case the British film scene isjust too small a pond for the big fish that you are. Everything is in this book. It tells you how to write a script, how to lay it out, who to send it to, how to pitch an idea, how to get an agent, even how to beat writer's block ("Cook something. Clean something")- It explains legal, contractual and insurance issues as they impact on a film production, how to secure finance, where to blag grants. It also has wisdom on whether to film in 35mm or DV, how to be a location manager, why assistant directors need comfortable shoes, and why lavatories and catering are the most important things on a film set It explains sales, distribution and publicity — everything is in this book. When you've absorbed it, you might end up making something small but beautiful, like the movies in Jason Wood's IOO American Independent Films. He defines that awkward word independent, referring not just to economic matters (who pays for and distributes it), but aesthetic ones — "films and film-makers whose work expresses a sensibility that contrasts with prevailing political, sexual and racial ideologies". it sounds a bit right on, but read on because dozens of classics and relative obscurities are given useful, well-informed coverage by 'Wood, who traces the US indie scene back to the great John Cassavetes and includes also the best of John Sayles, David Lynch, Jim Jarmusch, etc. If Hollywood's dominance bothers you, here is evidence that it's far from being the only show in town. And with the Guerilla Handbook you can prove it yourself. So, go create — as Thoreau would almost certainly not have said.
Beef up on the work of Jim Jarmusch in IOO American Independent Films

Author: Marsh, Stefanie
Title: A space of her own
Full_text:
review books
A space of her own
Dava Sobel's tiny blockbuster Longitude turned history writing on its head. Now, she tells Stefanie Marsh, she is getting ready to navigate the heavens
Stars in their eyes: the Abbess (Anna Carteret) tests the device invented by the father of Sister Maria Celeste (Rebecca Hall) In Galileo's Daughter, above. Opposite: the writer Dava Sobel
Did Dava Sobel look this accomplished before hitting the big time? Even from a distance, her erect figure suggests predestined success. The high forehead, the face framed by thick short hair left not unflatteringly grey, brings to mind first Mount Rushmore, then a trio of American female high-achievers: Camille Paglia, Susan Sontag and, more incongruously, the sex therapist Dr Ruth Westheimer. Sobel will say that she finds success confusing and that she thinks of herself as "very odd", but nothing in her bearing suggests this. Hers is the face, I think as we shake hands, of a woman with both brains and a purpose. In the vernacular of her home town, New York, this is the face of a ball-breaker. Crunch go my knuckles. It is the sad fate of contemporary Americans, no matter how accomplished, that they should feel the need to excuse their nationality to a European. Almost the first thing that pops out of Sobel's mouth when we meet in Bath — where Peter Hall is directing the stage version of her second bestselling book-— is an apology. "It's a terrible thing to be an .American these days." Sobel knows all about our wrinkle-nosed ambivalence to her country, having struggled to find a publisher for her first, subsequently genre-redefining and blockbusting, little history book, Longitude. As ten editors in a row told her nine years ago, the Brits "don't want their history told to them by a foreigner". No such doubts bogged down the Italians a few years later when they were faced with Sobel's most recent book, about the relationship between Galileo and his daughter. How those British editors must kick themselves, considering how enthusiastically the British public gobbled up the story of John Harrison, the Yorkshire clockmaker who invented tiie first seaworthy dock and so enabled sailors to determine their longitude.
g A handful of academics continued to splutter their protest. One man, named Rex Cowan, systematically picked the book apart in The Oldie, sourly pronounting Sobel's work "a fairytale." Her crime was her weakness for the lflfi
colourful, sometimes unverifiable, anecdote. "History is always a partial record even when you're living ft," she says. "There's that great Italian expression: 'If it isn't true, it's still well told and worth telling.'" Most enthusiastic among her fans, Sobel claims, are builders, attracted, presumably, by the book's obvious love ofthe well-made. Many of them, she daims without sarcasm, have dedded that she must be a man and, therefore, "a more reliable authority". This too she has decided to interpret as a compliment Whatever the gender of its author, Longitude has made "a frightful amount of money" for its author. "Reports of my millionaire status are unfounded," she says, although she has never so far added up the cheques. Success has made her happier, she says, and, I could add, more confident too, judging by the dramatic evolution of her wardrobe (gone are
i feel i m mmG THE D1EAM OF 2©0 LlFiTliiiS'».2,AND imtmimmum FIGHT FOI A CAUSE
NOBBY CLARK
the buttoned-up shirt-blazer combinations of her forties). But success has also brought anxiety. Sobel's next job, as she sees it, is not so much to write another book (which she has already done — it's about the planets and will be out next year) but to answer the twin questions: "Why did this happen to me?" and "To what good purpose can I put the fame that I have achieved?" "Longitude has been published now in perhaps 30 countries. It's still in hardcover. This never happens. I feel that I am living the dream of 200 lifetimes. I often wonder if I've been given this. I've become famous and I sometimes think that there is something I should be doing with this platform, and I should be fighting for a cause — and perhaps I will." To understand the ambivalence about success we must first rewind to life before Longitude. Just over a decade ago Sobel was happily married with two children. Then her first husband
plants. Had he never left at all, Sobel would most likely still working as one of The New York Times's many competent sdence writers as well as churning out the odd book on back pain and arthritis. Certainly she would never have taken up dancing lessons and met the Italian tango teacher to whom she is now married. Instead, separation left her free to take up dandng, toy with becoming a telescope operator and spend several months trying to get an artide about John Harrison published Most editors rejected the story as esoteric and boring, but Harvard Magazine eventually relented, using a picture of John Harrison's elaborate prototype clocks on its cover. Were it not for that article, the keen-eyed vision of a small publishing house and that the then divorced Sobel fdt finandally able to risk $30,000 of her own money, Longitude would never have been written. One crucial person did not live to witness
dedded he wanted a divorce. His reason was straightforward enough: "I don't want to be married any more." Had he walked out a little earlier, Sobel would be known to a few readers as the little-known author of a guide to the medidnal properties of tropical
Sobel's success: her father, a dodor. An eccentric second-generation Russian Jew, his wilful personality and unorthodox views had much in common with Galileo's, says Sobel. And Harrison, a hard-working and self-made outsider, also shares many of his charaderistics. Sobel grew up with two "really good, really very odd" parents in the Bronx, where her partially deaf mother read the encydopaedia for fun and went to night school to learn to navigate the 40ft (12m) family sloop. "I couldn't have come out of my family unscathed," Sobel says cheerfully. "Yes, I would say I am an odd person." Some say the same about her older brother, a dentist, who gave new meaning to the word "anglophile" when he donated two pints of blood on a trip to London because he wanted to "contribute something to the country". Galileo's Daughter, a biographical exploration ofthe sdentists close relationship with his eldest daughter, Suor Marie Celeste, a nun, is based on 124 letters from daughter to father. In researching it, Sobel used the Italian that she had left to rust since university. When asked what she intends to do with her talent in the future, this 56-year-old mother of two answers like the earnest teenager she might have been 40 years ago: "I'm trying to live my life in a good way and make sure that my parents would be proud of me, even though they're gone." Fulfilling her promise is not enough, however. Sobd has established herself as a spedalist in the unsung and the negleded, having resurreded Harrison and unearthed Galileo's daughter. Soon it will be the turn of her father, a maverick in his day for his support of abortion when it was still illegal and his passionate belief in euthanasia. "My father had unusual opinions, and did things in his field in an unorthodox way, so he often drew critidsm. He really believed there was a time to die and that was up to the person. "Assisted suidde for the dying is something that interests me very much. I would certainly want it for myself if I were ill, so what would be the best way for me to support a cause?" The idea is embryonic but will take a literary form, she says — maybe a play. Sobel sees herself as an educator, a champion for curious ignoramuses keen to better tiieir knowledge. She hopes that her books have the power to make the world more comprehensible — and more meaningful. Her book on the planets will, she says, help the layman to make sense of the world and his place in it And for non-readers, there is always the Peter Hall production. Sobel has her own cameo, although she is played by an actress and referred to in the programme simply as "tourist". Many years ago, when Longitude first came out critics accused Sobel of being a tourist of another kind — an American sdence writer trespassing on territory reserved for British historians. It stung. But then, Sobel has withstood worse and come out vidorious — sleeker, more chic, richer, happier. And one doesn't hear much of Rex Cowan these days.
Theatre Royal, Bath (01225 448844); August 14

Hers is the face, I think as we shake hands, of a woman with both brains and a purpose. In the vernacular of her home town, New York, this is the face of a ball-breaker. Crunch go my knuckles. It is the sad fate of contemporary Americans, no matter how accomplished, that they should should feel the need to excuse their nationality to a European. Almost the first thing that pops out of Sobels mouth when we meet in Bath where Peter Hall is directing the stage version of her second bestselling book- is an apology. Its a terrible thing to be an. American these days. Sobel knows all about our wrinkle- nosed ambivalence to her country, having struggled to find a publisher for her first, subsequently genre- redefining and blockbusting, little history book, Longitude. As ten editors in a row told her nine years ago, the Brits who want their history told to them by a foreigner. No such doubts bogged down the Italians a few years later when they were faced with Sobels most recent book, about the relationship between Galileo and his daughter. How those British editors must kick themselves, considering how enthusiastically the British public gobbled up the story of John Harrison, the Yorkshire clockmaker who invented the first seaworthy dock and so enabled sailors to determine their longitude. g A handful of academics continued to splutter their protest. One man, named Rex Cowan, systematically picked the book apart in The Oldie, sourly the Sobels work a fairytale. Her crime was her weakness for the book ress, sometimes unverifiable, anecdote. History is always a partial record even when it living it, she says. Theres that great Italian expression If it is true, its still well told and worth telling. Most enthusiastic among her fans, Sobel claims, are builders, attracted, presumably, by the books obvious love and well- made. Many of them, she st without sarcasm, have seen that she must be a man and, therefore, a more reliable authority. This too she has decided to interpret as a compliment Whatever the gender of its author, Longitude has made a frightful amount of money for its author. Reports of my millionaire status are unfounded, she says, although she has never so far added up the book. Success has made her happier, she says, and, I could add, more confident too, judging by the dramatic evolution of her wardrobe gone are i feel i m mmG THE D1EAM OF 20 LlFiTliiiS. 2, AND WILL FIGHT FOI A CAUSE NOBBY CLARK the buttoned- up shirt- blazer combinations of her forties. But success has also brought anxiety. Sobels next job, as she sees it, is not so much to write another book which she has already done its about the planets and will be out next year but to answer the twin questions Why did this happen to me? and To what good purpose can I put the fame that I have achieved? Longitude has been published now in perhaps 30 countries. Its still in hardcover. This never happens. I feel that I am living the dream of 200 lifetimes. I often wonder if Ive been given this. Ive become famous and I sometimes think that there is something I should be doing with this platform, and I should be fighting for a cause and perhaps I will. To understand the ambivalence about success we must first rewind to life before Longitude. Just over a decade ago Sobel was happily married with two children. Then her first husband plants. Had he never left at all, Sobel would most likely still working as one of The New York Timess many competent and writers as well as churning out the odd book on back pain and arthritis. Certainly she would never have taken up dancing lessons and met the Italian tango teacher to whom she is now married. Instead, separation left her free to take up with, toy with becoming a telescope operator and spend several months trying to get an and about John Harrison published Most editors rejected the story as esoteric and boring, but Harvard Magazine eventually relented, using a picture of John Harrisons elaborate prototype clocks on its cover. Were it not for that article, the keen- eyed vision of a small publishing house and that the then divorced Sobel was ot able to risk 30, 000 of her own money, Longitude would never have been written. One crucial person did not live live to witness had he wanted a divorce. His reason was straightforward enough I never want to be married any more. Had he walked out a little earlier, Sobel would be known to a few readers as the little- known author of a guide to the the properties of tropical Sobels success her father, a man. An eccentric second- generation Russian Jew, his wilful personality and unorthodox views had much in common with Galileos, says Sobel. And Harrison, a hard- working and self- made outsider, also shares many of his family. Sobel grew up with two really good, really very odd parents in the Bronx, where her partially deaf mother read the word for fun and went to night school to learn to navigate the 40ft 12m family sloop. I would have come out of my family unscathed, Sobel says cheerfully. Yes, I would say I am an odd person. Some say the same about her older brother, a dentist, who gave new meaning to the word anglophile when he donated two pints of blood on a trip to London because he wanted to contribute something to the country. Galileos Daughter, a biographical exploration of very close relationship with his eldest daughter, Suor Marie Celeste, a nun, is based on 124 letters from daughter to father. In researching it, Sobel used the Italian that she had left to rust since university. When asked what she intends to do with her talent in the future, this 56- year- old mother of two answers like the earnest teenager she might have been 40 years ago Im trying to live my life in a good way and make sure that my parents would be proud of me, even though it gone. Fulfilling her promise is not enough, however. Sobd has established herself as a be in the unsung and the future, having left Harrison and unearthed Galileos daughter. Soon it will be the turn of her father, a maverick in his day for his support of abortion when it was still illegal and his passionate belief in euthanasia. My father had unusual opinions, and did things in his field in an unorthodox way, so he often drew as. He really believed there was a time to die and that was up to the person. Assisted in for the dying is something that interests me very much. I would certainly want it for myself if I were ill, so what would be the best way for me to support a cause? The idea is embryonic but will take a literary form, she says maybe a play. Sobel sees herself as an educator, a champion for curious ignoramuses keen to better the knowledge. She hopes that her books have the power to make the world more comprehensible and more meaningful. Her book on the planets will, she says, help the layman to make sense of the world and his place in it And for non- readers, there is always the Peter Hall production. Sobel has her own cameo, although she is played by an actress and referred to in the world simply as as tourist. Many years ago, when Longitude first came out critics accused Sobel of being a tourist of another kind an American who writer trespassing on territory reserved for British historians. It stung. But then, Sobel has withstood worse and come out even sleeker, more chic, richer, happier. And one st hear much of Rex Cowan these days. Theatre Royal, Bath 01225 448844 August 14

Author: Kelly, Ian
Title: Brain fodder for gourmets
Full_text:
books review
Brain fodder for gourmets
FOOD BOOKS IAN KELLY
"What, another work on cooking! For the past few years the public have been deluged with writings of this sort. I agree. But it is precisely all these works that give birth to (my) one." Menon (chef to the courts of Louis XV and XVI) in Le Manuel des Officiers de bouche, 1759 The chef Menon, so famous they named him once, may have thought his Manuel was the last word in food writing. But in this, as in his claim that the French monarchy would be pre-eminent for as long as French cuisine, he was wrong. Poor Menon. After him, the deluge. Two centuries later, two centuries of cookbooks and food theorists, restaurant critics and now even chef-biographers — it's enough to make a bibliophile head for the kitchen. Priscilla Parkhurst Ferguson tackles the issue head on: why care about food, and why care about French food in particular? Accounting for Taste:
The Triumph of French
Cuisine (University of Chicago Press, £1750) has all its academic ingredients in place: 50 pages of appendices, notes and bibliography and a generous dousing of US universityspeak ("the aestheticization that counter the materiality and ephemerality of food"). But don't be fooled. Parkhurst Ferguson has her nose in the right place, and an infectious lust for her subject that makes this trawl through the history and cultural significance of French food — from French Revolution to Babette's Feast via Balzac's suppers and Proust's madeleines — a satisfying meal of varied courses. Accounting for Taste brims over with both anecdote and insight, not to mention cartoons and illustrations, and is particularly good both on the written formalising of French cooking at the beginning of
the 19th century and on France's export of a sort of culinary-pastoral myth of itself. Mann ist, was er ifit — we are what we eat — as the German said to the Frenchman, and French culture is perhaps best understood through the bottom of a saucepan. Ferguson's chapter on Careme, the key figure in the birth of haute cuisine and more vitally in the dawning respectability of food via literature, is finely wrought and judiciously peppered with Careme's own words. Probably it's in the nature of food writing and food writers, but her academic's desire to feed the mind is never at the expense of a humane and palpably stickyfingered love of the act of eating, and she even rounds off her thesis with a mouth watering essay on a film: Babette's Feast I've done a fair bit of thinking about French food, and eating of it too, but neither will be quite the same again: if it's all a matter of taste, I for one feel mine accounted for. Alexis Soyer, chef at the Reform Club and with the British Army in the Crimean War, does not fit comfortably into the heroic ascendancy of French cooking, but this may be why his life story, amusingly dished up over seven courses in Ruth Brandon's lush The People's Chef: Alexis Soyer,
A Life in Seven Courses
(John Wiley and Sons, £16.99; offer £13.59), makes for such an interesting read. Soyer had a social conscience, worked in England, and was Protestant, which leaves Brandon with the twin problems of explaining both his uniqueness and the French and chefly traditions he followed or traduced. She triumphs in both regards, even if TTie People's Chef reads like an unusual hybrid of cookbook and Boy's Own adventure. No criticism there: such was Soyer's life. Soyer cooked at the opulent Reform Club, published bestselling cook-
II w j±sau lutiHiuiiMiTnnmnnTmnniiniiiuniiBiMiiiHiiiiHiiuiiiiiiiii'iii icr? P!
books — aimed cannily at the middle of the market or below — but is perhaps most famous for trying to relieve the Irish potato famine with nutritious cheap soups, and for an unlikely friendship forged in the hospital kitchens of the Crimea with Florence Nightingale. As Careme's biographer, I would have to take issue with the idea of Soyer as the "first celebrity chef — I back my guy — and also her definition of service a la francaise, but Soyer's impact on British cookJng was indubitably great (we may have him to thank for HP Sauce) and his life is epic in scale. Brandon has a picaresque adventure to narrate, but as with Careme, some unusual primary sources: cookbooks. They can be surprisingly illuminating, and Brandon has structured her book around seven courses, with recipes taken from various Soyer works, that make her authorial voice sing out in the appropriate setting of a kitchen. Some chapters work better than others. The Irish famine story is fascinating; the soup is not.
The book is lavishly garnished with etchings of the period — some Soyer's own, some more decorative than illustrative. A book full of Flashmanesque adventure and recipes that ends unexpectedly in Kensal Green Cemetery. Who said food writing was a limited genre? Gerald Samper, anti-hero of James Hamilton-Paterson's
Cooking with Fernet Branca:
A Novel (Faber & Faber, £10.99; offer £8.79), would adore The People's Chef, the food and the adventures. Whether his Gothic snobbery would lead him to appreciate the social conscience of a midVictorian like Soyer is more open to question. This novel is pickled in disdain, as much as in Fernet Branca, the scrawny last-picked kid of the drinks' cabinet team. There's been a bottle of Black Tower, a friend warns me, doing the rounds of South London dinner parties for a decade now: an unwanted gift of urban-mythic proportions. The Fernet Branca of the title is in this same tradition: an ingredient used to amuse the
cooks and disgust the recipient. Femet Branca may well sue. Gerald lives in Tuscany off his fortune and infamy as a ghost writer to sporting heroes, with back catalogue titles like Life in the Fast Lane; The Absolute Pits. His only near neighbour, Marta, a deadringer for Miriam Margolyes giving her finest impersonation of a middle-European vulgarian, co-narrates the story; a comedy of misunderstanding, Mafiosi and extraordinary food under the Tuscan sun. The neighbours loathe each other so intently that were this a Hollywood rom-com they would soon end up in bed together. This being Tuscany, and the protagonists being an effete English food-obsessive, and, well, Miriam Margolyes, they cook and record the recipes. Cooking with Fernet Branca is food-lit light on useful menus (Mussels in Chocolate anyone? Garlic ice-cream?) but larded with bitter satire and piquant wit, at the expense, often, of its readers and their dreams of Italy. You may want to rethink
your place in the sun after meeting the hideous inhabitants of Le Roccie. There are few characters to warm to: it is Hamilton-Paterson's style that wins hearts. I laughed out loud several times a chapter, which is considered rude in bed, I am told. Hamilton-Paterson's love of Italy, and of food, is heavily masked in a lurid and unkind humour — think of Stealing Beauty reworked by Bo' Selecta!—so don't look here for Under the next Tuscan Sun, look here for an unflattering mirror on every food obsessive and on a British tradition only just catching up with the food literature dominating the American and continental markets. And be warned: this could be you.
Ian Kelly is the author of Cooking for Kings: The Life of Antonin Careme (Short Books) He has recently performed in a stage adaptation of the book as part of the Brits Off Broadway season in New York. He is working on a biography of Beau Brummell to be published late next year

Author: Wood, Christopher
Title: New Books
Full_text:
CHRISTOPHER WOOD ON TWO DIRECTORS WHO MADE THE RULES - AND BROKE THEM
On Film-making by Alexander Mackendrick. Faber, £25, 0 571215610 instant Light Tarkovsky Polaroids. Thames & Hudson, £15.95, 0 500 54289 9 THE US-born, Scots-raised, Ealing-employed director Alexander Mackendrick retired from making films in 1969 in exasperation atthe amount of his time spent striking deals. He came to see his period at Ealing Studios — which produced some of the firm's sharpest movies, including The Man in the White Suit and The Ladyklllers — as having afforded blessed protection from the commercial winds which later dispersed his interest in the business. But the art of film remained a con^ming passion, and for 25 years after his "retirement" Mackendrick inspired students at the California Institute of the Arte. His class hand-outs apparently became treasured possessions, and some are now collected in an indispensable volume. Some students apparently found Mackendrick rather dusty and old-fashioned, and a section in On Film-making describes what the teacher was up against in those revolutionary days around the turn of the Seventies. "Do you agree with any of the following?" Mackendrick asked, listing "1. Plots are old-fashioned. A story with a plot is contrived, artificial and boring," before running through a list of then-popular aesthetic stances and ending: "I like to play with scenes of fantasy rather than reality. I like dream sequences and flashbacks. It's more interesting when you can play around with time." Mackendrick then patiently addressed these hratre new sentiments and ANORET A TARKOVSKY AllffiGKtS RESERVED
explained why it was still worth learning what Aristotle had to say about dramatic construction, and how it might improve screenplays. And Aristotle they were expected to know, as well as scientific theories about persistence of vision and how to draw a moderately convincing human figure so that they could construct storyboards. He summarised his teaching in a series of "Slogans for the Screenwriter's Wall" ("Passivity is a capital crime in drama", "Ambiguity does not mean lack of clarity", Two elements of suspense are half as suspenseful as one"), but like aH sensible teachers Mackendrick demanded that his precepts be challenged. Or as he put it "Remember no 'rule* is worth anything until you have discovered it afresh for yourself." Such a discovery could hardly be undertaken more pleasurably than by reading On Film-making. Mackendrick had a gift for lucidity of thought and language that helped to demystify film-making while retaining a sense of its mage and wonder; this book is as vital and enjoyable for the watcher of films as their potential maker. Now where did ) put that camcorder? Andrey Tarkovsky had what Mackendrick doubted could be taught an imagination allied to an acute eye - qualities as apparent in a collection of Tarkovsky's Polaroids as in his films. A first group was taken at home in Russia, of Tarkovsky's son, ofthe family dog and the bleached browns of parched grass, fields, trees. A second group was made in italy during the director's painful exile. "Artistic creation is by definition a denial of death," Tarkovsky wrote, and 18 years after his own death, this poignant and illuminating voiume would seem to echo his words.

Author: teeman, tim
Title: Inter Alia
Full_text:
review books
INTER ALIA TIM TEEMAN
■ After the acoustics fiasco at the British Museum last year — in which each table had to have a loudspeaker placed on it — the Man Booker Prize has finally announced a new venue for this year's prize, which will be presented on October 19. After much investigation - possible venues included Tate Modern, the Science Museum, Banqueting House and the remodelled piazza at the British Library - the organisers have gone for the Art Deco-style Lawrence Hall, part of the Royal Horticultural Halls in Westminster. It is 1,800 sq m and able to cope with 650 guests and a BBC
live broadcast. In fact one of
those BBC betweenprogramme idents was filmed here — the one featuring the manic acrobats twirling about on long bits of red sheet. ■ There are now more than seven million copies of The Da Vinci Code, by Dan Brown, in print, though it was published less than a year ago. Doubleday, its publisher, says that it is the only adult book to have sold so many copies in such a short time. Its closest competitor is Robert James Waller's The Bridges of Madison County, which sold six million copies in two years. Brown is now at work on a sequel. His first book, written with his wife in 1995, was rather different from his bestselling theological thriller: it was called, rather fabulously, 187 Men to Avoid: A Survival Guide For the Romantically Frustrated Woman. ■ A tip for aspiring literary agents. Andrew Wylie, aka the Jackal, tells The Washington Post that when he started no editors in publishing houses would see him, so he made friends with the receptionists. With their help he was able to feed his submissions into the right editorial hands. It obviously did the trick. books@thetimes.co.uk

Title: Bestsellers

Author: Davis, Clive
Title: Who Wants to Be a Jazz Millionaire?
Full_text:

SO IS IT ALL HYPE? There have been so many bogus sto - r ies about big-money advanc - es to unknown artists that these deals should perhaps be measured in a new unit of cur - rency . The Magnus would be named after Magnus Mills, the bus driver-turned novelist who was supposed to have been handed his own personal crock of gold in exchange for his debut book. After all the hy - perventilating had died down, the alleged fortune turned out to be rather less than he could have earned steering a Route - master along Oxford Street. So when news broke late last week that the 23-year-old singer-pianist Jamie Cullum
HE IS VIRTUALLY UNKNOWN, BUT SINGER JAMIE CULLUM HAS JUST SIGNED A £1 MILLION DEAL. CAN HE BE WORTH IT, ASKS CLIVE DAVIS
had signed a million-pound deal with Universal Music you could be forgiven for assuming that somebody was indulging in more speculation on the Magnus market. After all, Cul - lum is a jazz musician, and jazz musicians are more accus - tomed to seeing their names printed on social security cheques than on anything with lots of noughts. Hence Ronnie Scott's old joke: how do you make a million from jazz? Answer start with two million. But this time the deal is genuine. Cullum will receive slightly more than a million in return for four albums, with the first due to be released in the autumn .
Universal is the parent com - pany of Verve, home to the enormously successful Diana Krall, so it does not take a clair - voyant to see where Cullum may be headed. Dickon Stainer, the Universal execu - tive who has had a hand in the rise of classical-lite performers such as Russell Watson and girlie string quartet Bond, in - forms me that Cullum will be taking his band into the studio in the next couple of weeks to lay down some tracks. "He has a clear idea of what he wants," Stainer says. "We want to keep him true to himself.Other major labels, includ - ing Sony, were also on the trail of Cullum, who last year used his own money to release an acclaimed album, Pointless Nostalgic , mixing Harry Con - nick - style swing with some in - sp i r ed pop-flavoured originals . But why were Universal prepared to pay so much? "It was desperation," Stainer cheerfully explains. "We'd have done anything to sign
him. We'd have bungee - jumped off a cliff, if necessary. He's the most talented musi - cian we've ever come across." Viewers who saw Cullum make his TV debut on Michael Parkinson's show on Saturday may ask themselves if the record moguls had suffered a rush of blood. The choice of song, You're Nobody 'Til Some - b o d y Loves You, was, after all, a little tame, and the mid - Atlan - tic vocals had Connick stamped all over them. Why all the fuss? For one thing, though , Cul - l um was shrewdly tapping into the same audience that has ac - quired a taste for Robbie Wil - liams 's bestselling swing band theatrics. And even in that brief appearance on Saturday, it was clear that the diminutive pianist possesses enormous charisma . Where Williams's Swing When You're Winning of - fers nothing more than reheat - ed Rat Pack fingersnaps, Cul - lum is sculpting a genuinely original approach that blends past and present. Having gigged in rock bands too, he is as happy reinventing a Radio - head tune as he is delving into Sinatra's greatest hits. "HE'S THE MOST TALENTED MUSICIAN WE'VE COME ACROSS" The Connick comparisons are worth pondering too. Cul - lum is a grittier performer. But the first time I saw him play live last summer, I could not help recalling the evening, al - most a decade and a half ago, when Connick — then un - known here — gave an aston - ishingly assured London debut at the Dominion. Jazzniks were slow to re - spond then, partly because commercial success always arouses suspicion , partly be - cause Connick's matinee idol looks filled so many column inches. It took several years be - fore the critical establishment began to take him seriously. (Interestingly enough, Diana Krall was no overnight success with them either. She was, per - haps , too blonde for her own good.) Cullum may face simi - lar resistance at first, but only the most churlish soul would fail to acknowledge that he is a
truly gifted figure, part show - man , part unreconstructed jazzer. Like Connick — who was often portrayed as unbear - a bly cocky — he is aware of how much work he still needs to do. Anyone who has inter - viewed him will have been struck by how openly he talks of his desire to improve his piano technique so that he can express the ideas bubbling in his head. Will he make it in Ameri - ca ? October will offer the first test. That month he has a resi - dency at the Algonquin's Oak Room in New York. In con - trast to Robbie Williams, who is about as cosmopolitan as Shakin' Stevens, he has the po - tential to cross the water. Word is slowly circulating in Manhattan, according to the leading critic Will Friedwald. "I enjoyed the album," he says. "It was very well pro - duced , with a very good band.
I couldn't quite decide wheth - er he was the British Connick or the male Krall. I like him lots better than Connick (whom I can't stand) but not as much as Krall." It will be fascinating to see how the young hopeful fares. It is worth bearing in mind that the record industry has never quite got the best out of Connick, one of those restless figures who always seem more alive on the bandstand than in the studio. Nor will it be easy to compete with the impecca - ble Diana Krall. On the other hand, the introverted Canadi - an singer has scored her big - gest commercial successes with glossy, string-laden pro - duction values. Cullum has more than enough personality to achieve stardom without smoothing down the rough edges. Something tells me there will be many more cheques in the post.
Swinging on a star: Jamie Cullum is shrewdly tapping into a market Robbie Williams has opened up

Author: Jones, Nicolette
Title: Fantasy Matches how our Brains are Made
Full_text:
"FANTASY MATCHES HOW OUR BRAINS ARE MADE"
DIANA WYNNE JONES feels a mixture of gratitude and resentment about the enormous impact of J. K. Rowl - ing 's Harry Potter books — books which bear a certain re - semblance to her own. "It is marvellous that a whole lot of adults have now realised that this is good stuff to read.
DIANA WYNNE JONES WONDERS IF HER OWN WIZARDRY INFLUENCED J. K. ROWLING. AS SHE TELLS NICOLETTE JONES
Seems to have swept away the idea that was still extant when I started writing that fantasy was very bad for you because you ended up not knowing what was true." But although she makes no accusations of plagiarism, she finds it annoying that children, who "never look at pub - lication dates" , think she might have copied Rowling. "I think it is likely that J. K. Rowling read my books as a child and felt this is how chil - dren 's books should be. There are so many strong similarities and she is just the sort of age to have read them the first time round. If she didn't , it is very, very strange." In recent years, sales of Diana Wynne Jones's children's books, of which she has writ - ten 36 since 1972, have been climbing. This is de - spite the fact that The Merlin Conspiracy, out on April 7, is her first children's book for a decade. But in the wake of Pottermania her earlier books have been astutely repackaged by Col - lins , who recognised the potential of the fact that they share qualities with Rowling. Occasionally the correspondences are star - tling . Dogsbody, for instance, has a character called Sirius who transforms into a dog (Sirius the dogstar is the common inspiration); Charmed Life involves a boy in an unhappy fami - ly who grows up not knowing he is a wizard (al - though he believes his sister has powers). In gen - eral , Jones's are books in which the ordinary world and magical worlds collide, and in which plucky children confront dangers. Yet although there are overlaps in the con - tent , and even, Jones says, "verbal echoes",
Rowling and Jones are stylistically very differ - ent . Rowling's books are scrupulously struc - tured , with no detail unintended at the outset Jones's books have an unplanned logic, by which events tumble on, arising out of what has gone before, until everything ties together in the end. She does not always know where the story will go. "Sometimes you feel you are pro - ceeding in front of an enormous chasm and if you stop you'll fall in." The unexpectedness of her books may stem from the unexpectedness of her own beginnings as a writer "You don't have it in you," her moth - er said to her dyslexic eight-year-old daughter when the latter announced she would become a writer. Encouragement was not her parents' forte. Jones and her two younger sisters lived a life that combined, she says, neglect with pres - sure to do well at school. It did not involve any - one remembering to feed them regularly or clothe them properly. She came to know she would write fantasy "because I was not able to believe in most people's version of normal life". Jones's parents, an Oxford-educated mother and an academic father, ran a residential cultur - al centre for young adults in Essex, to which they devoted all their efforts. Their daughters in - habited a "shack" 100 yards away from the main house, where they narrowly avoided incin - erating themselves as they regularly knocked over the paraffin heater, and once almost hanged Jones's sister Isobel, who asked to be suspended by a rope like a pantomime fairy. It is quite common for the parents to be vil -
lains in Jones's books. "Adults in children's books used to be supposed to do everything right When I started the children's book thing was beset with rules. My writing was an exercise in how to slip sideways through the gaps." She had few books as a child. Her mother for - bade some on the grounds that they were "silly" — and these were always fantasy. Her father, to save trouble at birthdays and Christmas, kept the Swallows and Amazons series in a locked cup - board and would bring out one volume between the girls when presents were required. The girls
classified their bookshelves, and one section was called "Goddy books": "The books we were allowed to read were all those books about chil - dren getting together to Do Good. We never touched them, though I argued with Isobel about The Railway Children, which she loved and I said was a Goddy book" Jones has three sons and five grandchildren, and lives with her husband John Burrow in Bris - tol , where he taught English at the university She started to write when her sons were at school, keeping work on top of the fridge, and
jotting down ideas when she could. The boys would test her on what they had just said, recog - nising her "total absence of mind". But she was inspired by reading to them all the children's books she had not been allowed. Her boys " im - mediately got restive as soon as they were being preached at I thought, 'let me see what I can do that flouts the rules and interests children but can still get published'." Once she started to write, the "dam broke" and she produced three or four books a year. She had a habit from childhood of "mytholo - gising the whole county"; she and her sisters would construct imaginary lives around the characters they saw, including the "six cross - eyed bothers: the eldest had eyes that were just too close together, but they got worse down the line until the youngest was completely cross - eyed " , and the "clone girls" — a family of nine creepily similar sisters. These last inspired the idea, in Charmed Life, of identical girls taking each others' places in parallel universes. Real life finds its way into her stories: a wiz - ard in The Merlin Conspiracy resembles the Welsh preacher grandfather to whose home she was evacuated briefly at the age of five; Chresto - manci , the wizard hero of her Worlds ofChresto manci series, was handsome and dapper like her father. She is strong on bossy elder sisters — based partly on herself and partly on her moth -
er . The Merlin Conspiracy includes two awful lit - tle girls, identical twins, who constantly behave badly in ways that most girls (including her granddaughters) do "maybe once or twice a month". A kindly elephant in that book was in - spired by an elephant at London Zoo, under whose legs her first toddling granddaughter ran obliviously before she could be stopped, and which "did a polka" to avoid the child. But Jones cannot bear too much reality. "It seems to me that a lot of very realistic books are like journalism and feeble as a result telling you one thing about the present day." The essential premise of humanity, she believes, is "what if?" : it is the question that makes the ape put a flint on a stick to kill a lion. "Fantasy matches the way our brains are constructed," she says. The "what ifthat triggered The Merlin Con - s p irac y is: "What if kings still travelled the coun - try as they did in medieval times, staying at dif - ferent stately homes?" The protagonists of this novel are a girl who travels with the "King 's Progress" and a teenage boy lately transported from a world like ours, though his origins are
mysterious. It is a rich tale of conspiracy and ad - venture , eight years in its conception. "It is a mi - rage , though, that I did not write anything in that time," says Jones, "I was writing for adults — humorous books that arose out of my Tough Guide to Fantasy Land, a send-up of Tolkien imi - tators . They were published for adults — I nev - er have a sense of whether my audience is adults or children: if I do I get self conscious and muscle-bound and can't write a thing. I write be - cause I have thought of a marvellous story and want to know what happens next" Another motive to is to "provide a space where children can relax and walk round their problems and think 'Mum 's a silly fusspot and I don't need to be quite so enslaved by her no - tions '. Everybody ought to think for themselves I feel profoundly for those children who are rushed from ballet to elocution and are never given a spare moment to be themselves. You need to extract yourself from the turmoil of oth - er people's interventions."
• The Merlin Conspiracy, Coffins, £12.99 (offer, £1039 plus £1.95 p&p)
